IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will develop and apply analytical technology enabling nanoscale characterization of biomolecular condensates (nanoBMCs) in living neurons using data from super-resolution single particle tracking imaging. Current BMC analyses mostly rely on fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) on large BMCs which overlooks potential nanoscale BMCs likely to act as “seeds” for the generation of larger BMCs and of irreversible amyloids associated with Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Based on spatiotemporal indexing, our proposed analytical pipeline will enable characterization of the dynamic spatiotemporal nanoscale organization of wildtype and AD- mutant Tau and a-synuclein trapped in these enigmatic membraneless nanoscale compartments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This project aims to uncover the mechanisms by which the cortex controls its processing. We will use new closed-loop stimulation and laminar recording technology for direct causal manipulation of neural activity and the recording of its consequences. We will test the hypothesis that deep cortical -layer alpha/beta rhythms carry top-down predictions that inhibit the superficial-layer gamma/spiking that feedforward predicted sensory inputs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The prevalence of obesity is increasing in the United States and worldwide with significant negative effects to both health and the economy. This study will evaluate and improve three new minimally invasive image-guided therapies for morbid obesity in which interventional techniques are used to suppress the body's signals for feeling hungry, leading to weight loss. Our goal is to use new imaging techniques and devices to make these procedures safe, accurate and effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Immune cells can sense the changing levels of proteins and produce antibodies to protect host from virus infection. This response involves a complex network of signaling molecules. We aim to understand how this signaling network is organized to respond to the changing concentration of proteins so that we can design better strategies to improve immune defense against virus infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) is a challenging and highly prevalent human disease that has a major genetic component, but many of the identified genetic risk loci for the disease remain unexplored with unknown target genes or tissues in which they act. In my prior work I have used human genetic data from multiple individuals and discovered that one of those uncharacterized genetic loci affects a new gene in endothelial cells called REST. This proposal will use novel laboratory genetics methods that manipulate endothelial cells in the lab and a genetic mouse model of REST inactivation to understand how our DNA affects REST in endothelial cells and how REST can affect the walls of our arteries to cause ASCVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this research is to inform regulatory efforts to minimize marijuana (MJ) use in disproportionately- impacted populations, in states with legalized recreational MJ and those that subsequently legalize it; this proposal’s immediate objective is to examine the recreational MJ market, MJ use, and related perceptions in market segments of diverse young adults. Our scientific premise builds on literature that indicates that licit drug retail marketing – both brick- and-mortar and online – target certain populations (e.g., young adults, racial/ethnic and sexual/gender minority groups) and the negative consequences of such retail on substance use in these groups; based on existing evidence, our central hypothesis is that exposure to MJ retailers and their marketing, advertising strategies targeting specific consumer market segments (defined by key sociodemographics or psychographics), and increased availability of products and promotions may contribute to increased MJ use in these groups. We include dissemination plans to translate tools/findings to practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Deficiency of genes involved in nuclear excision repair (NER) has been linked to Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) and cancers including skin cancer, however the mechanism regulating NER is not fully understood. This application is aimed to uncover a novel And-1-mediated pathway regulating NER and skin tumorigenesis. The proposed study will help to understand how skin tumor is initiated and benefit the development of therapeutic approach to treat skin tumor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This study is designed to improve our understanding of the changes in brain structure and function that result from post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus, a form of brain injury that is common in prematurely-born infants and associated with high rates of disability and requirement for repeated neurosurgical intervention. Employing a multidisciplinary approach, we will use information from cutting-edge magnetic resonance imaging studies to identify modifiable mechanisms that underlie this disease and address long-standing clinical questions regarding the impact of neurosurgical treatment on brain development. The overarching goal is to establish an innovative line of neurosurgical treatment strategies designed to thwart the harmful effects of post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus and support clinical trials seeking to improve outcomes in this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Poor nutrition and bedrest are common in the pediatric intensive care unit, and both practices are associated with poor outcomes in young survivors of critical illness. We propose a clinical trial to determine the feasibility of an innovative intervention that combines optimal protein delivery and early exercise in critically ill children. The results of this study will help determine the safest and most effective strategy for these interventions, and advance investigations to improve long-term, patient-centered outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative 8. Project Narrative Hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin (HPFH) mutations reduce the severity of β-hemoglobinopathies and can be introduced experimentally and for therapeutic benefit. The aim of this proposal is to understand mechanisms of naturally occurring and therapeutically induced HPFH. Once the mechanisms are better understood, it will be possible to develop safe and effective precision medicine-based treatments for β- hemoglobinopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All cells produce a contingent of incomplete proteins due to surprisingly common errors in gene expression, and mechanisms exist to suppress these truncated protein variants, suggesting that they are highly cytotoxic; however, this proposition has not been systematically tested. In the proposed work, I will harness a powerful new method for massively parallel measurements to determine the cytotoxicity of incomplete proteins across proteomes. Combined with complementary techniques, this approach will allow me to address fundamental questions regarding the importance and function of nonsense-mediated quality control mechanisms, the roles of incomplete proteins in the bactericidal activities of antibiotics, and the evolutionary consequences of suppressing incomplete protein-coding mutations, with implications for the 10-15% of human diseases linked to premature truncation variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The tobacco industry’s decades of manipulations to the nicotine form and length of tobacco leaf (long vs. fine cut) in moist snuff (i.e., dip) have resulted in a product with strong appeal and addictive qualities, which contributes to health inequities in Appalachia where the prevalence of use remains high. The proposed research will evaluate how level of smokeless tobacco (SLT) dependence is associated with characteristics of moist snuff (e.g., total nicotine, form of nicotine, and tobacco cut) used by adolescents and adults in Appalachian Ohio, as well as how variations to tobacco cut and nicotine form affect product use behaviors and nicotine delivery. Results will provide justifications for local, state, or federal regulations aimed at reducing the appeal and addictiveness of moist snuff.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research spanning recent decades has established that electroencephalography (EEG) can be an effective tool for identifying Alzheimer’s disease (AD) at an early stage. Using machine learning, SPARK Neuro is unlocking the full potential of EEG to better assess cognitive health and neurodegeneration. This neuroanalytic platform— called SPARK Scan—will be a standardized, objective, non-invasive, cost-effective diagnostic tool capable of highly sensitive and specific detection of cognitive impairment across the entire disease continuum, vastly expanding AD screening initiatives and providing neurological insights to aid in the diagnosis and tracking of disease progression.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it intends to identify a new and improved method of contraceptives for women. Ineffectiveness of current over-the-counter (OTC) contraceptives is one of the major contributors to the high unintended pregnancy rate in the United States. This project aims to provide a proof-of- concept outcome for a novel on-demand contraceptive that keeps semen in a gel-like state in the vagina and blocking of sperm transport in the female reproductive tract.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Changes in the elastic properties of connective tissue elements within muscle are associated with several neuromuscular disorders, aging, and occur secondarily to stroke and spinal cord injury. A fundamental understanding of the influence of these elements on muscle mechanical function will inform the design of rehabilitative strategies and interventions to improve muscle-tendon function. An improved understanding of how both muscle fluid mechanics and elastic elements influence the mechanical behavior of healthy muscle-tendon units may also aid in the design of prosthetic devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: We propose to study the neuronal mechanisms underlying impaired contextual discrimination, which is an endophenotype of mood and anxiety disorders. Specifically, we will attempt to demonstrate that pattern separation is likely the neural mechanism underlying contextual discrimination. In addition, our results may suggest that strategies aimed at modulating hippocampal activity either by stimulating neurogenesis or by inhibiting the activity of mature granule cells will have potential therapeutic benefits for decreasing the contextual discrimination deficits that often accompany mood and anxiety disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Improved methods for deriving high quality affinity reagents will be needed to keep up with the pending impact when single molecule protein sequencing instrumentation comes ‘online’ in the next few years. When that time comes, it is not a realistic expectation to be able to go to an existing Ab catalog for mAbs that are well-validated, cloned, and sequenced, and that work in specific applications against newly discovered biomarkers. The high costs and low throughput of current antibody-generating technologies represent significant roadblocks to the development of a comprehensive and broadly available resource of renewable affinity reagents. Thus, there is an urgent need for all Abs to be defined by their sequences and made recombinant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When blood clots form in the large veins, a common condition known as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), patients are treated with blood thinning medications, which carry the risk of bleeding and are ineffective at dissolving the clot, ultimately leading to the risk of recurrent DVT and chronic leg swelling, pain and ulcers (post thrombotic syndrome). Immune cells (monocytes/macrophages) help to break down the thrombus, and accelerate this process without bleeding risk. This research proposal is intended to evaluate the role of a common cellular signaling pathway, TLR4, in monocytes/macrophages in directing thrombus resolution, assess potential as a therapeutic strategy, and provide advanced immunologic training for a promising young surgeon-scientist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The prevalence of allergic diseases is increasing worldwide. The long-term objective of this project is to investigate the fundamental mechanisms underlying the etiology of these immune-mediated diseases. Specifically, we will investigate how exposure of airway epithelium to environmental allergens initiates the immune responses that culminate in the disease process underlying allergic inflammation. Successful completion of this project will provide new prevention and treatment strategies for these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this research is to evaluate the impact of a culturally tailored, intergenerational, home-based type 2 diabetes intervention for American Indian adult diabetes-related health outcomes including HbA1c. We will also evaluate the impact of the program on enrolled adult's children in terms of diabetes risk and protective factors. If the intervention is effective, American Indian communities may benefit from an empirically supported, family-based model with promise to break the cycles of intergenerational diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Repair and regeneration of the lung alveoli are essential to restore the ability of gas exchange after lung injury. The molecular pathways that drive this process are poorly understood. The current proposal seeks to characterize a newly identified epigenetic and potentially druggable process that regulates how cells differentiate and reprogram from one state to another.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of our Program is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which human cytomegalovirus regulates molecular signaling in the host to establish latency and reactivate. Despite advances in diagnostics and therapeutics, HCMV remains a major life-threatening complication following solid organ or stem cell transplantation. Our projects will define a network of virus-host interactions that will inform antiviral strategies to control HCMV latency and reactivation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative: Continuous Evolution of Proteins with Novel Therapeutic Potential We have successfully evolved many different classes of proteins with new and altered activities using a technology that we developed to evolve biomolecules ≥100-fold faster than conventional laboratory evolution approaches. We propose to use this technology to evolve novel proteins with therapeutic potential, or that serve as new tools for therapeutics discovery. Success would enable the development of next-generation therapeutic agents to treat human diseases including genetic and neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the leading cause of dementia and the sixth leading cause of death in the United States, while the current disease incidence indicates approximately 16 million Americans will be affected by 2050 without an effective treatment. This proposal will develop intelligent computer-based network medicine and systems pharmacology tools, capable of searching human genome sequencing findings and existing drug-target databases, while also testing the most promising network-predicted repurposable drugs and drug combinations using large-scale patient longitudinal data complemented by in vitro and in vivo mechanistic observations. The innovative network methodologies and potential prevention/therapeutic approaches developed in this proposal will prove to be novel and effective ways to improve outcomes in long-term dementia care and quality of life for the rapidly growing AD population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Heart diseases remain leading causes of death in industrialized countries including the US. The overall goal of this project is to develop new gene therapies that employ engineered prokaryotic sodium and calcium channels. The ability of these therapies to improve electrical and mechanical function of the heart will be tested in mouse models of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: BRAFV600E-positive papillary thyroid cancers (PTC) correlate with metastasis and increased mortality and develop resistance to current treatments; accurate delineation of the critical factors in aggressive PTC is therefore urgently needed for early diagnosis and effective new therapies. Although the FDA has approved selective BRAFV600E inhibitors that showed promise in clinical trials, primary and secondary resistance to these inhibitors has been widely reported, and our studies of the impact of thrombospondin1 (TSP-1) on the PTC microenvironment and the CDK4/6-E2F1 pathway on genomic instability imply novel targetable mechanisms. We recently identified the first thyroid-specific long intergenic noncoding RNA (lincRNA), which is epigenetically silenced by BRAFV600E to deregulate iodine metabolism, promote tumor cell survival and resistance, but is rescued by a trimodal combination of anti-BRAFV600E-EZH2-CDK4/6 drug therapies for aggressive BRAFV600E-PTC; our analysis of this lincRNA’s mechanisms and regulation will have a significant translational impact on patient outcomes by identifying critical factors in PTC and supporting clinical trials of new, more accurately targeted combination therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: This project focuses on generating two critical tools to characterize newly identified protein assemblies (termed “biomolecular condensates”) that regulate the function of microglia (brain-resident cleaning cells) in aging and Alzheimer Disease (AD). Specifically, we will develop and validate: i) a CRISPR engineered microglial cell line that allows us to monitor these condensates in living cells; and ii) novel workflows to identify additional protein components of these condensates. These tools, which will be shared with the field, will enable future work to understand how these condensates regulate microglial function - knowledge that will be pivotal in designing precision biomarkers and therapeutics to manage microglial dysfunction in aging and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research will shed light on how reprogramming of the creatine metabolic pathway participates in breast cancer metastasis and help us to better understand key enzymes in creatine metabolism of breast cancer. Creatine metabolism holds promise as prognostic indicator and potential therapeutic target for metastatic breast cancer. We will develop integrated highly multiplexed mass spectrometry imaging and immunohistochemistry approaches to detect creatine metabolic enzymes and creatine metabolites in breast cancer specimens for future use in pathology workflows.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Chronic infection with Trypanosoma cruzi results in chronic inflammation and progressive cardiac fibrosis, known as Chronic Chagasic Cardiomyopathy. Our goal is to better define the mechanisms of inflammation and fibrosis to identify host specific targets for intervention. Ultimately, this approach will identify therapies that can be used in an integrated, multimodal treatment strategy to preserve cardiac health and improve clinical outcomes for patients with CCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The Harvard-wide Program on Antibiotic Resistance is designed to fill critical gaps in knowledge that will allow new approaches for treating serious infections with antibiotic resistant staphylococci and enterococci to be developed. This is done by identifying and where needed, creating new advanced technologies to gain insight into how these microbes can be targeted by new classes of molecules, and by more thoroughly understanding how they survive treatment with current antibiotics. These critical advances are accomplished through synergistic interaction among a multidisciplinary team ranging in expertise from mathematics to infectious diseases, with each sharing their special insight and working together to achieve goals that otherwise would be unattainable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The Harvard-wide Program on Antibiotic Resistance is designed to fill critical gaps in knowledge that will allow new approaches for treating serious infections with antibiotic resistant staphylococci and enterococci to be developed. The Administrative Core provides overall coordination and orchestration of this effort, and facilitates sharing results from this project with the scientific community to catalyze progress in addressing the global health crisis of antibiotic resistance. This is done by creating structures that enhance the synergistic interaction among a multidisciplinary team, and that insure the rigorous execution of the experimental plan in a manner that is fully transparent, accountable, and authenticated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Oriented cell divisions represent a crucial mechanism to control cell fate choices, and in the skin epidermis, a progenitor’s division axis dictates whether it self-renews or differentiates. When orientation errors cause this balance to be perturbed, this results in altered cell fates, disrupted tissue architecture, and potentially cancer. In this proposal, we will determine how division orientation is influenced by both intrinsic factors such as polarity cues, and extrinsic factors such as the adhesive forces within the local microenvironment, and investigate how its dysregulation may contribute to the pathogenesis of congenital human skin diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The Mother Machine Technical Core provides access for each of the subprojects to leading-edge technology for continuous single cell imaging of populations of thousands to millions of bacteria per experiment. This capability, which cannot readily be replicated in other labs and is not commercially available, allows rare cells in an altered physiological state, such as those that persist despite the presence of otherwise lethal levels of antibiotics, to be examined for susceptibility to new antibiotics being designed in this P01. It also provides a deep, rich and precise description of every mutant in a large mixed population, such as mariner transposon insertions in a Tn-seq mutant pool, along with the ability to recover and further study mutants of interest, for studies identifying new antibiotic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections are responsible for significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. Project 1 seeks to capitalize on discoveries about S. aureus that were made through collaborating on innovative technological and conceptual approaches with other Project Team members. We will elucidate two S. aureus pathways that are targets for anti-infective compounds, and identify compounds and strategies that may allow us to exploit these pathways to treat MRSA infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE There is an urgent need for the development of new antibiotic agents to help combat the increasing number of severe infections and the development of resistance. The main objective of this proposal is to study the efficacies and mechanisms of action of compounds that are active even against resistant methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus bacteria that are in a metabolically inactive state and are thus tolerant to conventional antibiotics. These studies have the potential to play a pivotal role in identifying novel targets for drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cystic fibrosis (CF) patients have abnormal clearance of viscous mucus due to genetic dysfunction of the Cl- channel, CFTR. We have identified that ginsenosides from Korean Red Ginseng improve epithelial Cl- transport through the alternative TMEM16A Cl- channel pathway. The current proposal will test a ginsenoside TMEM16A potentiator in infected CF rats to demonstrate a new treatment for CF airway disease.

PHR: Pediatric anxiety disorders are common and severely impair the lives of youth and their families; yet less than half of anxious youth receive any intervention. The goal of this application is to reduce this mental health service gap by enhancing the capacity of primary care providers (PCPs) to identify and reduce anxiety, by refining, assessing the feasibility, and conducting a pilot randomized controlled trial of the Anxiety Action Plan, a brief PCP-delivered intervention to reduce pediatric anxiety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The enterococci are microbes that are extremely difficult to eliminate from the hospital environment or from sites of infection. Much of this is due to an intrinsic ruggedness that distinguishes them from their ancestors as well as most other species, but the genetic basis for this property is yet to be clearly defined. This proposal identifies unique genes that are shown to be functionally important for enterococcal survival and resistance to antibiotics, and identifies the underlying mechanism so that they can be targeted therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Air pollution may play a role in the development of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) but our knowledge about mechanisms is limited. Here, we test key underlying pathways, and among them, is the pathway through the olfactory system, a direct anatomic connection for environmental toxicants to reach the brain. We will estimate the effect of air pollution exposure on neurocognitive and olfactory outcomes in 5 well- characterized, longitudinal ADRD cohorts using integrated air pollution exposure data from the MESA Air and MESA Coarse studies, and examine how resultant neuropathology and direct deposition of PM (assessed by advanced microscopy) explains these relationships.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project studies how the psychedelic drug lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) alters the neurophysiological functions of the sensory and memory neural circuits inside the living brain. Its outcomes will advance our understanding of how sensory and memory functions are impacted by classic hallucinogens, uncover possible risks when such drugs are explored as potential therapeutics for mental disorders such as depression, anxiety disorders and drug abuse, and provide insights into how hallucinatory symptoms in schizophrenia and other psychiatric disorders may be produced and treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE With a highly representative sample of nearly one million adolescents (N=900,000) regularly screened for cannabis use in Kaiser Permanente Northern California’s large integrated healthcare delivery system from 2015-2023, this multi-method study will test whether and how California state recreational cannabis legalization (RCL) and local policies (e.g., retailer bans or caps, product and advertising restrictions, taxes, health warnings) impact adolescent cannabis use and cannabis-related health conditions using a quasi-experimental interrupted time series design. Quantitative results will be complemented by post-RCL interviews with addiction medicine, pediatric, and emergency department clinicians and adolescent focus groups to gain insights into the clinical impacts of RCL on adolescents. Together, results will have immediate public health and clinical implications, providing urgently needed data to identify potentially actionable areas for future policy adaptations and aid decision making for public health practices to reduce adolescent cannabis-related harms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Training dental providers to effectively promote the human papillomavirus vaccine (HPV-V) with their patients could prevent future HPV-related cancer of the mouth and throat in those who become vaccinated. This study will develop HPV-V promotion training and tailored scripts to support dental providers in promoting HPV-V. By testing this intervention in a real-world dental setting, this project has the potential to help increase HPV vaccination rates, reduce HPV-related cancers, and serve as a model for other organizations providing dental care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Phthiocerol dimycocerosate (PDIM) are lipids in the outer membrane of the pathogen Mycobacterium tuberculosis that are crucial for defending attacks by the immune system and antimicrobial compounds. The lack of routine screening and selection tools for PDIM levels have led to great uncertainty in experimental work in Mtb, and yielded countless in vivo studies where spontaneous PDIM mutations have led to inexplicable phenotypes. We will develop screening and selection tools to get rid of this issue and use those research instruments to understand PDIMs role in mycobacterial pathogenesis and drug tolerance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Mechanistic concepts from model organisms are used to translate ideas for therapeutics, vaccine design, managing infectious diseases and immune pathologies into humans. Mice are one of the most widely used preclinical models of human immunity, and the studies in our proposal will aid in predicting how structural variation between the genomes of model organisms and the human genome contribute to humans acquiring (or losing) cell-type and stimulation-dependent gene expression patterns and functions in immune cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the increasingly recognized role of the environment in the spread of virus aerosol particles and controlling many of the pathways that lead to the deposition and resuspension of viruses, the mechanism underlying the effect of the environment is poorly understood. We propose to address this need by using molecular dynamics and computational modeling with the spatial, and temporal collection of aerosolized virus particles to track their deposition and resuspension within a model hospital room at different ventilation configurations. The knowledge gained in the process helps develop better ventilation strategy guidelines to reduce the spread of virus particles in hospitals and mitigate disease transfer in these or other facilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE Bacterial infections in skin wounds cause suffering and distress in over 6 million patients in the US each year and incur treatment costs totaling over $25 billion annually. The current arsenal of antibiotics available to treat these infections is now almost empty due to the rise of bacterial resistance. Fundamentally new approaches that move beyond conventional antibiotic strategies and target bacterial virulence rather than cell growth would provide means to address this threat and have substantial impacts on human health; this proposal introduces such a strategy by targeting a chemical signaling process common to bacteria found in wound infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammatory responses in the peripheral and central nervous system appear to play a critical role in the development and progression of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The ability to non-invasively assess whole-body immune signatures in AD patients is a critical unmet need that will improve diagnosis and disease monitoring, as well as the development and screening of effective therapeutics. This work aims to reveal new insights into the complex neuroimmune interactions involved in AD pathogenesis using novel molecular imaging and immune profiling techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  There is a paucity of effective treatments for cerebral palsy and this proposal tests whether an essential enzyme co-factor is involved in brain injury before birth. Using animals in which genes have been altered in their genome by genetic engineering methods, and advanced methods of magnetic resonance imaging, the cellular and genetic basis of brain regional injury will be investigated. These studies will lead to a better understanding how treatment with the same co-factor can reverse the movement disorders caused by insults to the fetal brain before birth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Young adult alcohol misuse is a public health crisis for which new intervention approaches are needed. Smartphone apps are promising as in-the-moment intervention tools, but none are empirically supported for young drinkers. BAC is an important in-the-moment intervention target and there is need for enhanced knowledge that can be addressed via technology as proposed in this grant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE In this proposal, we propose to characterize the profile, fate and function of inflamed oligodendrocyte precursor cells (iOPC) that fail to repair myelin and instead develop the capacity to activate cytotoxic CD8 T cells in the brain. We aim to develop therapies that specifically target the signaling pathways leading to the dysregulated iOPC phenotype in order to suppress the damage and facilitate myelin repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The ability to carry out voluntary motor commands diminishes with age, reducing the quality of life and lifespan of individuals. Thus, it is critical to determine the changes within the somatic motor system that contribute to age- related motor deficits. Understanding the changes α-motor neurons undergo during aging is crucial for the future development of treatments that preserve motor function into old age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Increasing the radiation dose delivered to rectal cancers treated preoperatively can improve pathological response at the time of surgery and possibly even obviate the need for surgery but this has been challenging to implement in the clinic due to the limited radiation tolerance of the surrounding normal intestinal loops. Gold nanoparticles that preferentially accumulate in tumors offer the possibility to increase radiation dose within the tumor without damaging adjacent normal tissues. To amplify this radiation dose enhancement, we propose to advance clinical translation of a paradigm using gold nanoparticles that home to the tumor, get internalized by receptor-mediated endocytosis, disperse in the cytoplasm via co-administered pharmacological agents, and can be modeled by mathematical techniques that predict the biological consequences of tumor accumulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Narrative  The purpose of this Phase 1 COBRE proposal is to launch the Center for Molecular Interactions in Cancer (CMIC) at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences in Little Rock, Arkansas. The mission of the CMIC is to study molecular features of biomolecules that drive the functional properties of cancer using structural approaches and quantitative analysis of biomolecular interactions. Our short-term goals for Phase 1 are to foster the creation of a thematic multidisciplinary Center and to leverage a faculty mentoring plan, strategic recruitment and cutting-edge core resources to develop a critical mass of investigators that are able to compete for independent extramural funding in health-related research and support the long-term goal of creating a self- sustaining center.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are one of the most common bacterial infections caused predominantly by uropathogenic Escherichia coli (UPEC). UTIs occur at least once in more than 60% of women with more than 30% of risk for a recurrence within 6 months of initial infection. With the emergence of antimicrobial drug resistance, we are using a mouse model to understand the role of a protein named Mucin 1 (MUC1) in the urinary tract host defense during infection and recovery, in order to develop new antimicrobial-sparing therapies to treat affected patients.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed studies will investigate mechanisms regulating vacuole biogenesis in notochord cells and their role in vertebrate spine formation in zebrafish and mice. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Substance abuse disorders including opioid dependence are characterized by an imbalance between the gen- eration and detoxification of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the brain. In turn, ROS react with cysteine residues and these stress-related modifications often trigger changes in protein structure and function. The research pro- posed here develops and applies an innovative new chemoproteomics approach that will furnish a global portrait S-sulfenated (oxidized) cysteine ligandability in cell-based model of mu opioid receptor (MOR) signaling. The discovery of small molecules that bind to S-sulfenated (oxidized) cysteines in biological targets relevant to MOR signaling should serve as a rich resource for chemical probes and ultimately therapeutics to treat addiction and substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TRanslational Auditory NeuroScience: LAb-based Training for Empowered Self-efficacy in audiology doctoral students (TRANSLATES) aims to increase the representation of audiologists, including those from underrepresented backgrounds, in the clinician-scientist biomedical workforce. This innovative program will provide audiology doctoral students with an accelerated summer research bootcamp, followed by two semesters of immersive research training in NIDCD-funded laboratories that use diverse research methods and models towards a better understanding of listening in complex environments to increase research self-efficacy. By the end of the five-year program, 25 audiologists will be empowered to be clinician-scientists involved in team-based research and advancing the next generation of hearing healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This project is to develop a cost-effective, efficient, and mobile health detection technology for rapid home testing and point-of-care testing of blood creatine and acetylcholinesterase for assessment of heat-related illness and pesticide exposure using minimally-invasive finger-stick blood. Additionally, we will develop a health education app for farmworkers to learn heat and pesticides-related health information. The goal of this research is to overcome/eliminate the issues associated with farmworker health disparity: physical, economic, infrastructural, knowledge, language, and cultural barriers to healthcare resources and health literacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT The specific discriminate collateral immunosuppressive NARRATIVE endothelium is a key regulator of multiorgan dysfunction in response to shock. This study seeks to identify the transcriptional and post-transcriptional mechanisms driving endothelial dysfunction in this context in order to the mechanisms that regulate the required immune response for pathogen clearance from those leading to damage. The findings from these studies will provide the basis for the development of new non- therapies to limit organ dysfunction and increase survival after shock.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social recognition is essential for navigating human relationships, and impairments in this ability contribute significantly to difficulties faced by patients with neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders such as autism spectrum disorder and dementia. This research addresses how cortical processing organizes sensory information that distinguishes individuals, a prerequisite for making behavioral decisions in social groups, and thereby makes a fundamental contribution to our broader understanding of brain mechanisms that enable social behavior. Moreover, this work lays a foundation for intensive investigations of olfactory processing of natural stimuli, with the promise of significantly increasing the biological relevance of our insights and, by extension, the translational relevance of our work for patients with olfactory dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The disease burden for women in the US is higher than that for men across a broad range of conditions, including addiction and depression, certain types of cancers, Alzheimer’s disease, and many others. Significant advances on these challenging problems increasingly relies on interdisciplinary research that invokes a variety of techniques and diverse expertise. To address this challenge, we propose a COBRE center that develops a critical mass of researchers across multiple disciplines, united by the theme of leveraging large data sets for advancing biomedical research that will ultimately increase health equity for women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Aging people with prediabetes are at increased risk for frailty, and skeletal muscle architectural factors (which may improve with exercise or heat therapy) could underlie development of frailty and progression to type 2 diabetes. The proposed study will test local heat therapy as a method to improve skeletal muscle architecture (i.e., cross sectional area, capillarization, mitochondria), glucose tolerance, and frailty indicators in prediabetic older adults. Data generated will provide evidence supporting a directly translatable, easily implemented therapeutic intervention to ameliorate risk of developing overt type 2 diabetes and frailty in at-risk aging individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide and among the leading causes of death in women, and the vast majority of breast cancer deaths result from tumor recurrence at distant sites following treatment. Understanding how tumor cells survive treatment, persist as dormant cells, and eventually reinitiate malignant growth is essential to developing therapies to kill dormant cells and prevent breast cancer recurrence. We have previously studied the regulation and function of the tumor suppressor protein Par-4 in breast cancer recurrence, and in this proposal, we will build on our previous work to elucidate how regulation of cell contractility contributes to Par-4’s function as a tumor suppressor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Organ transplantation as a lifesaving therapy remains constrained by relentless loss of transplanted organs over time and complications associated with lifelong immunosuppression. Our proposal is designed to uncover novel epigenetic mechanisms that can be targeted to promote transplant survival. Our proposed studies will uncover novel insights and open new therapeutic opportunities in transplant tolerance induction as well as in treatment of autoimmune diseases and cancer.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: This proposal will examine non-invasive, in vivo EEG-based measures of neuroplasticity (the brain’s ability to alter its function or structure in response to changes in the environment or novel experiences) in Veterans with schizophrenia (SCZ) or traumatic brain injury (TBI). Despite the vastly different etiologies of these disorders (SCZ is a neurodevelopmental disorder; TBI is acquired), both have impaired cognition which is linked to poor community functioning and integration. Our understanding of the root causes of complex cognitive impairments remains limited. Neuroplasticity is a fundamental brain process that underlies cognitive functioning making it a very attractive area for clinical investigation as it provides a basic mechanistic understanding (at the cellular and neural levels) of what causes cognitive dysfunction in TBI and SCZ. The current application is the start of a systematic research program dedicated to understanding the mechanisms contributing to poor cognition in TBI and SCZ, and examine objective biomarkers of neuroplasticity that can be applied to future interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Understanding the genetic causes of arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death may lead to improved treatment and prevention of these conditions. Our proposal will leverage a unique and massive resource of individuals with high-depth sequencing data and electrocardiograms to discover genetic variation related to cardiac conduction abnormalities. By further examining the function of newly identified genes and linking genetic discoveries to clinical impact and outcomes, we will improve our understanding of individuals at greatest risk for arrythmias and sudden cardiac death before adverse events occur.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed research is to optimize a novel x-ray fluorescence emission tomography system capable of directly imaging metal maps in biological samples and if desired, jointly estimate the metal and attenuation maps. The proposed system will provide the spatial resolution, sensitivity, and tissue penetration depth needed to image gold nanoparticles in small animal models, paving the way to in vivo guiding and monitoring metal-mediated radiation therapy and photothermal ablation cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative IMSD at Texas A&M University: Initiative for Maximizing Student Diversity in Biomedical Sciences This program will increase diversity of doctoral trainees in biomedical sciences at Texas A&M University. Six major biomedical graduate training programs: Medical Sciences, Biomedical Sciences, Genetics, Toxicology, Biochemistry & Biophysics, and Biomedical Engineering are joining with the Office of Graduate and Professional Studies to create a cohesive learning community and a community of scholars to foster recruitment and retention of underrepresented minority populations of trainees. Didactic, research, experiential and career development activities will foster development of the future biomedical professionals who are highly successful in academia, industry, government and other professional settings.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this application is to better understand heart failure among people with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: We propose to study the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying stress susceptibility and resilience. We will examine adaptations in key brain reward neuronal and non-neuronal cells in social stress and the impact on reward behaviors. Our studies will provide new information into the neuronal and non-neuronal cell types in key a reward brain region in social stress, which can impact our understanding of many psychiatric illnesses affecting reward and motivation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Microglial neuroimmune interactions and retrograde trafficking via the retromer complex are critical cellular processes in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) pathobiology and dementia. Previous studies have focused on the effects of retromer risk genes in neurons, but emerging genetic evidence implicates microglia, the brain’s resident macrophages, in the pathogenesis of AD. This proposal aims to characterize the effects of retromer disruption on neuron-microglia crosstalk involved in neurodegeneration using mouse and stem cell-derived models combined with novel proteomics tools to identify endosomal signaling changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Essential tremor (ET) is a chronic and progressive neurological disease affecting 7 million individuals in the US, making it the most common tremor disorder, yet its underlying patho-mechanisms remain enigmatic. The study of human tissue is currently the most direct method to gain a mechanistic insight into the pathogenesis of ET, and in 2003, we established the Essential Tremor Centralized Brain Repository, harvesting 217 ET brains to date, by far the largest collection of ET brains in the world. Through detailed, systematic, controlled postmortem studies, we have made initial steps in identifying postmortem changes in the ET brain, yet in fundamental ways, our studies have only grazed the surface; we have yet to fully map the degenerative pattern seen in the ET brain and have made only initial attempts to dig deeper to begin to uncover the molecular events that are responsible for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance Recognizing the importance for understanding age-associated metabolic changes in Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), we propose to quantify aging- and AD-associated brain and blood metabolic changes through ex vivo and in vivo multimodality MR measurements in mouse models after an AD-promoting stimuli, anesthesia- surgery, with-or-without preventive, protective treatments. This approach recognizes that AD onset, pathogenesis and progression must produce alterations in the overall metabolic status, or metabolomics, of brain and other organs in AD patients, as compared with normal homeostasis in healthy individuals, and our understanding of the urgent need to develop non-invasive AD diagnosis tools. The goal of project is thus to establish translational protocols to guide and interpret multimodality in vivo MR imaging results, based on precise measurements from ex vivo MRS, EM, and immunochemistry studies of the animal models, particularly ex vivo MRS measurements, which are difficult or impossible to conduct in human brain tissues. Success in our project can supply information critical to guiding protocol design and interpretation for in vivo multimodality MR results from human patients, thereby providing a foundation for developing methods of non- invasive detecting and monitoring of age-associated AD metabolomic changes for use in the human AD clinic, an urgently needed capability that to date has remained elusive.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Women Veterans commonly experience urinary incontinence (UI) and may be at increased risk due to exposures during military service. Nonsurgical UI treatments are widely recommended by guidelines as first- line treatment options because of their demonstrated effectiveness and low risk of side effects. Given the identified need to improve access to UI treatments for women Veterans, we will implement a clustered randomized clinical trial of an interactive mobile-health application with and without booster clinical video telehealth visits and utilize practice facilitation as an implementation strategy for primary care practices, while also exploring patient and provider perceptions using a mixed-methodology approach.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Primary Care Understanding of Resources and Screening for Urinary Incontinence to Enhance Treatment (PURSUIT)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An ongoing challenge in the biomedical sciences is to recruit, train, retain and launch the broadest and most diverse scientific talent pool possible. At the University of Utah, we are poised to take advantage of sustained and unprecedented successes recruiting underrepresented students, in the state with the highest recent growth in the life sciences industry. By developing and innovating programs and strategies for inclusion and retention, we aim to mentor and prepare our IMSD@U2 Trainees and Scholars, establishing their careers as outstanding scientists and leaders in the biomedical sciences, while also developing and fostering our own research-intensive environment where underrepresented scientists can flourish.

PROJECT_TITLE: IMSD at the University of Utah (IMSD@U2)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public health relevance. Extensive genomic information now exists for Anopheles mosquitoes, but a significant gap remains in associating the extensive nucleotide variation with relevant disease phenotypes. Across all organisms, the ability to link changes in genotype with disease phenotype is complicated by the fact that variation in protein-coding genes explains only a small proportion of the genetic basis of phenotypes. We will fine-map the portion of the mosquito genome linked to malaria infection and dissect the function of genetic variation present in noncoding and coding sequence that is likely to influence mosquito biology and malaria transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Yuma County, Arizona is an agricultural hub producing more than 90% of the leafy greens consumed in the United States during winter with application of more than 2.6 million kilograms of pesticides per year. My previous quantitative research demonstrated concentrations of neurotoxic metals (e.g., copper [Cu] and manganese [Mn]) consistent with symptom manifestation as reported in the peer-reviewed literature. This study will utilize the Peromyscus eremicus rodent model to elucidate mechanisms of neurotoxicity due to Cu and Mn exposure, individually and combined, using transcriptomic and lipidomic techniques as well as gather samples for a preliminary exposure risk assessment on Cocopah Tribal lands.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We previously demonstrated that subdividing germinal center B cells into three populations reveals distinct epigenetic programs; therefore, we hypothesize that the epigenetic reader BRWD1, which controls B cell lymphopoiesis, is also important for peripheral B cell differentiation. Conditional deletion of Brwd1 in follicular B cells inhibited germinal center initiation, whereas deletion of Brwd1 in germinal center B cells promoted proliferation, prevented differentiation of memory B cells, and collapsed epigenetic differences between germinal center B cell subpopulations. The proposed experiments will determine how BRWD1 controls germinal center B cell differentiation, providing insight into how an epigenetic regulator controls cell fate decisions during the humoral immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Peripheral neuropathy (PN) is a major complication affecting about 50% of the diabetes population with symptoms ranging from pain, numbness, paresthesia and ulceration in the extremities it is also the major cause of non-traumatic amputations. Besides pain management the only option physicians have to slow progression of PN is glycemic control but in type 2 diabetes even good glycemic control is ineffective. Our pre- clinical studies have focused on discovery of an effective treatment and have identified the combination of omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (fish oil) and salsalate as a potential candidate, however; before clinical trials can be initiated we need to have a better understanding of the most effective dose of omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids and salsalate that will increase the omega-3 index to a healthy level and maximize the formation of pro-resolving metabolites in diabetes subjects with PN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project is designed to identify new vulnerabilities for subtypes of advanced prostate cancer that can be exploited to enhance clinical responses and improve outcomes. We will use multiple new models of metastatic prostate cancer that we have developed and characterized to identify specific subtype specific dependencies using pharmacologic and genome-wide loss-of-function screens. Combinations of agents that exploit genomic dependencies will be tested in vivo against a panel of patient derived xenograft (PDX) lines with and without the predicted vulnerability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Changes in DNA methylation and gene expression are hallmarks of acute myeloid leukemia, but mechanisms underlying these changes are poorly understood. We propose to define the genome-wide relationship between DNA hypermethylation and 3D genome architecture using primary AML samples with canonical DNA methylation phenotypes, and to perform detailed mechanistic studies of epigenetic modifications, chromatin interactions, and gene expression at the HOXA locus in primary AML samples and AML cell line models. Together these studies should allow us to better identify genes that are dysregulated by the effects of DNA hypermethylation, and may lead to new approaches for disrupting HOXA-mediated self-renewal in AML cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The Strategies to Innovate Emergency Care Clinical Trials Network (SIREN) will establish a robust and readily accessible infrastructure to conduct clinical trials to identify treatments to advance patient management in the prehospital and emergency department settings. The Data Coordinating Center (DCC) of the Network offers economies of scale that will enable the Network to conduct multiple clinical trials simultaneously and efficiently. This in turn will have an impact on the public health by potentially improving the outcomes of patients with emergency indications related to neurology (e.g. status epilepticus, traumatic brain injury, spinal cord injury), cardiovascular, respiratory, hematology, and trauma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the public health and economic toll of the opioid epidemic rises, the international community needs rigorous evidence on best practices for the clinical management of people with opioid use disorder. Taking advantage of perhaps the world’s most comprehensive population-level database to study opioid use disorders and applying cutting-edge methods for causal inference, our proposal aims to fill the highest-priority gaps in this evidence base. As expanding access to opioid agonist treatment is a key element in the public health response to the opioid crisis, this proposal directly aligns with the national declaration of a public health emergency on opioid overdose, the US’ National Drug Control Strategy, a number of state- level initiatives as well as NIH/NIDA’s HEALing Communities initiative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Squamous cell head and neck cancer (SCHNC) is a dreadful disease with significant physical disfigurement and poor survival rates. In this large prospective study, we will test the hypothesis that oral (fungal) mycobiome influences SCHNC development, potentially related to alcohol and tobacco carcinogen metabolism. Knowledge gained from this study will increase our understanding of the etiology of SCHNC, help to identify high-risk subjects, and may lead to new approaches for prevention of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite the encouraging results, a minority of cancer patients still benefit from immune checkpoint inhibition therapies, with many exhibiting primary or acquired resistance. Tumor cells have been shown to truncate or mutate 3' untranslated regions (3'UTRs) of coding genes, important regions for post-transcriptional control of gene expression, in order to bypass regulatory mechanisms and escape surveillance by the immune system. We will use comprehensive experimental and computational technologies to characterize the effects of 3'UTR mutations and truncations on the tumor immune landscape, across 33 tumor types; enabling a thorough understanding of regulatory mechanisms in cancer, as well as uncovering a novel class of markers for patient stratification or targets for immunotherapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This project will update and expand MIRDcell, a software tool for dosimetry and radiobiology for radiopharmaceutical therapy. The present version MIRDcell v2.1 is powerful, yet has limitations that restrict  its use to education and basic science. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research described in this proposal will investigate the effect of the exercise-induced, liver-derived blood factor Gpld1 on the brain vasculature, as a critical mediator in combating functional drivers of brain aging. This study will delineate cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the rejuvenating effects of systemic Gpld1 on cognitive function in the aged hippocampus. The results from this study will have significant translational potential, positing Gpld1 as a novel therapeutic target to reverse vascular and cognitive impairments in brain aging and age-related neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Prostate cancer is the most common and second most lethal malignancy in U.S. men, and better tools are needed to monitor disease and guide therapy. We propose to combine analysis of liquid biopsies (peripheral blood samples) with quantified evaluation of CT scans to monitor disease over time in a phase 3 multi-center clinical trial for men with metastatic prostate cancer. By integrating these modalities and the data we generate from them in a large prospective cohort, we will develop and validate new minimally invasive signatures of disease response and resistance that predict survival and can be used to monitor and optimize treatment in real time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Narrative Immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) has yielded promising results in patients with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC), but only a subset of patients respond and no predictive biomarker has yet been identified. A replication stress response defect (RSRD) signature has been identified as a potential biomarker that predicts ICB responsiveness in TNBC; the proposed work seeks to understand mechanistically how this biomarker predicts response. The results of the proposed research will help to identify TNBC patients likely to be helped by ICB treatment and to provide effective combination therapies to expand the treatable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PHS Relevance Statement. The determination of three-dimensional protein structures is essential for revealing molecular mechanism of disease processes, and also for structure-based drug design. Concomitantly, technological advances in protein design could revolutionize therapeutic treatment. With these advances, proteins and other molecules can be designed to act on today’s undruggable proteins or tomorrow’s drug-resistant diseases. The proposed computational and experimental studies of protein structures, dynamics, and design methodology will illuminate targets of biochemical and pharmacological significance, and the design of new therapeutics can alleviate mortality, morbidity, and human suffering.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will advance the capabilities of clinical MR scanners to image specific molecular signatures of primary brain tumors. The new features will provide rapid scanning, improved data quality, and automated data analytics for clinical use. This would enable precision oncology in patients with mutant IDH glioma tumors for early diagnosis, treatment planning, and clinical translation of targeted therapies. Hence, this research is relevant to NCI’s mission to advance diagnosis and treatment of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults (≥65 years old) are at the greatest risk of adverse drug events (ADEs) induced by anticoagulants, antidiabetic agents and opioids; these ADEs account for nearly 60% of all ADE-related emergency department visits. High-order drug-drug interactions, i.e. the concurrent use of ≥3 drugs is a major risk factor of these ADEs and is most prevalent among older adults. Knowledge on the safety of the concomitant use of ≥3 drugs is critical for preventing serious ADEs among older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Primary open angle glaucoma (POAG) causes permanent loss of vision and is a condition of public health significance worldwide, affecting millions of people. The etiology of POAG is poorly understood and effective means of primary prevention and curative therapies are not available. In this proposal, our collaborative consortium will complete genetic studies to identify risk factors for POAG and the normal tension subgroup with the ultimate goals of developing effective screening and prevention strategies and novel therapies targeted to the molecular events responsible for the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: The dynamics of cerebral blood flow are important in many clinical scenarios including acute stroke (infarct evolution, hemorrhage), traumatic brain injury, and preterm birth (hypoxic- ischemic injury). Real time maps of cerebral blood flow at the bedside are therefore a long sought after assay for neuro-critical care. This grant will develop speckle contrast optical tomography (SCOT) for imaging of cerebral blood flow dynamics in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many diseases of the nervous system, including neurodegenerative diseases and behavioral disorders, affect males and females differently. Using a genetic model system, these studies will identify molecular and cellular mechanisms by which the sex of an individual influences the development and function of the nervous system. These results will provide a framework for understanding similar processes in humans, which could explain the basis for sex-specific susceptibility or resistance to a variety of disorders of the nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tactile aids help people with low vision or blindness maintain independence, but tactile aids remain limited in what they can display because most tactile aids transmit information in a similar way: by using a mixture of bumps, lines, or textures. The proposed work will deliver several designer materials which can create a variety of new tactile sensations by using phenomena from materials chemistry. By increasing variety and control, these designer materials will improve the quality of tactile aids and make it easier to display mathematical concepts, play complex board games, and reduce the burden of everyday activities for people with low vision or blindness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative High-throughput sequencing can be used to measure many types of biochemical activity along the genome in a huge variety of primary cell types and cell lines (“biosamples”), but it is prohibitively expensive to measure all possible types of activity in all possible biosamples. Accordingly, we have developed a powerful machine learning approach to predict such measurements before they are performed. Here, we propose to increase Avocado's utility by extending the method to work with single-cell data types, to work with 3D genome architecture data, to incorporate information about DNA sequence and to decode regulatory DNA sequence and non-coding genetic variation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to develop a novel screening strategy to detect patients at high-risk for developing pancreatic cancer at least 6 months prior to the development of symptoms. The approach is based on following innovative premises: (i) using urine biomarkers to better enrich the screening population, and thereby, identify the subset of patients in whom more expensive and invasive surveillance strategies are warranted, which should significantly reduce pancreatic cancer mortality and patient care costs; (ii) using urine exosomes rather than total urine for some tests to further concentrate disease specific biomarkers, and (iii) using samples collected before diagnosis in prospective studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adenovirus Is the most common cause of human eye infection; corneal inflammation from the infection can persist and recur for years, even when the infection has resolved and the virus is no longer present. We have identified a chronically altered inflammatory milieu in the post infected cornea, evident by the persistence of infiltrating immune cells and pro-inflammatory proteins. In this application, we will explore the mechanisms of chronic corneal inflammation after adenovirus infection in vivo, with the goal to develop evidence-based treatments to prevent vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE This two site study will assess, in the R61 phase, the dose-dependent effects of the transcranial photobiomodulation (t-PBM) with near-infrared (NIR) light in major depressive disorder (MDD), using the increase in brain blood-oxygenation-level dependent (BOLD) signal as Go/No-go target engagement biomarker. In the R33 phase, we will study repeated administrations of t-PBM versus sham in MDD, to establish the target engagement and evaluate the association between changes in the biomarker and changes in clinical symptoms, while also collecting important information on antidepressant effects, safety and tolerability. This will be a key first step to developing a novel, easy to administer neuromodulation treatment for MDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Glaucoma is a chronic disease that leads to loss of vision following death of a specific cell in your retina, called a "retinal ganglion cell". Our research has identified a signaling pathway that is triggered during glaucoma that causes the death of these cells and we are studying the mechanisms by which this pathway causes death of these cells with the goal of developing novel targeted therapies for patients with glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Molecular chaperones rescue non-native proteins from aggregation and misfolding and are thus central to maintaining a functional proteome in the cell. Protein kinases regulate almost every aspect of cellular function, including cell growth, proliferation, differentiation, metabolism, migration, and death. Both protein families are targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Activities required for daily living usually involve planning and executing long sequences of movements, which are orchestrated through interactions between a large group or cortical and sub-cortical brain structures. Unfortunately, the ability to perform such movement sequences is significantly compromised as a result of neurological disease and/or injury (e.g., Parkinson’s, dystonia, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, etc.). This project aims to understand the neural computations and mechanisms of three key brain regions, including their interactions, which drive movements over long timescales.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The youngest victims of the opioid crisis are infants. Using a 3-trimester opioid exposure paradigm we have developed an animal model of Neonatal Opioid Withdrawal Syndrome (NOWS) that recapitulates robust withdrawal symptoms of relevant withdrawal behaviors in infants. We will use this model to identify underlying cellular and molecular mechanisms that may lead to new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: An improved understanding of different pathways used in metastasis will provide opportunities to slow the spread of high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC), improving patient prognosis and quality of life. In HGSOC, metastasis results from individual cells and aggregates of cells that break free from a tumor site, float through the peritoneum, and reattach in a new site. We hypothesize that single cell and aggregate- based metastasis are distinct processes and will test this hypothesis through analysis of patient samples, computational simulations of single cell and aggregate movement through the peritoneum, and experimental tests in vitro and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity, especially among young children, is a serious danger to the current and future health of America and understanding what personal and environmental factors influence obesity development are crucial to reversing the current obesity epidemic. This study will examine how two understudied factors, sleep-wake patterns and the gut microbiome, affect rapid weight gain in infancy, an early risk factor for obesity. The development of sleep-wake patterns and gut microbe communities will be evaluated, in the context of diverse feeding, maternal, and environmental influences, on infant weight gain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This prospective study will increase our understanding of the social determinants, with an emphasis on TB- and HIV-related stigmas, that influence progression along the TB cascade, from presenting for TB testing (finding the “Missing Cases”) to returning for TB test results (initial loss to follow up), and from retention in TB care to post-treatment TB outcomes in South Africa. Findings from this grant will inform changes to more patient- centered TB screening, treatment, and intervention guidelines in low-middle income countries globally. Results will also inform the development of stigma reduction interventions, as needed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite being a common and serious complication of diabetes, the pathophysiology of diabetic peripheral neuropathy is not well defined. This project will rigorously characterize the epidemiology and risk factors for diabetic peripheral neuropathy in a large cohort of black and white older adults with type 2 diabetes, with a focus on both traditional vascular and neurological risk factors as well as novel biomarkers that may inform pathophysiology and serve as potential targets for interventions in future studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Early human development is a crucial time period in which the structures of primitive streak and extraembryonic mesoderm are formed and errors in cellular differentiation can have dire consequences. This fellowship proposal seeks to advance our fundamental understanding of how human embryonic stem cells decide specific differentiation fates using advanced machine learning methodologies. The findings from this work will help develop future stem cell therapies for treatment of birth defects and miscarriages in early primitive streak and extraembryonic mesoderm formation, ultimately improving public health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE: Transplant-related complications including idiopathic pneumonia syndrome (IPS), graft-vs- host disease (GVHD) and veno-occlusive disease (VOD) of the liver are the major contributors to the development of MODS after allogeneic blood and marrow transplantation (BMT) and continue to limit successful outcomes following this otherwise lifesaving procedure. The development of novel strategies to reduce the incidence and severity of these complications or treat the life-threatening aspects of each once established remains one of the most significant challenges facing our pediatric BMT patients. Experiments proposed in this application will enhance our understanding of how inflammation engendered early after transplant contributes to vascular injury and organ dysfunction with great potential to reduce the risk and severity of MODS and improve outcomes for BMT recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE There is currently no acceptable screening method for ovarian cancer, and most cases are detected when the disease is widespread and likely to be deadly. We will develop a two-step blood-based biomarker followed by a minimally-invasive fallopian tube imaging and sampling technique, as an effective method to detect ovarian cancer at an early time when the disease is most curable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Older adults with type 2 diabetes are at higher risk for severe hypoglycemia and its related complications (including hospitalization and death) when taking insulin. We propose to evaluate, in a randomized clinical trial, a strategy of safe insulin prescribing based on an educational program that uses continuous glucose monitoring to support older adults at high risk for hypoglycemia. If the aims of this project are achieved, this novel care strategy could be widely applied to reduce severe hypoglycemia episodes in older, high-risk adults with type 2 diabetes.
