IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The United States (U.S.) is the country with the largest number of infections and deaths due to COVID- 19 and racial/ethnic minorities are disproportionately affected. Acceptance and uptake of COVID-19 vaccines will be instrumental to ending the pandemic. To this end, 2VIDA! (SARS-CoV-2 Vaccine Intervention Delivery for Adults in Southern California) is a multilevel intervention to address individual, social, and contextual factors related to access to, and acceptance of, the COVID-19 vaccine by implementing and assessing a COVID-19 vaccination protocol among Latinx and African American (AA) adults (>18 years old) in San Diego.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial complex I reactive oxygen species (ROS) production is causally linked to damage in ischemia reperfusion injury, the driving pathology of stroke. Complex I ROS production can also trigger endogenous protective signaling processes, however, and the precise mechanisms governing the physiologic versus the pathologic events are unknown and under studied. We propose to define the mechanisms underlying the apparent duality of ROS by taking unprecedented control of complex I ROS production at a fundamental level to reveal potential mechanisms of damage and recovery in hypoxic pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic rearrangements involving the ETS transcription factor family genes are causally associated with the development of prostate cancer. The overall goal of this proposal is to apply innovative genomics approaches to define the origins of recurrent genomic rearrangements in prostate cancer. Defining the mechanisms associated with the formation of recurrent genomic rearrangements will contribute towards our understanding of prostate cancer etiology and will impact several aspects of clinical disease management ranging from prevention, early diagnosis and therapeutic targeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: There has been a significant increase in incidentally discovered localized renal tumors, and it remains a challenge to reliably and noninvasively differentiate benign tumors from renal cancers or differentiate low grade from high grade renal cancers. In this study, we will apply a powerful imaging technology, hyperpolarized 13C metabolic MRI, to renal tumors for the first time to address an unmet need for noninvasive predictors of tumor aggressiveness. Successful completion of this work will aid in future management of patients with renal tumors by reducing the current overdiagnosis and treatment of indolent tumors while enabling early detection of aggressive renal cancers that require timely surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: The Indiana University School of Medicine is home to the Indiana Alzheimer’s Disease Research Center, the National Cell Repository for Alzheimer’s Disease, the Regenstrief Institute, the Center for Aging Research, the MODEL-AD Center, as well as administering the LEADS trial, which collectively receive >$100M in NIA funding. We propose to restructure the graduate program in Medical Neurosciences and initiate a postdoctoral training program to provide a skilled scientific workforce to these research centers. Importantly, we propose to employ the Medical Neurosciences Training Program to functionally integrate the scientific activities of the NIA supported investigators across IUSM and with Eli Lilly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long-term cancer remission requires generation of tumor-specific immune memory. Memory T cells that reside in primary sites of tumor growth and in sites prone to metastasis such as the lymph node are particularly critical. This application examines requirements for maintaining these tissue-resident memory T cells and their importance in durable anti-tumor responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to develop the first scalable, multi-frequency, phased-array, real-time, quantitative deep tissue optical imager based upon frequency-domain diffuse optical spectroscopy. This breakthrough in functional imaging is enabled by novel advances in hardware and software, ushering in a next generation of diffuse optical spectroscopy and tomography with unprecedented resolution, localization, depth sensitivity, and speed. This work will help meet the rapidly growing demand for more powerful technologies in personalized medicine and wellness. 1

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Mutations in the GBA gene are the biggest genetic risk factor for Lewy body dementia, a neurodegenerative disease that affects at least 1 in 100 people over 65, but it is not clear how those mutations harm brain cells. To find out the answer, we made a GBA mutant fruit fly; we learned that the mutant has an overactive immune system, and that blocking an immune pathway in the brain reduced the buildup of abnormal tangled proteins. We now plan to study how GBA mutations activate the immune system and how the overactive immune system kills brain cells, because the answers may help us prevent many diseases in which brain cells die.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center (OSUCCC) is a matrix cancer center that integrates and leverages all of the resources of the University to achieve its broad vision of creating a cancer free world. The OSUCCC addresses the public health needs of the catchment area (the state of Ohio) through research, education and community outreach and engagement as research conducted within the five OSUCCC Programs focuses on high priority cancers for the OSUCCC including lung, breast, colorectal, prostate, endometrial, cervical cancer, thyroid, and leukemia, as well as tobacco use, obesity and HPV vaccination. Screening and outreach activities are provided to the populations across the lifespan that we serve, especially those with higher burden of being diagnosd with cancer, such as racial/ethnic minorities and other underserved populations (e.g., rural, LGBTQ+, Appalachian) through targeted, culturally appropriate education activities, free cancer screenings, patient navigation, community networking, environmental scans, and addressing policy issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  To generate the scientific discoveries and medical interventions that meet the needs of our citizens, we must harness the inherit research talent present in the United States of America. However, disparities in the population of biomedical Ph.D. scientists indicate that innovative graduate training programs are needed to better recruit and retain researchers from a variety of backgrounds. The UCSC IMSD graduate training program creates an inclusive and interdisciplinary community that develops research and leadership skills across a diverse graduate student population to prepare the next generation of research scientists in the biomedical sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Platelet interactions with fibrinogen, fibrin, and D-dimer (a fragment of fibrin), and/or von Willebrand factor contribute to abnormal clotting in heart attacks, stroke, and COVID-19. Past studies from this grant produced the drug abciximab, which is used to treat patients with heart attacks; tests to monitor the effects of antiplatelet drugs like clopidogrel (Plavix); and a new drug for heart attacks (RUC-4, zalunfiban) that is undergoing human testing. Our new studies are designed to develop a deeper understanding of the receptor that the platelet uses to bind to these proteins, αIIbβ3, using new sophisticated methods, with the goal of developing even better therapies for heart attacks, strokes, and COVID-19.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biomedical research teams that combine diverse perspectives are predicted to generate more creative and innovative research projects for more effective problem solving. The long-term goal of UNC EDGE is to increase the diversity of scientists that enter and are retained in the genomics workforce using strategic recruitment, early exposure to career pathway education and research training, and multi-tiered mentoring. Ultimately, we expect this in-depth training in genomics at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill will give underrepresented professionals the opportunity to become stakeholders in the genomics-related research and healthcare decisions that affect their communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Both too little iron and too much iron lead to many serious diseases in humans including anemia, thalassemia, and hemochromatosis that together affect nearly 1 billion people worldwide. This proposal will investigate signaling proteins that control body iron balance and how genetic mutations found in patients with iron overload affect these proteins and their signaling function. Our ultimate goal is to understand how iron balance is controlled by the body, and to discover new ways to treat iron disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite treatment advances, people with HIV (PWH) often still develop neurologic problems. The HIV Neurobehavioral Research Center will provide scientific leadership and technical support for innovative studies that address the neuropathogenesis, continued persistence, and treatment of neurocognitive impairment in PWH. A new area of emphasis will focus on identifying and characterizing complex neurobehavioral phenotypes (derived from aspects of mood and cognition) and how they relate to CNS mechanisms and HIV disease-related outcomes which will improve our understanding of these conditions in PWH as well as their assessment and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE. Precision oncology has been demonstrably successful for the treatment of certain cancers. However, it has largely been limited to targeting mutant activated oncogenes while overlooking other pervasive mutations such as deletions of tumor suppressor genes. Our laboratory has pioneered an innovative therapeutic strategy, known as collateral lethality, which enables genomic deletions to serve as targets of precision medicine. Under this paradigm, we have developed an inhibitor of the glycolytic enzyme Enolase (ENO2 isoform) for the treatment of poorly prognosed tumors harboring homozygous deletions in ENO1. The goal of this proposal is to broaden the therapeutic reach of collateral lethality through strategic pro-drug modification of our laboratory’s core ENO2-preferred inhibitor so that ENO1-heterozygous deleted cancers, which comprise ~20% of all human cancers, may also be targeted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Virtually all advances in medicine rely on the use of animal models to generate, test and evaluate hypotheses relevant to human biology. Chief among these animal models is the laboratory mouse. In this era of genome- scale, data-driven biomedical research, the Mouse Genome Database (MGD) plays a pivotal role in standardizing, integrating, and disseminating information about the laboratory mouse as a model system for understanding human biology and disease processes. MGD's focus on supporting three distinct user groups -- basic scientists, clinical researchers, and computational biologists -- ensures the broadest possible impact of the resource in contributing to the development of new tools and hypotheses for advancing our understanding of the human genome and how it functions, and for advancing genomic approaches to improving human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE A hallmark of prostate cancer is enhanced androgen receptor (AR) activity. A mechanism by which AR mis- regulation is thought to occur is through acquisition of new binding sites throughout the genome that shift the transcriptional program from differentiation to proliferation. In this proposal, we investigate how mutations in ETS factors, clinically important oncogenic drivers of prostate cancer, promote luminal cell identity and regulate chromatin architecture of cancerous prostate tissues, including by co-option of AR function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is an ocular disease that causes progressive and irreversible vision loss by damaging optic nerve fibers as they exit the eye. High eye pressure is a well-established risk factor for the disease, but it is not the only factor. This project uses one-of-a-kind technology that we have created for monitoring and controlling pressure in conscious animals to examine mechanisms and possible contribution of circadian fluctuations in eye pressure, eye pressure history, and brain pressure to glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE  This project will develop a novel deep learning reconstruction technique for multi-component relaxometry. The proposed reconstruction technique can offer a unique opportunity to explore the acceleration of multi- component relaxation mapping by leveraging the latest deep learning techniques, resulting in an accurate, efficient, and reliable model that is widely generalizable to different relaxation types in many body regions. Successful completion of the project will provide a clinically applicable multi-component relaxometry technique that can help better study, understand and stage diseases such as osteoarthritis and multiple sclerosis from the tissue microstructural and biochemical level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Normal vision is hinged on the ability of photoreceptors to transmit their light excitation to downstream neurons in the visual circuit. Failure of this synaptic communication is a leading cause of congenital forms of night blindness. The work proposed herein will yield a clearer understanding of molecular mechanisms by which photoreceptors communicate with other retina neurons. This is expected to increase our understanding of blinding retina diseases and could offer new strategies for their amelioration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative PD-1 inhibitors are increasingly used for the treatment of solid tumors yet their clinical utility is limited by the development of immune-related adverse events, of which colitis is the most common, severe side effect. The goal of this project is to use a combination of single cell genomic and T cell receptor sequencing in combination with multiplexed immunofluorescence microscopy and organoid culture to characterize the interactions between damaged colonic epithelium and cytotoxic T lymphocytes, which sustain tissue inflammation following PD-1 blockade. These findings are directly relevant to public health because they will increase our understanding of how PD-1 signaling promotes immune tolerance in the gut and will identify new strategies to diagnose, treat, and prevent PD-1 colitis and other gastrointestinal immune-mediated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Borrelia burgdorferi (Bb) is the causative agent of Lyme disease that is transmitted through the bite of tix between small rodents and humans. This proposal is to determine how Bb can establish persistent infection in mice, and thereby act as a reservoir for infections of humans. We will test how antibodies generated during Bb infection might be reduced in their functionality, which could explain why the antibody responses to Bb that is strongly induced cannot clear the infection, and could identify potential future therapeutic targets for Lyme disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Anxiety disorders are highly prevalent during adolescence and associated with an increased severity of symptoms and comorbidities, yet predominant behavioral treatments have limited or no success for nearly half of the adolescent population. The proposed research will use a novel conditioned safety protocol to elucidate the mechanisms by which mice learn to utilize stimuli explicitly predicting safety (i.e., ‘safety signals’) to inhibit fear responding during adolescence. By investigating processes of fear inhibition specifically as they manifest during development, this research will inform the types and timing of behavioral treatments for adolescents that will maximize effectiveness.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because an integrated, co-designed system that is capable of rapidly identifying and responding to medical and social needs will promote better, more equitable patient- and population-level outcomes. While this application focuses on pediatrics, the concepts learned through this grant, will be readily applicable to other populations that are similarly affected by the social and environmental determinants of health and for other healthcare systems planning responses to both medical and social risks. The proposed research is in line with AHRQ’s special emphasis on the social determinants, priority on children, and stated mission as it will “produce evidence to make health care safer, higher quality, more accessible, eq- uitable, and affordable.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Advances in neuroprosthetic devices could soon allow substitution of lost senses, such as sight in blind. However, even with the best sensory prostheses, neural signal generated will be innately different and much degraded from those of biological sensory organs such as the retina. Here we will examine whether the adult brain can undergo appropriate changes to utilize artificially generated neural signal originating from a visual prosthesis analog.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Metabolism influences the epigenetic state of a cell because metabolic intermediates also act as the donor molecules for epigenetic marks such as histone methylation. Here, we will study how metabolic changes in the aging eye affect its epigenome, disrupting the rhythmic cycles of gene expression in the eye that synchronize expression of proteins with the day/night cycle. We propose that disrupting these rhythmic expression cycles in the eye enhances the risk of retinal degeneration, contributing to the increased risk of ocular disease with advanced age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The scientific impact of an NMR experiment depends on the sample quality and biological relevance of the sample conditions, the quality of the NMR data, and the ability to interpret the NMR data. This proposal develops biological NMR technology across all three areas with the overarching goal of advancing NMR studies of biomedically important problems. By reducing the time, cost, effort and learning curve to acquire NMR data and improving the quality and reproducibility of data analysis, we will enable wider application and increase the scientific value of biomolecular NMR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most biologists believe that the mammalian heart has a very limited capacity to regenerate, one that is generally not sufficient to sustain functional recovery after a heart attack. Our recent work challenged this principle and instead argued that heart regeneration is variable trait, like height or eye color, with some individuals capable of meaningful repair and others not. The focus of this project is to identify the genes responsible for why some individuals are better at regenerating their hearts than others, the knowledge of which will help us better understand the mechanisms of heart regeneration and design therapeutics to stimulate the process across all patients.

PHR: Project Narrative Continuous blood pressure (BP) is one of the most critical monitoring parameters during anesthesia, surgery and in intensive care units (ICU). However, the current gold standard technology for BP monitoring, the invasive arterial line (a-line), causes patient suffering (physical pain) and increases the risk of infection, and current noninvasive BP technologies have poor stability. In this project we will develop novel algorithms and hardware with improved stability to meet the clinical need for noninvasive continuous BP monitoring,

PHR: Environmental exposures are associated with a host of human diseases. Reversible methylation of RNA controls gene expression, modulates physiologic processes and it is deregulated in benign and malignant disorders. We will test the concept that oxidative stress, by disrupting intermediary metabolism inhibits RNA demethylases, promotes RNA hypermethylation and perturbs gene expression and cell signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With age humans can accumulate clones of leukocytes in peripheral blood that arise from somatic mutations in bone marrow stem cells: clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP). Mutations in DNMT3A or TET2 account for most CHIP, and associate with a striking 2-4 fold excess in atherosclerotic events, but we have little understanding of the underlying mechanisms. This study will investigate in mice bearing CHIP mutations in myeloid cells mechanistic hypotheses about the causality of interleukin (IL)-6 and IL-1 signaling and sex differences in accelerated atherosclerosis in Tet2 and Dnmt3a hypofunction, building on decades of our group's experience with cytokine biology in atherothrombosis in both basic and clinical investigations, an offers strong translational potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Sudden Unexpected Death in Epilepsy (SUDEP) is defined as the sudden, unexpected, and unexplained death of a person with epilepsy and accounts for between 8 and 17% of all epilepsy-related deaths. Increasing evidence supports breathing cessation as a primary cause of death following a seizure. Using a novel mouse model of SUDEP, we propose to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of breathing cessation during and after seizures, possibly creating new therapeutic avenues for SUDEP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Diet, other health behaviors, and social determinants of health, such as food insecurity, are difficult to change but are critical factors in the development and management of cardiometabolic disease. The proposed research will support Dr. Thorndike’s mentorship and research in developing novel strategies to improve dietary intake and other health behaviors in populations at risk for food insecurity and other social determinants of health. The research leverages Dr. Thorndike’s NIH-funded cohort of over 1,000 community health center patients and an existing Massachusetts General Hospital community health worker program to develop and test a community health worker nutrition intervention to improve dietary intake and blood pressure management in adult patients with hypertension and food insecurity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Protein translation is one of the most complex biological processes and maintaining fidelity during protein translation plays an important role during stress response and environmental adaptation in bacteria. The major goal of this project is to understand at the molecular level how some highly conserved novel accessory proteins are involved in translational fidelity in oral streptococci. This study will broaden our overall understanding on the molecular mechanisms of protein translation in streptococci and related organisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although tremendous advance in the research and clinical practice has been made over the past decade, heart disease is still a major cause of hospitalization and death worldwide. This study will address whether a novel protein post-translational modification is important to maintain heart function and investigate how dysfunction of this protein modification leads to dilated cardiomyopathy. This research will help advance our understanding of this debilitating disease; which could lead to new interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  CAR T-cells have revolutionized the treatment of blood cancers, but 50% of responsive patients eventually relapse and in ~50-70% of patients, this therapy induces devastating side effects (i.e. neurotoxicity (NTX) and cytokine release syndrome (CRS)). By studying the pre-monocytic activation status and cytokine profiles from the monocyte fraction of a patient, this proposal will aim to validate that one can predict CAR T toxicity and efficacy. Through the use of a developed humanized mouse model we will investigate if this pre- inflammatory status is causative of toxicity outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) Formaldehyde is a major environmental toxin and carcinogen whose aberrant exposure is connected to diseases spanning liver and cardiovascular disorders, cancer, diabetes, and neurodegeneration, but at the same time the body continually produces this reactive carbonyl species during normal physiology. We are developing and applying new chemical reagents for selective imaging and proteomics of formaldehyde in living systems to identify its molecular sources and targets, with the long-term goal of understanding how this reactive small molecule contributes both to normal physiology and disease.

PHR: NARRATIVE This project will create a novel serial optical coherence scanner system that can image axonal tracts within the brain at micrometer spatial resolution using unbiased label-free optical contrasts. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: Wheelchair users have a higher risk for obesity and cardiometabolic health-related diseases compared to persons without a disability and remain one of the most sedentary populations in the United States. Engaging wheelchair users in physical activity levels following the current recommendations to achieve cardiometabolic health-related changes requires tailoring and supports in an accessible community environment, but it is unclear if a community-based physical activity intervention that also prioritizes intensity levels is best to improve cardiometabolic health. This project will determine the effects and implementation outcomes of a community-based, intensity-controlled aerobic and strength training intervention on the cardiometabolic health of WU and will significantly advance public health knowledge of how to engage wheelchair users in physical activity to reverse or prevent cardiometabolic health-related disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents experience a confluence of major risk factors for depression, including short sleep duration, late sleep timing, and exposure to stressful life events. This research will use biobehavioral approaches to generate understanding about the linkages between sleep duration and timing, stressful life events, and depressive symptoms in adolescents, with a long-term aim of developing effective preventative interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: We propose to investigate how pancreas cells first start becoming neoplastic and how they progress to malignant cancer cells using a novel model system that we have developed and tested. Our studies will help us understand how pancreatic cancer starts and what signals initiate the process. The outcome from our project will enable future studies to develop more specific and effective treatments for this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS THE STATE UNIV OF NJ NEWARK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because several neurodevelopmental, mental and neurodegenerative disorders, including autism spectrum disorders (ASD), schizophrenia and prodromal Alzheimer’s disease (AD), are associated to difficulties in processing sensory information that could result from an abnormal top-down control of sensory processing. As our goal in this project is to determine the function and mechanisms of top-down modulation of visual processing, it is relevant to the part of NEI mission that pertains to supporting research that advance our knowledge of how visual system functions in both health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the effect of DNA somatic alterations and perturbations is still an open problem in cancer research. This project aims to provide principled machine learning algorithms as a computational approach to achieve this understanding. The proposed aims will result in improved and potentially actionable knowledge/analyses from sequencing data from cancer patients, and an efficient and scalable framework that can be used for experimental design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Sleep disturbances are reported by up to 45% of persons with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer’s disease and contribute to functional limitations, reductions in quality of life, and is a major driver of institutionalization. This project will examine whether Citicoline (a dietary choline supplement) can significantly increase choline levels and decrease inflammatory and potentially AD-associated biomarkers during a prodromal stage of AD (MCI due to AD). Positive outcomes from this project will enable better treatment of persons with MCI due to AD who are experiencing sleep disturbances in order to improve their health and well- being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this study is to determine how often and how much adolescents and young adults with Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) use alcohol and other drugs. Approximately 400 adolescents and young adults with ASD will be assessed four times annually to determine overall rates of alcohol and other drug use, when and if persons with ASD start to use alcohol and other substances as well as if their use increases over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is known that cancer risk increases with age, and that genetic instability and epigenetic alterations (e.g., cytosine methylation) are hallmarks of both aging and cancer; yet the underlying mechanisms involved and to what extent they are associated are not clear. We have found that alternative DNA structures serve as endogenous mutation hotspots in human cancer genomes, and that DNA structure-indcued genetic instability is altered with age in a tissue-specific fashion and by cytosine methylation; thus, we will explore the underlying mechanisms involved to inform on the development of various types of cancer. Results from the proposed study are expected to have a significant positive impact by delineating the relationship between tissue-specific DNA structure-induced genetic instability and epigenetic modification- related non-B DNA formation and instability as a function of age, which will guide the long-term goal of developing new strategies to prevent and/or treat age-associated diseases, such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uveitis involving the posterior segment of the eye accounts for the highest rate of vision impairment and development of ocular complications among patients with uveitis. Current clinical evaluation of intraocular inflammation using slit lamp biomicroscopy and indirect ophthalmoscopy is operator-dependent and semi- quantitative. We will evaluate the use of optical coherence tomography to objectively quantify inflammation in these patients, which can potentially enable better detection and surveillance of uveitis so that prompt treatment can be implemented to prevent blindness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with brain metastasis have limited therapeutic options and very poor prognosis. We have shown that melanoma-secreted amyloid-beta (Aβ) is required for adaptation to the brain parenchyma and that targeting Aβ secretion impairs brain metastasis in xenograft models. We propose to investigate the mechanism and therapeutic effects of Aβ inhibition (alone or in combination with immunotherapy) as a novel strategy against brain metastasis of melanoma and other tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease is a growing public health crisis that has been difficult to study and to develop effective treatments due to a two-to-three-decade-long time between when abnormal proteins can be measured in the brain and the onset of disease symptoms that affect memory and thinking. This study will use a new concept to study Alzheimer’s disease brain changes and symptom progression based on a new statistical technique developed by the study PI that allows estimation of when the disease began utilizing a brain scan called positron emission tomography that measures abnormal buildup of a protein called beta-amyloid. Applying this new concept to data from multiple existing studies (>5,000 people) is expected to provide new information about the things that affect how fast the disease progresses, which will inform when patients with Alzheimer’s disease should be treated to have the greatest therapy benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE STATEMENT    Stress granules and their components have been implicated in various biological processes related to human  health including regulation of infectious, inflammatory, and neurodegenerative diseases. However, there is a  major  gap  in  the  field  regarding  the  intersection  between  innate  immune  response  and  stress  response  in  multiple human diseases, including viral infections. Our proposal will uncover the mechanisms governing the  cross- talk between stress  response and host  innate  immune  pathways that dictate  protective or pathogenic  host response which could be targeted therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project quantitatively and qualitatively investigates and disseminates the mechanisms underlying potential racial/ethnic and sex disparities in substance use disorder treatment services among justice-involved adolescents, a health disparity population prone to suffer harsher consequences from substance misuse. Adopting a team science approach, the project integrates a sociological theory of health disparities, the juvenile justice behavioral health services cascade of care, mediation analysis with longitudinal structural equation modeling, stress instrumentation, and hybrid thematic analysis with cutting-edge technologies. The project will lead to the development and testing of culturally appropriate, sex-responsive, and trauma-informed SUD risk assessment protocols and disparity reduction interventions in the juvenile justice system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Older people with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD) have greater walking impairment and faster functional decline than those without PAD. Yet few therapies have been identified that improve disability in people with PAD. This randomized clinical trial will collect preliminary evidence to determine whether far red light therapy of the lower extremities improves walking impairment in older people with PAD, compared to a sham light device. If our hypotheses are correct, results will be used to design and conduct a large clinical trial of far red light therapy for PAD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE There is no scientific consensus as to whether the antiviral drug, oseltamivir (Tamiflu), the recommended treatment for influenza infection, is associated with neuropsychiatric adverse events (e.g., suicide, psyhocis, seizures etc). This proposal seeks to define the relationship between influenza, oseltamivir, and neuropsychiatric adverse events in children. Results of this research will inform the safety profile of the medication and guide clinical care to optimize outcomes in children with influenza.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Influenza virus is a significant pathogen in lung transplant recipients, but these patients respond poorly to standard-dose (SD) inactivated influenza vaccine (IIV). Studies suggest that two doses of SD-IIV or one dose of high-dose (HD-IIV) is superior to one dose of SD-IIV in solid organ transplant recipients; however, these strategies to improve immunogenicity have neither been extensively tested in lung allograft recipients nor have they been assessed in the early post-transplantation period when allograft recipients are at highest risk of severe influenza disease and complications. This study aims to compare two doses HD-quadrivalent inactivated influenza vaccine (QIV) or two doses SD-QIV in lung allograft recipients ≥16 years of age 1-35 months post-transplant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The major goals of this study are to develop a generalizable method to resolve the exact genome segmental duplication rearrangements underlying large copy number variants (CNVs), to apply the method in a group of affected individuals with the 16p11.2 CNVs and determine the rearrangement diversity across different individuals, to develop high-throughput genotyping assays for future large-cohort association studies in an expand group of affected individuals, and to investigate the functional consequences of rearrangement diversity using neuronal organoid models. The methodological framework established here for studying the 16p11.2 CNVs can be used to study the other large CNVs that are strongly associated with psychiatric disorders such as 22q11, 15q13, and 1q21.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: A proinflammatory protein complex, the inflammasome, has been implicated in promoting choroidal neovascularization (CNV) in neovascular age-related macular degeneration (NV-AMD). Our findings in a mouse model of NV-AMD and in eyes of patients with NV-AMD suggest that the AIM2 inflammasome plays a key role in NV-AMD pathogenesis, which has previously not been examined. We will assess the roles of the AIM2 inflammasome in comparison to the NLRP3 inflammasome for the manifestation and disease progression of NV-AMD pathologies in well-established mouse models of this common eye disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis (MS), an inflammatory disease of the central nervous system (CNS), is on the rise with a 50% increase in prevalence in the last decade. IL-17-producing T cells have a key role in driving destructive CNS tissue inflammation in MS. The proposed studies will advance our knowledge of the mechanisms that influence the ability of IL-17-producing T cells to cause damaging CNS tissue inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Repair of alkylation damage to the genome is critical, because such damage is cytotoxic and potentially mutagenic. The proposed project has the potential to improve public health by elucidating the novel role of His phosphorylation in DNA alkylation damage repair (DAR) pathway and genome stability, which will eventually lead to overcome the challenge to using DNA-alkylating drugs more effectively and designing additional personalized treatments for cancer. The proposed work will utilize laboratory-based science to advance strategies for overcoming resistance to alkylating chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In accordance with the goals of RFA-DK-21-004, the proposed project will examine the antigenic specificity of the anti-islet CD4+ memory T cell compartment in type 1 diabetic individuals. By testing the functional relevance of candidate autoantigens for β-cell destruction in pluripotent stem cell-derived islets, our studies will pave the way toward engineered, transplantable β-cells that can evade autoimmune rejection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The proposed research aims to identify and functionally characterize in situ pancreatic islet neoantigens and neoepitopes formed through protein posttranslational modifications under the conditions pre-type 1 diabetes and type 1 diabetes. The novel functional in situ neoepitopes confirmed from human patients and neoepitope- reactive T cells will provide novel biomarkers for type 1 diabetes and important mechanistic insights into the initiation of type 1 diabetes to guide prevention strategies for at-risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dopaminergic neurons are comprised of diverse subsets, and declines in these critical cells contribute to many mental illnesses and neurological disorders. However, the mechanisms responsible for generating and maintaining dopamine neuron diversity are not well mapped. In this project, we examine how a specific kinase pathway programs the numbers, diversity, and connectivity of dopamine neurons with the long-term goal of preserving these cells to improve outcomes in dopamine-regulated mental illnesses and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human gut microbes primarily feed on carbohydrate substrates derived from diet and host, and produce important metabolites that significantly influence host physiology and health. The functional annotation of the carbohydrate metabolic enzyme repertoire of gut microbes is poorly defined for most bacterial phyla, resulting in gaps in understanding of how microbial communities utilize these carbohydrates to influence human health. Creating new bioinformatics tools for predicting carbohydrate utilization will contribute to the arising microbiome-based personalized nutrition practice and aid in the development of therapeutic options to prevent/treat human metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative Endocannabinoids are lipid signaling molecules within the brain that regulate neurotransmission and synaptic strength. This study seeks to demonstrate that fatty acid binding proteins are synaptic carriers for endocannabinoids at central synapses and regulate retrograde endocannabinoid signaling. The outcome of this study will greatly improve our understanding of endocannabinoid signaling and may lead to novel therapeutic strategies to treat psychiatric and neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narratives  The goal of this proposal is to determine how the increased expression of a small noncoding RNA miR- 182-5p in the front part of human eyes contribute to elevated eye pressure and glaucoma risk. Eye pressure is the major and only treatable risk factor with glaucoma patients in the clinic. The successful completion of this project will help uncover critical information on the specific roles of miR-182-5p and its molecular targets in regulating eye pressure and provide new treatment targets to lower eye pressure more effectively in glaucoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative  Optical imaging instruments have permeated medical practice because of their ease of use, rapid adaptation to clinical needs, portability, real-time feedback, and relatively low cost. We have developed a wearable head- mounted display device that is augmented by visible and near-infrared fluorescence imaging of tissues in real- time. In collaboration with an industry partner, we will optimize the device performance and ergonomics using human factors engineering. Successful completion of the research will accelerate its clinical translation and adoption in both high- and low-resource communities.

PHR: Project Narrative The T32 Program ‘Promoting Academic Workforce Diversity in Translational Behavioral and Cardio- Metabolic Research-PINNACLE’ at the University of Miami will train, mentor, and sustain a network of 12 underrepresented minority post-doctorate mentees committed to developing independent academic careers in translational and behavioral cardiovascular health research. This will have a strong impact in achieving the national mandate (Healthy People 2030) to increase diversity in the academic workforce, thus expanding capacity to implement translational models to improve health quality and equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite growing evidence supporting the effectiveness of medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD), access to these medications is still insufficient, with most patients remaining untreated. Therefore, enhancing knowledge about real-world effectiveness and guiding optimal use of MOU D in the clinical care of patients is of critical importance. The proposed studies, by leveraging electronic medical records from the Veterans Affairs, state-of-the-art data models, machine learning algorithms and causal inference methods, provide a timely and unique opportunity to close these knowledge gaps and answer a set of timely questions centering around OUD care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Graft versus host disease (GVHD) is a serious complication of allogeneic bone marrow transplantation affecting many organs including the eyes causing ocular surface damage, conjunctival and lacrimal fibrosis and severe dry eye. The current proposal will investigate the role of host and donor origin macrophages and their interaction with fibroblasts and goblet cells in the pathogenesis of ocular GVHD. These studies can potentially lead to new therapies that target macrophages to treat or prevent GVHD-associated conjunctival and lacrimal gland fibrosis and dry eye.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancers of the gastrointestinal and gynecologic tracts (GI/GYN) cause of US cancer deaths. The goal of this proposal is to improve QOL in patients with advanced GI/GYN cancers, decrease patient and family caregiver distress, and reduce health care use by improving symptom management and skills training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Helicases are essential enzymes that unwind the strands of DNA and RNA. They are critical to maintaining the genomes of all organisms, and defective helicase function is implicated in various human disorders. The project will use advanced biophysical techniques to understand the mechanisms of helicases involved in repairing DNA damage, specifically investigating how helicase interactions with DNA and with accessory proteins regulate their functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lynch syndrome (LS) affects over a million of people in the United States and is one of the leading causes of hereditary cancers (e.g., colorectal and endometrial cancer), which can be prevented or treated with active screening and early diagnosis. Cascade testing for at-risk relatives of patients with LS is cost-effective, but underutilized because there are many barriers to testing. Increasing pre-test genetic counseling in this population will have substantial public health impact by promoting awareness and identification of LS and subsequently help reduce cancer morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Mitochondrial metabolism plays an important but poorly understood role in the development of obesity related liver disease. Anaplerosis and cataplerosis are non-oxidative mitochondrial pathways that link biosynthetic and catabolic capacity to cellular energy metabolism, redox state and antioxidant function. This project investigates how anaplerosis impacts mitochondrial metabolism and impinges on liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative Trypanosomatid parasites cause devastating human diseases that affect millions of people worldwide. Drugs to treat these diseases are limited and parasite resistance to these drugs is on the rise. As our data on Trypanosoma brucei indicate, the cyclin-dependent kinase CRK9 forms a unique tripartite protein complex and has essential roles in the trypanosome-specific mode of gene expression and the completion of the cell cycle. Thus, analysis of the CRK9 enzyme architecture and of CRK9-controlled substrates, signaling pathways and mechanisms may unravel new chemotherapeutic intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Basement membranes (BMs) are non-cellular protein layers that separate tissues forming cell-attachment sites and barriers between tissue compartments. The inner limiting membrane (ILM) is a special BM that prevents movement into the retina from the vitreous, as such it is a formidable barrier to cell- and gene-based therapies. The goal of this project is to manipulate the molecular structure of the ILM to promote integration of neural stem cells or viral transfection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on genetic and epigenetic factors that underlie the etiology of Ph-like acute lymphoblastic leukemia where there exists a cancer health disparity within the Hispanic/Latino population regarding incidence, prevalence, and mortality. Further understanding of these factors lays the groundwork for predictive diagnostics and personalized preventative medicine. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission to foster discoveries pertaining to the causes, diagnosis, and prevention human diseases and improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Because dysfunction of inflammatory and anti-inflammatory T cells has been associated with multiple sclerosis (MS) and its animal model, experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), control of T cell development and function is of major clinical interest. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a class of short non-coding RNAs critical in controlling gene expression. Most recently, we found a major role for microRNA-92a (miR-92a) in the regulation of pathogenic and regulatory T cells in EAE and MS. Findings from this proposal will advance our understanding of miR-92a in T cell function, and provide an incisive picture of molecular networks that could underlie new therapeutic avenues to treat disease, including miR-92a inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will determine in a seamless phase II/III design whether older and/or medically infirm patients with hematological malignancies will see an improvement in their quality of life following allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation when treated with one of three novel peri-transplant interventions: supportive and palliative care, clinical management targeting specific comorbidities, and both interventions combined. Overall survival, non-relapse mortality, other patient-reported outcomes, and use of resources will also be compared between the intervention arms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Parasitic worms, allergens, and some protists all trigger a “type 2” immune response, but we do not yet fully understand the underlying mechanisms of immune sensing and regulation. More than 1 billion individuals are currently infected with worms, and the incidence of allergies is rising worldwide. By studying the role of epithelial tuft cells in type 2 immunity, we hope to discover novel targets for therapeutic intervention in helminth infection and allergy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Legionella pneumophila (Lp) is the agent of a severe form of pneumonia known as Legionnaires' disease and an intracellular parasite of macrophages and epithelia when it is introduced in the lungs. We have gained first- time evidence that Lp secretes multiple mucinase activities, with one of them (ChiA) being a multifunctional chitinase that degrades both gel-forming mucins from the lungs and a component of the human complement system. Mucinases are an emerging part of understanding Lp and pneumonia pathogenesis and potential targets for addressing disease, and therefore, the proposed studies are aimed at determining how Lp mucinases promote infection and in different ways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) causes Kaposi’s Sarcoma and B cell lymphomas. KSHV expresses 12 miRNA genes and a number of viral long noncoding RNAs, including anti-sense and circular RNAs. Using ribonomcs techniques we demonstrated that KSHV infection leads to de-regulation of cellular lncRNAs in a miRNA-dependent and -independent fashion. The main focus of this project is to increase our understanding of how viral short and long noncoding RNAs contribute to viral disease, and specifically to tumor formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Melanin is a very important pigment in the biosphere and is involved in numerous biological processes from protection against sunlight to energy harvest. Melanin is made by many pathogenic organisms, including several pathogenic fungi. It contributes to fungal virulence by undermining host defense mechanisms and increasing fungal resistance to certain antifungal drugs. This proposal will take a multidisciplinary approach to the problem of melanogenesis in the fungal pathogen Cryptococcus neoformans by seeking to understand how melanin is made, with the goal of discovering new science that can lead us to novel therapies that target melanization pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative The Epstein Barr virus (EBV) is a primary causative agent in HIV-associated lymphomas. Based on preliminary studies in tissue culture and clinical models, we hypothesize that two large EBV miRNA clusters are critical players in eliciting the tumor phenotype through altering the immune cell microenvironment via their canonical functions and cell growth and/or protection against cell death through a previously unknown non-canonical mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kaposi Sarcoma (KS) is a cancer caused by Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) and is very common in individuals with HIV/AIDS. Weakening of the immune system is thought to play a role in allowing KSHV infection to occur and KS to develop. We propose to use common marmoset monkeys to demonstrate that the removal of immune cells allows KSHV infection and KS development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The transforming human gammaherpesviruses EBV and KSHV establish stable latent infections in B cells, providing a lifelong reservoir of virus that can contribute to the development of malignant disease. Thus, defining the mechanisms that govern long-term latency and tumorigenesis is critical for designing rational strategies to prevent disease. In work here, we will use a mouse model of gammaherpesvirus infection and tumorigenesis to defined the mechanisms by which viral noncoding RNAs shape critical B cell signaling pathways to promote virus dissemination, latency and tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plant nectar-feeding is essential for survival and reproduction for many mosquito species, and mosquitoes locate sugar sources by using their sensitive olfactory system. Trap-and-kill systems that exploit the nectar-feeding behaviors have shown to be an effective control intervention, but we don't know which odorants in the plant scent that mosquitoes find attractive, or how they process this information in their olfactory system. Using Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, we will characterize the genes involved in the odorant reception of nectar source odors and determine the mechanisms by which this olfactory input is processed in the brain, thereby providing new attractant lures and tools for mosquito control.

PHR: CORE D NARRATIVE The purpose of Core D (Clinical Sample and Tumorigenesis core) is to provide essential services for Projects 1, 2 and 3 that include clinical sample acquisition and storage (Aim 1), histological processing and diagnostics (Aim 2), and in vivo experimentation using humanized mouse, xenograft mouse, and murine virus tumorigenesis systems (Aim 3). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Much like armor, Gram-negative bacteria (e.g., Escherichia coli) have a unique outer surface that prevents the use of many antibiotics making infections caused by these organisms extremely difficult to treat. This proposal will help determine the molecular machinery used by Gram negatives to assemble their outer surface providing new opportunities for the development of novel therapies to fight multi-drug resistant bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dengue virus serotypes 1-4 cause disease of major importance worldwide, but there are no effective vaccines or therapies that can be safely administered to all populations at risk of infection. Primary DENV infections, as well as the only licensed vaccine, can elicit antibodies in unexposed individuals that can enhance subsequent DENV infection with a different serotype; however, following a secondary DENV infection, immunity typically broadens and the risk of severe disease is decreased, indicating that serotype cross-protective immune responses can indeed be generated. In this study, we will use cutting-edge serological and genomic sequencing technologies coupled with unique longitudinal sample sets from our long-standing cohort study in Nicaragua to investigate how secondary cross-protective antibodies and B cells are induced and maintained over time in order to guide improved strategies for vaccine design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: According to the National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders (NIDCD), millions of people in the United States have a communication or related disorder. Thirty million people 12 years of age or older have hearing loss in both ears, 6–8 million people have some form of a language impairment, and 7.5 million people have a voice difficulty. The Lessons for Success program aims to increase the generation of research in Communication Sciences and Disorders by providing educational support and guidance to 150 of the most promising early-career scientists, which will lead to improvements in the communication health of millions people with communication or related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The opioid crisis has inflicted a tremendous socioeconomic burden and resulted in the countless loss of lives. In order to further initiatives geared towards resolving the opioid crisis with novel treatments, basic neurophysiological mechanisms that underlie pathological opioid behaviors need to be elucidated. The goal of this proposal is use combinatorial genetic, photometric, electrophysiological, and machine-learning based behavioral analysis to decode the behavioral and neural correlates of the heterogeneous mesolimbic dopamine system that regulate morphine response and associative learning in non-dependent and morphine-dependent mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults are the fastest growing segment of the population. While vision loss is common in this age group, information on the true prevalence of vision impairment (distance visual acuity impairment and contrast sensitivity deficits) and the impacts that these impairments have on daily function and quality of life is limited. The goal of this project is to determine how common these impairments are in women aged 80+ and the impact that they have on physical and mental well-being.

The JHM Hub-and-Spoke network over 25 clinical sites in five states and Washington, DC, associated with 9 institutional partners with committed EMS systems. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: In mammals, the motor cortex plays a key role in the control of voluntary movements, but how neural activity in the motor cortex is related to movement remains poorly understood. In this project, we leverage powerful experimental methods or recording and perturbing neural activity across multiregional circuits in the brain to determine how neural activity is transformed at each processing stage between the motor cortex and the musculature. A synthesis of these data and computational modeling results will allow us to evaluate the validity of a leading model of movement control by the motor cortex to help us link neural activity to behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell-based therapy revolutionized our approaches to cancer treatment. Current limitation of this transformative therapy is a poor efficacy against solid tumors because CAR T cells rapidly lose their viability and activity inside these tumors. Studies proposed here will characterize key regulatory mechanisms responsible for death and inactivation of the intratumoral CAR T and identify novel means to target these mechanisms to disrupt the immune suppressive tumor microenvironment and to increase the efficacy of anti-cancer CAR T immunotherapies against solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to early-life adversity is a significant source of risk for poor developmental outcomes in young children, and is unequally distributed across groups, with minoritized people experiencing the greatest levels of adversity leading to gaps in mental and physical health. This proposal will test if Promoting First Relationships (PFR), an evidence-based 10-week home visiting program, delivered within a primary care setting, will operate as a protective factor against cellular aging in young children as measured by telomere length and epigenetic aging clocks. We will also evaluate the effectiveness of PFR with two additional sessions of PFR in Primary Care to enhance sensitive caregiving and parenting for low-income families in the context of primary care.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autistic adolescents have deficits in age-appropriate daily living skills (e.g., hygiene, laundry, cooking, cleaning, managing money) that impact their ability to successfully transition from high school to the adult world and achieve positive outcomes in employment, college, independent living, and quality of life. Our team iteratively developed the first evidence based DLS intervention for autistic adolescents without ID, Surviving and Thriving in the Real World (STRW), which recently demonstrated statistically significant and clinically meaningful gains in daily living skills for adolescents with autism compared to a social skills control group. The current proposal seeks to conduct a fully powered, multi-site randomized clinical trial to assess the efficacy of the STRW-telehealth (STRW-T) intervention to increase the acquisition of age-appropriate daily living skills and examine the impact of improved daily living skills on early adult outcomes after high school graduation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL COMPONENT  Center of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) in Nutrition and Women’s Health Inadequate or imbalanced nutrition is one of the most interwoven, unifying themes underlying poor health among women across the lifespan. This COBRE will support research leading to evidence-based practices to improve women’s health through better nutrition. This research addresses the roles of gender in health and disease; promotes participation of women in clinical nutrition research; and integrates sex as a biological variable in basic, preclinical, and translational nutrition research.

PHR: NARRATIVE Otitis alternative disease. research by to are media or inflammation of the middle ear is a significant cause of morbidity in t he US and worldwide, and prevention, diagnostic and treatment strategies are urgently needed to alleviate the burden of this Strengthening the collaborative network among otitis media investigators will l ead to cross-disciplinary and training of the next generation of researchers, with a strong representation of different backgrounds gender, ethnicity, specialty, technical skills, and leadership experiences. Our program of activities is designed support and advance careers in otitis media research, particularly for early-stage investigators and those who from under-represented minority groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Migraine, a chronic intermittent headache disorder, ranks in the top five causes for years lived with disability. Some basic science research and one study in humans suggest that cocoa extract supplements may be effective for migraine prevention. The goal of this application is to perform a pilot study of a cocoa extract supplement for episodic migraine to help inform the design of a future, full-scale efficacy trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative . It is well appreciated that vascular complications associated with lifestyle-related diseases, such as diabetes, contribute to an increased risk of hypertension, coronary artery disease, and heart failure associated with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). Yet, mechanisms, especially those underlying vascular smooth muscle dysfunction, are poorly understood. This proposal addresses these fundamental knowledge gaps and fulfills relevant public health goals and NIH missions by generating fundamental basic knowledge that could help identify and develop novel treatment strategies to address vascular complications associated with diabetes and HFpEF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed IMSD program at Dartmouth College will strengthen current doctoral training in biomedical sciences through enhanced scientific, personal, professional, and leadership development. Trainees will be supported by multi-tiered team mentorship and cohort building to create a thriving, intellectual community for PhD students from historically underrepresented groups. Pre-matriculation and ongoing programming throughout doctoral training will support trainees to become leaders in the biomedical research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the many improvements in health and the increase in life expectancy over the last 50 years, there persist significant health disparities among Alaska Native (AN) people including the highest incidence of colon cancer reported globally; the highest incidence of gastric cancer in the U.S.; persistently high rates of tobacco use; the highest regional rates of RSV in observed in the U.S.; high rates of early childhood dental caries; rural communities without piped water and sanitation; high rates of suicide; high rates of unintentional injury; and high rates of chronic liver disease and related mortality, all of which need to be addressed. However, it is also essential to acknowledge that the Alaska Native people possess tremendous strengths; despite the negative impact of colonization, boarding schools, and other adverse social determinants of health, the sense of community, respect for elders, and the traditions and cultures of the many Alaska Native Tribes are strong. The Alaska Native Center for Health Research will address these disparities while incorporating Alaska Native peoples’ world views and focusing on resilience and positive elements across and within Alaska Native communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Dysregulation of molecular clock function in the placenta is a novel mechanism causing poor pregnancy outcomes, leading to lifelong health consequences for the newborn. This transdisciplinary project proposes a new, high impact virtual consortium that will advance fundamental knowledge into chemically-induced dysregulation of the molecular clock in the placenta. This work will transform our understanding of pregnancy disorders stemming from environmental exposures and set the basis for targeting preventive approaches related to the molecular clock.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current SARS-CoV-2 vaccines require frequent boosting due to limited potency, durability, and breadth of neutralizing antibody responses and limited development of antigen-specific T cell responses. In the proposed clinical trial, we will test a novel immunotargeting vaccine approach to improve both B- and T- cell responses against SARS-CoV-2. Our strategy that has broad applicability for the development of vaccines for the prevention of infection and disease. More effective vaccine technology would have tremendous long term public health impact, with both individual and population-level benefits, including requiring less frequent or fewer vaccine doses, decreasing infection-related complications and transmission, and decreasing the economic and health systems burdens of pandemic infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL We propose establishing the Center for Cardiovascular Research in Biomechanics (CRiB), which will support research aimed at the development of novel biomedical materials and devices to treat cardiovascular diseases. Our CRiB Center encompasses a robust mentoring program for junior investigators, a unique Tissue Analysis Core, and three research projects focused on the effects of sex on vascular elastogenesis and the development of novel materials and devices for Peripheral Artery Disease surgical treatment and post-treatment recovery using elastomeric bypass grafts and ischemic wound dressings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity has become increasingly prevalent in the United States, and this epidemic is a global health problem. The storage capacity of adipose tissue is an important link between excessive adiposity and the pathogenesis of numerous metabolic diseases, including the Metabolic Syndrome, Type 2 diabetes mellitus, and cardiovascular disease. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide new insights into mechanisms that regulate human adipose tissue expansion, distribution, and function, which can greatly influence whole body health and metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trichomonas vaginalis, the most common non-viral sexually transmitted infection worldwide, disproportionately affects African Americans and is associated with increased risk of HIV acquisition, adverse birth outcomes, infertility, and other adverse reproductive morbidities. Metronidazole is used for the treatment of trichomoniasis, but in up 10% of cases, T. vaginalis isolates are resistant. Results from the proposed studies will provide new knowledge about metronidazole resistance in T. vaginalis that will inform development of future assays for rapid metronidazole-resistance detection as well as novel drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The autoimmune disease systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) offers an unexpected new approach to treating glioblastoma multiforme (GBM), the most lethal and difficult to treat primary malignancy of the brain. Deoxymab- 1 (DX1) is a nuclear-penetrating lupus anti-DNA autoantibody that localizes to tumors, inhibits DNA repair, selectively kills DNA repair-deficient cancer cells and tumors, and in a pilot study was found to cross the blood- brain barrier (BBB) and have single agent activity against GBM in a patient-derived xenograft (PDX) mouse model. We believe DX1 has potential to be translated into a novel therapy for GBM, and propose to: 1) elucidate and enhance the mechanism of BBB penetration by DX1 in GBM, 2) use DX1 to exploit the vulnerability of GBM to DNA damage, and 3) develop DX1 as a drug delivery ligand for targeting GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Voltage-gated ion channels (VGICs) are responsible for electrical impulses in cells of the brain, heart and other tissues. We will use innovative electron cryo-microscopy techniques to obtain near-atomic-resolution structures of two VGICs in their resting and active states. This will provide an unprecedented view of the mechanism by which they control the electrical currents of ions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Diabetes occurs in over 10% of the U.S. population, but little is known about the regulation of the mechanisms that develop within the fetus that promote insulin action after birth. This research proposal puts forth a highly innovative and novel concept and paradigm shift that a defect in skeletal muscle vascular development and function originating in the fetus precedes the onset of insulin resistance after birth in the offspring. A very new concept is also proposed that estrogen in utero has an essential role in developing the microvessel network in fetal skeletal muscle required for promoting insulin action and glucose homeostasis in offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Spinal cord injury (SCI) affects 1.3 million Americans. The proposed experiments in this application are relevant to public health because they will elucidate mechanisms for how neuronal activation promotes axon growth, thus identifying potential therapeutic targets. Additionally, they will test whether neuronal activation – alone or in combination with other manipulations – promotes functional axon regeneration after SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative Brains have evolved to process and store information from the outside world and do so through synaptic connections among interconnected networks of neurons. Our work will illuminate higher-order genome folding as an unexplored dimension of the long-range epigenetic control governing neuronal activation in the mammalian brain. Synaptic defects underlie many neurological disorders, therefore understanding the molecular mechanisms governing activity-dependent expression is of tremendous importance toward our knowledge of how neural circuits are disrupted in brain disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial and ethnic diversity in cancer genetics and genomics research is limited, despite the observation of differences in genomic contributions to cancer health disparities in certain racial and ethnic groups. This lack of diverse genomic data limits the ability to implement genetic risk assessment and management in minority groups and can lead to genetic misdiagnoses in all populations (including non-minority groups). The proposed research will contribute diverse genomic data for prostate cancer, for which African genomic information is limited.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Mechanosensitivity is a fundamental physiological capacity which allows us to interact with the environment through the perception of mechanical force, but molecular and cellular mechanisms that contribute to the modulation of mechanotransduction and mechanosensitivity under normal, pathological or adaptive conditions remain to be fully elucidated. The objective of this proposal is to elucidate how mechanical force is perceived at the molecular level in rapidly-adapting mechanoreceptors. Insights gleaned from these studies will facilitate the development of pharmacological strategies to treat a range of neurological disorders associated with altered mechanosensitivity in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This work aims to elucidate structure and chemical reaction mechanisms of metalloenzymes using quantum chemistry methods to model x-ray absorption, x-ray emission, and optical spectroscopies. Understanding the intermediates involved in these reaction mechanisms is directly relevant to ATP synthesis, melanin produc- tion, and to understanding infantile genetic disorders such as ethylmalonic encephalopathy. The methods for computational x-ray spectroscopy that come from this work can be used in the study of metal metabolomics, e.g. alongside experimental x-ray analyses of human brain tissue in the study of Alzheimer's disease, which is known to present with increased metal dyshomeostasis in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic variation in humans contributes to disease processes in both simple (one sequence leads to disease) and complex (multiple sequence variants lead to disease) ways. In this project, we will develop a toolkit of proteomics and computational methods to interrogate protein sequence variants found in the neurogenerative diseases: Ataxia Oculomotor Apraxia 2 (AOA2), Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis 4 (ALS4), and PontoCerebellar Hypoplasia (PCH). The development of these approaches will allow us to speed up the characterization of protein sequence variants found in patients with rare disorders with a goal of rapid identification of potential therapeutic avenues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The four serotypes of DENV are significant causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide, as half of the world’s population is at risk of DENV infection. The recently licensed DENV vaccine is not approved for use in people who are younger than 9 years old and are naïve with respect to prior DENV exposure. At present, a DENV vaccine that protects infants and young children, who represent highly vulnerable populations for manifesting severe dengue disease, and naïve individuals of all ages is a global health priority. This project will advance our understanding of the mechanisms regulating protective vs pathological Ab responses to DENV, and in so doing, contribute to the development of safe and effective DENV vaccines.
