IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The lack of an efficient therapeutic strategy against flavivirus virus infection has raised a global health concern. This proposal will lead to an in-depth understanding of the mechanisms by which the NS5 proteins from two members of flavivirus family, Zika virus (ZIKV) and dengue virus (DENV), suppress human STAT2 protein and related host interferon responses. Ultimately, this study will help the development of a novel therapeutic strategy against flavivirus infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many human diseases including genetic disorders and cancers are caused by mutations in transcription factors or their dysregulation. The overall goal of this project is to determine the mechanism of transcription by eukaryotic RNA polymerase I (Pol I) and how it is dysregulated in disease. This work will provide fundamental knowledge about the basic molecular mechanism of Pol I transcription and discover key steps that may be targeted in cancer and developmental disorders to enhance health and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative The contributions of repressive cis-regulatory elements (silencers and enhancer blockers) to regulatory control and the results of their misregulation in cancer have been understudied relative to these elements’ predicted abundance in the human genome, in large part due to the lack of a high-throughput reporter assay designed specifically to address the limitations inherent to identifying them. Previously, enhancer assays have been used for repressive element detection but suffer from high false positive and false negative rates and low replicability, limiting their ability to detect negative regulatory elements (NREs). The goal of this project is to develop a high- throughput reporter assay which overcomes these limitations, allowing efficient and robust identification and characterization of novel NREs and expanding our understanding of the role that NREs play in gene regulation across many cancer cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adverse morbidity Streptococcus inflammation  pregnancy outcomes, including premature birth and stillbirth, are the leading causes of neonatal and mortality. A frequent cause is Intrauterine infection, which occurs when bacteria like Group B (GBS) ascend from the vagina into the uterus and invade the amniotic cavity, leading to and tissue damage. As maternal GBS colonization of the female genital tract (FGT) represents the major risk factor for adverse pregnancy outcomes my research seeks to elucidate the molecular mechanisms that govern the dynamic aspects of GBS vaginal carriage and ascension to the FGT.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: NARRATIVE Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a devastating lung disease of older veterans marked by progressive respiratory failure for which there remains a significant unmet need for effective medical therapies. Lung epithelial cell dysfunction has emerged as an important causal contributor to the development of fibrotic lung scarring. In order to improve our understanding of IPF, we generated two novel mouse models expressing IPF-associated mutations in the lung epithelial cell restricted Surfactant Protein C gene (SFTPC). Using this preclinical platform we will characterize the mechanisms underlying lung epithelial dysfunction found in SFTPC mice including abnormal cellular quality control responses (e.g. endoplasmic reticulum stress, autophagy, mitophagy) and metabolic reprogramming. Results funded by this project will permit rapid identification of new cell populations, signaling pathways, and molecular targets thus accelerating the discovery of new IPF treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In a series of genetic studies, we have identified and validated SVEP1 as a novel extracellular matrix protein that promotes atherosclerosis in humans and mice. The mechanisms underlying the role of SVEP1 in the pathophysiology of atherosclerotic disease, however, remain unknown. In this proposal we will assess the cellular and molecular impact of SVEP1 in the development of atherosclerosis and determine which of its protein interactions are required for its effects, thereby expanding our understanding of how this protein influences disease and evaluating the therapeutic potential of targeting SVEP1 as a treatment for coronary artery disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Postmenopausal women, who have very low levels of circulating estrogens, are at high risk of life-threatening, obesity-related disorders such as metabolic syndrome. Many studies have shown that estrogen is the factor that protects women from metabolic risk. This project will investigate new directions in estrogen and circadian biology research in mouse models and therapeutic feeding behaviors for at-risk postmenopausal women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Dermis is a complex connective tissue that provides protective, regulatory, and sensory support to the epidermis. This project will significantly advance our understanding of the pathological and physiological roles of the PDGFRβ signaling in the dermis. This information will be significant to human health because it will open the way to precisely modulate PDGF signaling as a treatment strategy for skin disease and regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Successful completion of the proposed aims will provide a systematic, experimentally validated understanding of how laryngeal and vocal tract adjustments affect voice production and vocal fold contact pressure, and a better understanding of the scientific rationale for voice therapy in treating patients with phonotraumatic vocal hyperfunction. PHR: Narrative  In the last several years, a number of genes for familial lipodystrophies have been discovered but the molecular basis of many patients remains unknown. The second aim is to study relationship of the molecular defects with clinical characteristics and metabolic derangements in patients with lipodystrophies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study is relevant to profound disparities in COVID-19 and other health conditions and lower coverage for all recommended adult vaccinations, including the COVID-19 vaccine among Latinos communities. This proposal will test the efficacy of a combination intervention REDES (“Networks”) - a social network and mobile health (mHealth) enhanced community health worker (CHW) intervention - to address COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy and uptake among a cohort of Latinos and their networks in Maryland. The proposed study will be the first to rigorously test a peer network and mHealth vaccine intervention integrated into state-of-the-art CHW-led community care for Latinos.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disparities in substance use and high rates of suicide pose significant risk to American Indian youth. Strategies for early prevention are needed, but evidence on what is effective for this population is lacking. This study will test the effectiveness of a substance use prevention program tailored for American Indian youth and families that also holds promise for impacting suicide risk, providing an opportunity for efficient intervention in communities with limited resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While DNA mutations have been sequenced in many different tumor types, the mutational profile of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors is unique, with frequent alterations in DAXX and ATRX. As we currently do not yet understand how these mutations lead to disease, we will use physiologically relevant models (both mouse and human) to understand the normal functions of these genes and then evaluate what happens when they are lost or mutated. Combined these studies will advance our understanding how pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors develop, thereby providing the foundations for the development of new therapeutic approaches to treat these cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  Opioid use disorders (OUD) are a continuing public health emergency. Public sexually transmitted disease (STD) clinics are high-volume medical settings that serve a high-risk patient population, with high prevalence of untreated OUD.  This study will examine the effectiveness of OUD treatment linkage strategies for opioid-dependent patients seeking care at walk-in STD clinics, comparing Usual Care (UC), referral via Patient Navigation (PN), and Patient Navigation + Buprenorphine Initiation (PN+BUP) in a parallel 3-arm randomized clinical trial. The study could have high impact, spurring novel integration of OUD treatment linkage services within the STD care sector.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ceramides are fat metabolites that accumulate in individuals susceptible to diabetes and heart disease. Herein we will investigate how a molecular downstream effector of ceramides, Fgf13, mediate its effect in the progression of disease pathology in adipocytes. The work could uncover new therapeutic approaches for metabolic diseases such as diabetes, cardiovascular and heart diseases associated with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This research will define how the basic module for information transfer in the brain – the synaptic active zone – forms and matures during development. Given that maturation and plasticity of synapses is a fundamental feature of neuronal signaling and circuit remodeling, it is critical to define molecular mechanisms that control this process. Identification of pathways mediating active zone development and maturation will allow analysis of their role in presynaptic plasticity, as well as how disruptions in these components contribute to brain diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement Proper neural connections are essential for normal nervous system function. Abnormalities in neural connectivity are associated with a multitude of neurodevelopmental and mental health disorders, including autism and schizophrenia. Determining the mechanisms by which cytoskeletal elements inside the growth cone are coordinated to drive the morphological responses of the growth cone (advance, retraction, and turning) may eventually lead to understanding the basis of neuropsychiatric disorders and may contribute to designing prevention and/or treatment strategies in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Early detection of Alzheimer’s dementia is critical to obtaining treatment, counseling, and planning for the future. Bilingualism is known to impact the interpretation of cognitive tests, and very few neuropsychological tests are available for assessment of older deaf adults who regularly use both American Sign Language and English. This project will fill this critical need, by developing tests in ASL and written English, identifying how ASL-English bilingualism affects performance on these tests, and the cognitive profile of deaf AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Peripheral neuropathy is the main dose limiting side effect of many widely used and effective chemotherapeutic drugs. Most chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathies are characterized by loss of nerve fibers (axons). Here we will explore several avenues to block this destructive process. If successful, this project will identify novel treatment strategies for the prevention and treatment of chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy, which have the potential to be translated to the clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) are effective in many EGFR-mutated non small-cell lung cancer patients but not curative and always followed by the development of acquired resistance, most often a lethal event. We have uncovered a key step in this process and propose to use this insight to better understand how lung tumor cells resist drug treatment and define a new therapeutic approaches. Our goal is to use laboratory insights to improve care for lung cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative and Significance Regulation of genome stability is the hallmark of normal cells, and often deregulated in cancer cells. This project will determine whether the Origin Recognition Complex (ORC), till now believed to be essential for replication initiation, can be bypassed in cancer cells and the mechanism of this bypass. This will be very important for understanding how genome instability occurs in cancers. Non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ) mediated repair of double-strand breaks in DNA is important for the resistance of a cancer cell to radiotherapy and common types of chemotherapy. By implicating a novel family of protein kinases in the signal transduction from DSB to activation of NHEJ, the project will identify new targets for drugs that will increase the sensitivity of cancer cells to radiotherapy or chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Unlike neural stem cells in most other regions of the brain which disappear following development, dentate gyrus neural stem cells become quiescent so that they can remain in the adult brain, generating new neurons and contributing an added layer of plasticity to the hippocampal circuit throughout adulthood. The proposed research aims to understand the special developmental process that leads to the establishment of quiescent dentate gyrus neural stem cells and will give us insight into mechanisms that promote long-term neural stem cell maintenance. Future studies may translate the fundamental principles of neural stem cell maintenance derived from this research into therapeutic interventions to enhance neural plasticity and neuroregeneration in the adult brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Glutathione (GSH) is the master antioxidant in the body and mainly produced in hepatocytes and depletion of hepatic glutathione has found to strongly correlate with an increased susceptibility to oxidative stress and high risk of many diseases ranging from liver injuries to immunodeficiency, Parkinson’s disease and infectious diseases; however, unlike those conventional serum markers, hepatic glutathione depletion cannot be readily monitored through blood testing. The objective of this proposal is to develop an innovation nanotechnology that empower blood test to be a simple and rapid tool for noninvasive and consecutive monitoring of hepatic GSH depletion. The success will allow this crucial pathophysiological process to be readily monitored in the clinics and serve as an earlier indicator for liver injuries and many other oxidative-stress related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Underserved racial/ethnic minority and low-income individuals with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) have relatively poor access to kidney transplantation, including in early stages of the process to obtain a transplant where the dialysis facility team's assessment of whether a patient is suitable for transplant is pivotal. This application will support an early-stage investigator seeking to become an independent researcher who will investigate these assessment processes, the multi-level (provider, facility, community, and region) factors that shape them, and their impact on patient-level transplant access and disparities. This K01 award will provide mentorship and rich training opportunities to develop new research skills and knowledge, enabling the investigator to conduct groundbreaking research in this area and foster the development and implementation of multi-level interventions that address barriers to transplant for underserved patients with ESRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Tau protein may play a role in regulating protein phosphatase 1 (PP1) in neurons and disease-related modification of tau may cause aberrations in this function leading to toxicity in Alzheimer’s disease and AD- related dementias, however, there are many critical gaps in our knowledge of this potential physiological and pathological mechanism. We will take a multifaceted approach spanning cell culture models (including primary neurons) and in vivo mouse models of normal tau biology, sporadic tauopathy and inherited tauopathy to rigorously study the mechanistic connections between tau and PP1 in multiple cellular pathways. This work will have a significant impact by shedding light on a potentially novel physiological function of tau and the mechanisms driving tau toxicity in sporadic and inherited tauopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The treatment of prostate cancer by radical prostatectomy has long term survival benefits, but in an effort to completely remove the cancer, surgeons often remove nerves adjacent to the prostate which increases postoperative incontinence and impotence. This program will develop new microscopy technology to image prostate surgical specimens during surgery in order to determine if the nerves can be spared without leaving residual cancer. This can increase the rates of nerve sparing prostatectomies, improving postoperative quality of life for prostate cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Viral mimicry is an emerging therapeutic approach that transcriptionally reactivates endogenous retroviruses and retrotransposons in cancer cells to elicit intracellular antiviral pathways that promote antitumor effects and augment the efficacy of certain cancer therapies, including immunotherapy. However, viral mimicry inducing agents identified to date target both cancer and normal cells, leading to significant side effects for cancer patients. Understanding how the FBXO44/SUV39H1 pathway promotes DNA replication-coupled repetitive element silencing selectively in cancer cells could uncover a targetable epigenetic vulnerability whose inhibition induces viral mimicry to prevent tumor growth and progression and enhance the efficacy of cancer therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Insulin resistance is a risk factor for metabolic syndrome and is often observed in patients suffering from obesity, a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Endothelin-1 is increased in patients with obesity and may contribute to insulin resistance. The current proposal will elucidate mechanism by which ET-1 contributes to insulin resistance and will provide preclinical evidence to determine if ET-1 antagonists improve insulin sensitivity and cardiovascular outcomes associated with insulin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Digital mobile-delivered obesity interventions have the potential to impact a wider population than traditional in- person programs, but to date have not resulted in similar weight losses. Newer digital approaches called just- in-time-adaptive interventions (JITAIs) offer adaptive, personalized feedback “when needed” and in “real time,” but there has been no examination of what types of support are needed for weight loss, for whom, and in what behavioral contexts. This study uses a micro-randomized trial to systematically test the effects of behavior change techniques on achievement of daily behavioral goals to optimize message delivery in a comprehensive weight loss JITAI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are approximately 360,000 survivors of preterm birth per year in the US, and these infants have a higher risk of wheeze, asthma, and longer-term lung disease. Methods to assess disease severity and response to treatment have been limited by the difficulty of performing pulmonary function tests among infants. This project will use non-invasive oscillometry to measure lung mechanics among spontaneously breathing healthy term infants and preterm infants with and without lung disease, to improve understanding of developmental lung trajectories and determine the extent to which this novel tool can measure disease severity, quantify response to treatments, and predict longer-term lung health among preterm infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: We study how many types of viruses (SARS-CoV, flu, HIV...) attack cells, and what factors can help or hinder this. We use a technique called Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) to learn how the parts of viruses that do the attacks, called “fusion peptides,” are built, and how proteins in viruses interact with membranes (cell walls), to find possible targets for new drugs to fight the viruses. We also use ESR to study how complexin, an important protein that is related to diseases of the nervous system, interacts with membranes.

PHR: Project Narrative Synaptic connections are the fundamental building blocks of the brain. Many psychiatric and neurodegenerative diseases involve pathological synaptic function at the cellular and molecular level, but little is known about how synaptic molecules operate in health and in disease. Using a powerful combination of genetics, live animal imaging, biochemistry, and physiology, we propose to study complexin and Munc13, two essential proteins required for proper synapse function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this project is to collect and disseminate nationally representative Wave VI data of the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent to Adult Health (Add Health). The data to be collected and disseminated will be used by thousands of researchers to better understand the social, economic, psychosocial, contextual, and biological determinants of health trajectories and disparities among the cohort of Americans who are approaching midlife. The project has extraordinary potential to contribute to the science of aging, health, and health disparities for decades to come, as the Add Health cohort ages into the middle adult years and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project  Narrative:  The  mechanisms  that  protect  stalled  DNA  replication  forks  and  promote  their  recovery  are crucial for genomic stability and, paradoxically, may also drive chemoresistance in BRCA- deficient tumors. We  will investigate the mechanisms by which the ATR kinase protects stalled replication forks in BRCA- proficient cells,  as  well  as  the  PALB2  and  Ubc13- mediated  pathways  that  promote  fork  protection/recovery  in  BRCA- deficient  cells, shedding new light on how to target fork protection/recovery pathways in cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public health relevance) Proper brain function requires a lot of energy from fuel molecules like glucose, and this energy supply process is highly regulated at the level of individual brain cells and from moment to moment. We know surprisingly little about how this regulation works, and how it goes awry (as it is thought to do) in aging or in neurodegenerative disease. This project will discover the key details of brain cell energy metabolism, including its dynamic response to brain activity and how it varies among different cell types in the brain, and this knowledge will enable future work on disease mechanisms and how they might be corrected by therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The purpose of this R01 proposal is to deepen our knowledge of the primary cause of drug overdose deaths in the U.S. today: novel psychoactive synthetic opioids, the majority of which are fentanyl analogues. Using a multicenter registry of patients who present to emergency departments, novel fentanyl analogue overdose will be studied in terms of its epidemiology, analytical confirmation, clinical risk factors, and treatment needs, by a uniquely qualified multidisciplinary team with an extensive track record of collaboration in the field. The overall specific aims of this proposal, are three-fold: (1) molecular identification of novel synthetic fentanyl analogues using state-of-the-art toxicology analytics; (2) determination of treatment requirements such as naloxone, need for critical care and/or mechanical ventilation; and (3) geolocation of regional and temporal overdose trends.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 6 million children in the United States have asthma, causing billions of dollars in healthcare expenditures and over 14 million missed school days annually, with most childhood asthma morbidity attributable to medication non-adherence. The proposed research program will evaluate a school-supervised asthma therapy intervention to improve medication adherence in children with poorly controlled asthma that is tailored for real- world settings. This intervention fills an unmet need for the families, pediatric practices and schools that support children with poorly controlled asthma, and has the potential to dramatically improve childhood asthma outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 30,000 Americans die from hepatocellular (liver) carcinoma (HCC) every year and current treatments provide no long-term benefit, highlighting the urgent need for new and effective therapies. We have discovered that a protein called BCL6 is required for the growth of HCC tumors, and found that inhibiting BCL6 not only blocks hepatic tumor growth but also enhances the ability of the immune system to eradicate the tumor. The results of the experiments proposed in this application will establish the role of BCL6 in promoting HCC and evaluate novel small molecule inhibitors of BCL6 as a novel HCC therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Narrative High-resolution recording at the meso-scale around a depth electrode is arguably one of the most important gaps in the BCI and diagnostic neurosurgery communities. Our approach to recording uses the novel combination of substrate and electrode size to achieve directional sensitivity to isolate local field potentials in the human cortex. This project will conduct an observational study in epilepsy patient volunteers and our translational goal is to eventually treat patients with profound speech dysfunction, first locked-in syndrome and ultimately non-fluent aphasia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is now the most common chronic liver disease in the world, estimated to affect ~25% of the world’s population, and its incidence is projected to continue to grow over the next several decades. Yet, currently available medical therapies for NAFLD are quite limited in number and efficacy. This proposal aims to use a subset of genetically defined NAFLD associated with nuclear envelope defects as a model to gain fundamental insights into NAFLD pathophysiology and provide avenues for novel therapeutic approaches to benefit the millions of people affected by this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We will study the role of an adaptive stress response (termed “Integrated Stress Response”) and its effector ATF4 in progression and metastasis of malignant melanoma. We will examine how in non-malignant cells the ISR shapes the microenvironment by remodeling blood vessels and the extracellular matrix, and how in turn melanoma cells respond to the microenvironment by using the ISR in combination with well-known pro- tumorigenic mediators to promote invasion and survival during metastatic dissemination. The long-term aim of these studies is to uncover new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The Brain Research Apprenticeships In New York At Columbia (BRAINYAC) program addresses science education disparities found in low-income neighborhoods by providing an authentic mentored research experience for high school students who are from under-served neighborhoods or under-represented minorities in science. We will support these students through preparatory training during the program and opportunities for alumni of the program. In this way we seek to reinforce students’ intent to pursue studies or careers in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on finding more effective treatment strategies for pancreatic cancer, one of the most lethal cancers, with a five year survival rate of only ~10%. Pancreatic cancer is extremely aggressive and responds very poorly to existing treatments, this is partially because of the tumor microenvironment that makes tumors more resistant to therapies. Our laboratory studies how this environment induces drug resistance, particularly by enhancing DNA repair, and we have identified novel drivers of resistance that we will target to develop new improved therapies for pancreatic cancer, reducing mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Biomedical research holds great promise for finding better treatments and hopefully cures for a range of debilitating and/or fatal diseases, but the innovation and problem solving needed to harness the potential of biomedical research requires a diverse group of individuals who generate new perspectives and more inventive solutions. Given that diversity is critical to biomedical research, it is important to acknowledge that the benefits of diversity are only fully realized through inclusion. The purpose of the IMSD at Vanderbilt is to ensure that students from diverse backgrounds and identities not only acquire the knowledge and skills to pursue successful careers in biomedical research and related areas, but do so in an environment that provides a sense of belonging, where they are comfortable bringing their authentic self to the training experience and empowered to reach their full potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Brain metastases occur in almost half of the triple negative and epidermal growth factor receptor positive breast cancer patients and are strongly associated with a high mortality rate among US women patients. The present application will identify and develop a novel predictive marker to enable early detection of brain metastasis, and the conceptual advances of cMET/MUC5AC-axis in the metastatic brain microenvironment could lead to the development of effective management strategies. The current proposal will block the cMET/MUC5AC-axis as a novel targeting approach for targeting brain metastasis of TN and ErbB2-positive BC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE & RELEVANCE There are up to 100 million chronic pain sufferers in the US, a majority of whom seek treatment via physical rehabilitation. Rehabilitation for orthopedic and neurologic conditions often involves the use of motor learning strategies, in which new movement patterns are developed using repeated task practice, but we currently have very little knowledge of how pain impacts motor learning, especially in older adults. The purpose of this project will be to thoroughly examine the effects of pain on motor learning processes in young and older adults with and without chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Human vision is best at the fovea, yet we know much less about the specific code that the retina uses to convey the retinal image to the brain than we do about peripheral retina. This project will use a new technological approach to survey the different kinds of retinal cells that provide us with vision at the fovea, knowledge that could accelerate the development of new approaches to restoring vision in the blind.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interventional Cone Beam CT (CBCT) provides critical 3D information to guide minimally-invasive procedures in the abdomen, but CBCT image quality is often compromised by organ deformation due to breathing, cardiac, and peristaltic motions. We propose a novel framework to mitigate the effects of this complex deformable motion using only the CBCT image data, without a need for gating, external trackers, or fiducial markers. This algorithm will remove a major impediment to 3D guidance in procedures such as transcatheter embolization procedures in the abdomen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: COX-2 is a critically important target in cancer that we found to influence mechanical force exerted by cancer cells, the extracellular matrix and cancer associated fibroblasts, and tumor and spleen metabolism. Here we intend to focus on new directions that investigate the role of COX-2 in mechanobiology, and in metabolism and immune suppression to develop new translatable strategies to improve triple negative breast cancer treatment outcome. We will also deliver COX-2 siRNA using novel dextran nanoparticles that will also be modified to scavenge cytokines in the tumor microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Even expert radiologists can find it challenging to detect the presence of a subtle, low-contrast pulmonary nodule in a chest X-ray, which could potentially indicate cancer. This project will develop a validated computational approach to generate a diverse and visually realistic set of simulated nodules in real chest X-ray images, in order to i) characterize radiologist performance on an image-by-image basis, ii) develop an image- computable model of expert performance, and iii) create a novel learning-based paradigm to characterize the perceptual and cognitive mechanisms of nodule detection. This project will provide foundational knowledge of the visual and cognitive processes that underlie expertise in nodule detection, and will promote the development of a learning-based protocol to enhance the diagnostic training of radiology residents and other medical professionals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Prostate cancer stem cells (PCSCs) constitute prostate initiation, progression, metastasis as well  as drug resistance, leading to castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC), which  represents a highly aggressive cancer with poor outcome due to the lack of an effectively  targeting strategy. Our study aims to identify novel druggable targets critical for maintaining  PCSCs and CRPC progression in order to develop an effectively therapeutic strategy to target  PCSC-mediated CRPC progression and drug resistance. Our study will not only reveal a paradigm-shift  concept and novel mechanistic insight for PCSC regulation, but also offer a highly effective  strategy for targeting CRPC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposal will: (1) establish a broad network that brings together a corps of interdisciplinary researchers to establish innovative and rigorous scientific bases to understand emotional well-being (EWB); (2) contribute important foundational knowledge of EWB by advancing a new generation of measurement and mechanistic research together; and (3) ultimately provide important information about understanding and promoting EWB across the life course including the use of mind-body interventions (MBIs), risk and protective factors as well as windows of opportunity to promote EWB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Recent electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) images (EPRI) of absolute pO2 in murine tumors have shown for the first time significantly improved tumor cure when hypoxic regions were specifically targeted for dose boosts when compared to dose boosts to equal volumes of well oxygenated tumor. For translation to routine clinical use of this radiotherapy strategy, we will use preclinical EPR pO2 images as a ground truth, to develop novel methods to derive a signature from a suite of magnetic resonance (MR) images of several tissue physiologic factors, available for human use, to sharpen the definition of tumor hypoxia delineated by positron emission tomography (PET) images using a hypoxia radiotracer, 18F-fuoronitroimidazole (FMISO). The resulting modified PET-FMISO images can more accurately represent and emulate EPRI pO2 images, which can be used in turn in image-guided radiation therapy of hypoxia tumors with improved delivery and effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Myocarditis, a serious inflammatory reaction in the heart causing cardiac death, can occur as a result of immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy. Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) are a novel class of cancer therapeutics which release the brakes on T-cell cytotoxicity against tumor cells but may also lead to T-cell mediated myocarditis. This project aims to define the precise T-cell subsets, identify molecular mechanisms potentiating T-cell activation/expansion, and uncover the culprit antigens in ICI-induced myocarditis, thus paving the way to prevention and cure of this serious side effect of ICIs and helping ensure the cardiovascular safety of cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE No pharmacologic treatments have been identified to treat Alzheimer's disease (AD); however, lifestyle interventions targeting modifiable AD risk factors provide a promising evidence-based prevention strategy. The proposed study will add comprehensive assessments of cerebral autoregulation, autonomic function, and vascular structure and function in 500 cognitively normal but at-risk older adults enrolled in a multi-site randomized controlled trial involving an intensive 2-year lifestyle intervention to examine intervention effects on neurovascular mechanisms and their association with cognitive and brain outcomes. The results will provide critical insight into preclinical changes that compromise brain perfusion and may identify an effective strategy for improving neurovascular function, which could have important consequences for preventing AD and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic is a public health crisis characterized by pneumonia and multiorgan dysfunction. We propose a novel investigation of the intermediate and long-term cardiac, vascular, and renal consequences of COVID-19. Our approach will investigate the frequency of and risk factors for serious cardiac events in COVID-19 survivors and will characterize changes in vascular and kidney structure and function over time, with a goal of identifying future interventions to mitigate adverse outcomes in these patients.

PHR: Project Narrative Activating heat production in a tissue termed brown fat might offer new ways to combat obesity, however, availability of coenzyme Q (CoQ) might limit brown fat activity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE ! The Charleston Alcohol Research Center is dedicated to addressing one of the nation’s foremost public health concerns: alcohol use disorder. The Center embraces a multidisciplinary, translational research approach involving both clinical and preclinical researchers who are investigating why some individuals transition from social drinking that can be controlled to more excessive, uncontrolled drinking. Understanding brain mechanisms involved in this transition to excessive, compulsive-like alcohol consumption is crucial for developing new and more effective therapeutic strategies for arresting the progression to alcohol addiction, and preventing negative consequences associated with alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CD33 is a validated target for acute myeloid leukemia (AML) immunotherapy but existing therapeutics are ineffective in many patients. Since AML cells are highly radiosensitive across the entire genetic disease spectrum, we plan to develop and optimize a new form of CD33-directed radioimmunotherapy with the a-emitter astatine-211 for use in transplant and non-transplant settings. We believe astatine-211 is ideally suited for targeting CD33 because it deposits high energy over a short distance to enable AML cell kill with limited off- target toxicity and decays without any long-lived or potentially dangerous daughter isotopes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposal describes an inter-disciplinary project whose goal is to systematically determine the role of RNA- binding proteins (a set of cellular regulatory proteins that recognize, bind, and regulate mRNAs) in the process of cancer progression. Our preliminary data suggests that these regulators play a disproportionately important role in cancer and our project is a multi-faceted computational/experimental strategy to characterize this landscape. If successful, the project will expand our understanding of cancer pathways in novel directions that may have significant impact on diagnosis and treatment of a variety of cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Type 2 diabetes affects 30.3 million people in the U.S., and the reasons why some people with diabetes suffer worse diabetes complications are not well understood. For many people with diabetes, differences in the immune system may play an important role in how diabetes progresses. This research project will measure immune system differences in blood samples from people with diabetes to understand how these differences affect their diabetes complications and outcomes so that we can develop better, more individualized treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Contemporary theories of schizophrenia posit that symptoms arise from deficits in using prior experience to form predictions about sensory information and in using these predictions to help interpret the world; however, an empirical basis for delineating the specific nature of these deficits is lacking. The visual system is uniquely suited for the experimental study of prediction abnormalities in schizophrenia. The current project focuses on visual adaptation – a canonical form of experience-dependence in visual processing – to characterize alterations in the influence of prior experience in schizophrenia, at the level of brain and behavior, and to identify the clinical significance of these alterations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In utero exposure to ethanol at low doses, known to contribute to fetal alcohol spectrum disorders and increase risk for alcohol use disorders, is shown in rodents to stimulate in the hypothalamus both hypocretin/orexin peptide neurons that play a major role in alcohol intake and abuse and local inflammatory neuroimmune systems. In a transparent zebrafish model, we will use live imaging to characterize, at a single-cell level and in real-time across developmental stages, these effects of embryonic ethanol exposure on this neuropeptide system, test if the observed changes are causally related to disturbances in behavior, and determine if specific inflammatory chemokine systems have a functional role in mediating these lasting neuronal and behavioral disturbances. This research will increase our fundamental understanding of the long-term effects of embryonic ethanol exposure at low levels, creating a stronger foundation for developing improved strategies for prevention or reversal of the serious consequences from maternal consumption of even small amounts of ethanol during pregnancy.

PHR: The proposed research aims to determine how mechanical forces exerted from extracellular matrix in the tumor microenvironment are translated into biochemical signals to promote tumor invasion and metastasis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In a sample of 200 young and middle age adult romantic couples assessed over 7 months, the Connected Lives: Overcoming the Self through Empathy (CLOSE) Study will investigate whether the harmful effects of repetitive negative thinking (RNT) on social and mental health also extend to one’s romantic partner. By combining data from a novel neuroimaging empathy task with data from two smartphone apps designed measure thought and behavior in everyday life, the CLOSE study tests the hypothesis that RNT impairs participants’ ability to empathize (and thus socially connect) with their partners, which exacerbates negative health consequences for both members of the relationship. This work holds promise for advancing our understanding of how individual and social risks for psychopathology operate together to shape emotional disorders with the ultimate goal of identifying novel intervention targets to strengthen social connectedness in the service of improving mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Whether bacterial or human, cells transform their proteomic content to adapt and proliferate. The most efficient proteome design in turn dominates the evolutionary dynamics within microbial communities or cancer populations. By investigating the design principles for how to construct an effective proteome, we will provide insights for attacking proteome homeostasis in bacterial pathogens and disease cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although many mutations in retinitis pigmentosa (RP) arise in rod-specific genes, it is secondary loss of cone function, leading to diminished high-resolution daylight vision that is most debilitating. We provide evidence glucose transport from RPE to photoreceptors is diminished in RP, causing their starvation and loss of function. A pathway regulating glucose transport is identified, and we link its deregulation to RPE metabolome changes in RP.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Data Management and Analysis Core (DMAC) provides centralized biostatistics as well as collaborative research and data management support for the research projects of the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) Superfund Research Program (UAB-SRP). Through collaboration and consultation, the DMAC will provide UAB-SRP investigators with assistance and direction in their experimental design, data collection, data management, and interim and final statistical data analysis. The DMAC will lead the data integration and serve as the focal point from which UAB-SRP investigators and trainees, including basic scientists, biomedical researchers, and clinicians, can draw data management and statistical expertise for the communication and analysis of their research projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The genome within all cells of a mammalian system is identical, yet distinct cell types display varied phenotypes due to differences in their epigenome that play a key role in regulating gene expression, and dysregulation of these regulatory factors is associated with developmental disorders, cancer and aging. Current techniques to map epigenetic landscapes in different cell types are dependent on the ability to isolate these cell types at high purity using cell surface markers and high-quality antibodies that are frequently unavailable, or through the expression of cell type-specific fluorescent reporters in transgenic animal models that are extremely time intensive to generate. Therefore, in this proposal we plan to develop single-cell multiomics technologies to simultaneously quantify the transcriptome and different epigenetic marks/features from the same cell, thereby enabling unbiased cell type identification in silico using the transcriptome and quantification of gene regulatory landscapes by pooling together the epigenome of cells that correspond to the same cell type, resulting in an marker-free approach to map the epigenome of different cell types, including rare ones, within complex tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In this project, we will determine the conditions under which new motor memories are created, how existing motor memories are updated and the rules by which they generalize to new tasks. This project will contribute to funda- mental knowledge on the mechanisms of human motor learning with both empirical work and the development of a novel computational framework for motor learning. This knowledge has the potential to be used to understand deficits in neurological disorders and develop paradigms that can improve rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT CORE (CEC) Project Narrative Communities proximate to sources of environmental contamination are adversely affected both by ongoing exposure and resulting health issues. Most often, these communities are also economically disadvantaged and lack the resources and capacity needed to overcome the impact of hazardous substance exposure. As such, the Community Engagement Core (CEC) will facilitate the development and maintenance of an infrastructure to support culturally-appropriate remediation of risks and/or complications of chronic lung diseases and resilience in communities impacted by hazardous substances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) is an incurable disease which manifests resistance to both conventional chemotherapy approaches and ibrutinib, a B cell receptor signaling inhibitor. Here we will use primary patient material to prospectively investigate the role of NFκB pathway activation in ibrutinib resistance in MCL. Armed with our preliminary data, we will evaluate a novel strategy to overcome this resistance by targeting the Nedd8- activating enzyme (NAE), by conducting investigations in vitro, in mouse models using ibrutinib-resistant MCL cell lines and patient-derived xenografts, and in a clinical trial of pevonedistat, an investigational inhibitor of NAE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease for which there are no biomarkers and only limited treatments stemming from a poor understanding of its pathogenesis. Here, we propose to integrate novel computational methods with spatially resolved transcriptomic and proteomic analyses of clinically deep-phenotyped postmortem ALS brains and spinal cords to determine the specific molecular correlates of functional impairment in this disease. By integrating these data with WGS and RNAseq data, our ultimate goal is to unveil how disease-associated variants drive specific dysfunction in ALS, which may in turn foster precision medicine-based treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human cancer is one of the leading causes of death worldwide, a reflection of the fact that the molecular basis of the disease is yet poorly understood. We propose a novel computational strategy to build a cancer progression model using genomic data obtained from excised tumor tissue samples (static data). The delineation of the dynamic disease process and the identification of pivotal molecular events that drive stepwise cancer progression will provide a wealth of new insights into tumor biology and guide the development of improved cancer diagnostics, prognostics and targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Inhaled particulate matter containing heavy metals such as arsenic, manganese and cadmium, are known to cause chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), however the mechanism remains unclear. Residents of an EPA proposed superfund site live close to coke ovens and coal fired power plants in Birmingham, AL and have twice the prevalence of COPD than elsewhere and their lungs demonstrate the presence of abnormal proteins. We will work closely with the EPA and ATSDR in providing information to the community about COPD and about the science that informs our work.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE   Environmental exposure of the lung to airborne mixed heavy metals contributes to development of chronic  lung diseases, including asthma in children. This project will identify novel pathobiologic mechanisms for  airway remodeling and hyper-responsiveness related to heavy metal exposure, and develop new therapeutic  strategies to treat asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent developments in artificial intelligence and neuroscience have revealed neural population codes for reinforcement that represent predictions of a range of potential reward outcomes, rather than a singular expected value. This distributional reinforcement learning has enabled improved performance of artificial agents and has clear implications for human choice behavior and neuropsychiatric disorders. This proposal aims to leverage our experience recording human neuronal activity from the brains of epilepsy patients to begin addressing the novel avenues of research in distributional reinforcement learning. We will determine where distributional codes exist in the human prefrontal and mesial temporal lobes, and how those codes are expressed dynamically in time as humans make impulsive choices and learn reward probabilities. The results of these experiments will have important basic scientific implications and will begin to address how distributional reinforcement learning in the human brain underlies choice behavior that has implications for neuropsychiatric disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Combined BET Bromodomain Inhibition (BBDI) and CDK4/6 inhibition demonstrated strong synergism in preclinical models of NUT Carcinoma, an aggressive and rare malignancy with no FDA approved therapy or established treatment regimen. We will conduct a phase 1 clinical trial (NCI Protocol #10509) of the BET inhibitor ZEN003694 plus the CDK4/6 inhibitor abemaciclib in NUT Carcinoma and other solid tumors. Using pre-treatment, on-treatment, and progression biopsies, we will study proof-of-mechanism and biomarkers of response and resistance to combined BET and CDK4/6 inhibition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Higher prevalence of obesity increases risk of cancer in rural populations who often lack access to weight control programs, have fewer food and physical built environment resources that promote healthy lifestyles, and limited availability of evidence-based treatment. This study will assess the effectiveness of TelemedTeam, a two-year team-based telemedicine intervention that pairs intensive group telemedicine visits with a lifestyle coach and quarterly team-based clinic visits with the patient, PCP, and telemedicine lifestyle coach. This novel collaborative telemedicine solution combines the benefits of group-based treatment, home-based telemedicine delivery and team-based care integration in local rural clinics, capitalizing on the importance of medical management, and local resources and support networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative We are proposing to develop and test affordable high surface area carbonaceous hybrid materials fabricated from natural-fibers, industrial carbon fiber waste and vegetable precursor textile fibers for removal of heavy metals (Cd, As, Mn) from contaminated soil and for household air filtration. We will optimize and tailor the fibers to obtain sorbent mats and filters to be used in these applications. The research proposed here will advance the material science and engineering domain with knowledge gain to be applicable for environmental remediation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Among the top preventable causes of death, suicide is arguably the most preventable as it is the result of a voluntary act, yet our ability to prevent suicide remains rudimentary and ineffective as evidenced by escalating rates across nearly every state, age range, and demographic cluster. Identifying proximal suicide risk markers will inform our ability to detect and ultimately intervene prior to an individual acting on suicidal thoughts. NIH’s mission will be served by the proposed study through improving the prediction of suicidal behaviors in high-risk populations and informing prevention efforts, ultimately reducing suffering and mortality with substantial societal cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hereditary hypophosphatemic disorders caused by inactivating mutations of Phex and Dmp1 are characterized by elevated serum FGF23 levels and hypophosphatemia leading to impaired skeletal growth and mineralization. These alterations in bone and mineral metabolism are thought to be the direct consequence of impaired PHEX and DMP1 interaction in bone. This project proposes to test whether the interaction between PHEX and DMP1 in the kidney prevents FGF23-induced phosphaturia, thus providing novel potential therapeutic targets in diseases associated with altered phosphate homeostasis.

PHR: CORE NARRATIVE – DATA MANAGEMENT AND ANALYSIS CORE The Data Management and Analysis Core (DMAC) develops an integrated data management plan for the entire SRP. PHR: CORE NARRATIVE – COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT CORE The Community Engagement Core (CEC) will respond to the concerns of communities impacted by hazardous substances and identifying effective public health intervention and prevention strategies that reduce the amount and toxicity of PAHs and other harmful substances. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The cause for the late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (LOAD), which accounts for > 95% of AD cases, is unknown. In this project, we will test a novel hypothesis that O3 exposure synergizes with aging and APOE4 leading to LOAD in a sex-dependent manner. The results from these studies will not only shed new lights on the etiology of LOAD but may also lead to the development of novel strategies for the prevention and treatment of this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction represents a significant public health burden in the United States. Although effective therapies exist, gaps in their adoption contribute substantially to excess morbidity and mortality. The “polypill” represents a potential strategy for simplifying the adoption of proven heart failure therapies. We propose a practical, single-center randomized trial to test the feasibility and effectiveness of a polypill-based strategy for the treatment of heart failure in a low-income, racially-diverse population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – TEEGUARDEN PROJECT This project will produce transformative tools that dramatically improve researcher ability to measure metabolic potential and chemical distribution, to quantify these molecular determinants of susceptibility in test systems and to compare the results with analogous measurements in humans. Two innovations, activity-based proteomic probes, and multi-modal chemical microscopy, will open new scientific horizons in the understanding of molecular determinants of differential susceptibility. The impact will be translatable modeling of PAH exposure effects on metabolism and distribution that directly inform our stakeholders in environmental remediation and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder is one of the most expensive and damaging of all chronic medical conditions and has few treatment options. Our work has shown that brain inflammatory signals promote excessive ethanol consumption and that pharmacological intervention with certain anti-inflammatory drugs reduces drinking. However, neuroinflammatory pathways are still an under-explored area in alcohol research, and our proposed experiments to explore the role of interferons have the potential to discover new approaches to reduce excessive drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many people report using alcohol to alleviate stress. Yet heavy alcohol consumption provokes a stress response, resulting in a feed-forward cycle of stress-alcohol interactions that contribute to acquiring a diagnosis of alcohol use disorders. This project uses novel neuroscience technologies in rhesus monkeys to understand how the primate brain adapts to aberrant alcohol-stress interactions and open new pathways for developing personalized treatments for alcohol use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – ANDERSON PROJECT We propose to develop and test generalizable technology to measure movement of bioavailable PAHs between sediment, water, and air at Superfund sites relative to seasonal and tidal variations. We will determine where and how much PAHs are moving at Superfund sites, providing regulators and stakeholders key information to assess potential remediation strategies, assess remediation performance and understand key system parameters of as a function of daily and seasonal time scales. With novel chemical exposure wristband sampler technology, we will describe to stakeholders and communities a) how external exposure to PAH mixtures varies as a function of location near a Superfund site, b) which components of the mixtures, if any, may threaten human health, and c) how remediation of a Superfund site influences the local community's external exposure to PAHs.

PHR: The goal of the current proposal is to bring new insight into the fundamental mechanisms of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) - associated mutations on the cellular behaviors of human specific progenitor subtypes during early cortical development and on neuronal network activity. Thus, the proposed research has the potential to advance our understanding of the neuropathophysiology of NF1 and to fertilize the development of novel therapeutics strategies for NF1, which is relevant to the mission of NINDS that pertains to seeking fundamental knowledge about the brain and nervous system that will help to reduce the burden of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance The goals of this proposed study are to examine the trends in the prevalence and incidence of Alzheimer’s disease related dementias (ADRDs) over the past 30 years (1991-2020) and to determine whether, and to what extent, the risk of ADRD is affected by anticancer, antihypertensive and antidiabetic drug therapies. There is no large cohort study monitoring and assessing the effects of these medications on the risk of developing ADRDs. This study takes advantage of the unique opportunity provided by Medicare Part-D comprehensive drug coverage, which was implemented in 2006, wherein medication use for millions of recipients is documented, thereby making it possible to determine the impact of the use of these medications on the risk of developing these dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Decades of research have demonstrated that the immune system can eradicate cancer cells but only if immune evasion mechanisms, such as immune checkpoint proteins, can be overcome. Multiple new immunotherapeutic approaches have recently been developed that can induce durable remissions in patients with advanced cancers – unfortunately, the majority of patients still succumb to their cancers. The goal of this COBRE application is to establish a new Center for Cancer Immunology and Immunotherapy that will focus on understanding immune escape mechanisms, developing new approaches to activate/reinvigorate anticancer immunity, training promising young cancer immunologists and improving the research infrastructure of the University of Louisville.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Mammographic density is one of the strongest known risk factors for breast cancer, but previous studies have almost exclusively been limited to non-Hispanic White women. The proposed research sets out to study non- genetic and genetic risk factors of high mammographic density in a large, diverse population of Hispanic women. Completion of the study aims will advance our understanding of mammographic density and provide insights into racial disparities in breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: The brain is very vulnerable to metabolic problems and synapses, the machinery that mediates the conversion of electrical information into chemical information, are very sensitive to metabolic imbalances. Since neurodegenerative diseases results in improper function of synapses, we hypothesize that these disease states have a strong metabolic component arising from an imbalance in fuel availability and fuel use at the level of individual synapses. The fuel here that matters is a molecule called ATP and our work aims to understand how it is produced at synapses, who consumes it and how in diseases that cause dementia (e.g. Alzheimer’s) this changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Each year in the United States, over 2,500 children undergo hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) as life- saving therapy for cancers, immunodeficiencies, blood disorders, and many other life-threatening diseases. After HCT, many children develop complex lung disease triggered by infections, chemotherapy, the transplanted immune system, and other factors. An improved understanding of the pathobiologic role of pulmonary infections and pulmonary inflammation is necessary in order to improve survival after pediatric HCT and thus constitutes the focus of this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis or blood poisoning is a life-threatening illness arising when the body is overcome by infection that has spread through the bloodstream. Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. Currently, there are no effective treatments that can cure sepsis. This project aims to understand how the host responds to blood infections, and to develop new therapies that could protect the organs against the damaging effects of the body's own uncontrolled defense systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative There is a significant underrepresentation of Hispanic/Latinx investigators in the research workforce with Hispanics contributing with a 6% of all funded NIH grants, even though Hispanics represent 18% of the total US population. The goal of this application is to create a highly focused, intense, and personalized mentoring program to train 12 junior Hispanic/Latinx students, post-docs and recently hired faculty members. Mentoring and training activities will be conducted during an expanded and enhanced version of the annual meeting of the American Society of Hispanic Psychiatry by a group of mid-career and senior Hispanic/Latinx investigators with a track record in NIH funding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Appropriate modulation of insulin clearance (the removal of insulin from the circulation) is critical for the prevention of diabetes in at-risk individuals. PHR: Narrative This project aims to develop an operational surveillance system based on routine hospital testing to track SARS- CoV-2 transmission and immunity seroprevalence in the community and vulnerable groups over time. The pro- posed statistical methods focus on adjusting sample representation, yielding reliable subgroup estimates, and examining disparities across health outcomes, social determinants, and behaviors. The data collection and anal- ysis procedure will be publicly accessible via a web interface and enhance data harmonization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: To improve care in newly diagnosed Pediatric type 1 diabetes patients we propose using a combination of (4T) Teamwork, Targets, and Technology to maintain Tight glucose control to optimize patient glucose and psychosocial outcomes. We will use an integrated approach to care and develop automated glucose data management and psychosocial monitoring systems that can be translated to other US clinics to optimize glucose control and reduce burden on patients, families, and health care teams. The research outlined in this proposal aims to lower HbA1c, develop glucose data management and communication systems and support the psychosocial challenges of T1D in a program that is practical, sustainable, and translatable to other Pediatric Diabetes clinics in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glucose homeostasis is maintained primarily by the action of the regulator, insulin and the counterregulators, glucagon, cortisol, epinephrine, and growth hormone, and impaired counterregulation can lead to both hyper- and hypo-glycemia, causing chronic and acute pathologies. Alpha cell dysfunction and impaired glucagon secretion exacerbate type 2 diabetes which has reached epidemic proportions worldwide and places enormous burden on the healthcare system. The mechanisms and contribution of impaired counterregulation to type 2 diabetes and development of hypoglycemia will be studied.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Wound healing cost the healthcare system billions of dollars and the current cost is set to increase as the population ages. The ability to improve poorly healing wounds would impact the lives of millions of Americans ranging from patients undergoing scheduled surgeries to patients with accidental injuries or wounds caused by other diseases such as diabetes. The goal of this proposal is to develop materials that can use the body’s immune system to promote regenerative wound healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tissue barriers depend on intercellular junctions that seal the space between adjacent cells. Recent work has shown that i) physiological function requires these barriers to be selectively-permeable; ii) dynamic channels that traverse the intercellular junctions mediate permeability; and iii) pharmacologic modulation of channel activity can effectively treat disease. The absence of necessary tools has prevented further study. The project will develop an innovative device to overcome this obstacle and provide a foundation for future advances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This research proposal is directly focused on improving the lives of children and adolescents with kidney disease. We will characterize the relationship between kidney disease biomarkers, quantitative neuroimaging correlates, and cognitive concerns observed in early pediatric chronic kidney disease (CKD) – prior to need for dialysis or transplant. The proposed research will directly evaluate the impact of CKD progression on cognition and the developing brain in order to identify disease-related risk factors, particularly those that are modifiable, that can be harnessed to mitigate cognitive risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: After heart attack the heart loses many muscle cells which leads to the loss of ability to bump blood to the rest of the body. The muscle cells in the heart are not able to regenerate themselves which made it difficult to treat such disease. Here we are developing new transient gene therapy approach to regenerate these muscle cells in the heart and make them able to heal the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The inexorable increase of cephalosporin resistance in N. gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of the sexually transmitted infection gonorrhea, has severely limited treatment options and threatens a public health crisis. This application proposes to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of cephalosporin resistance conferred by mutations in N. gonorrhoeae penicillin-binding protein 2, with the hypothesis that mutations act by restricting protein dynamics. The long-term goal is to translate this information toward the design of new antimicrobials that overcome such mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune suppressive drugs have greatly improved the management of inflammatory joint disorders in children and adults, but increase the risk of serious infections and cancer. In contrast to generalized immunosuppression, this project aims to validate an immune modulating agent for expanding and restoring disease-protective immune cells called Treg to spare joints from damage. If successful, our approach has the potential to greatly improve disease control without further suppressing protective immune responses in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Targeted cancer therapies have the exciting potential to selectively kill malignant cells while sparing healthy tissues, as evidenced by their often remarkable upfront activity in patients. However, in nearly all patients, a subset of residual cancer cells survive therapy and later emerge to give rise to resistant disease that is very difficult to treat. In this proposal, we build on our recent discovery of unique biological processes related to cell death regulation and DNA repair that are activated in residual cancer cells, proposing mechanistic studies that will significantly expand our understanding of residual tumor biology while directly nominating therapeutic strategies to eliminate this critical tumor cell population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Amongst the neuronal populations implicated in sleep-wake control, the ventrolateral preoptic (VLPO) nucleus has emerged as a key sleep-promoting center. This project seeks to define the long-range and local cellular and circuit bases by which arousal and sleep-promoting afferent inputs to the VLPO contribute to behavioral and electrocortical sleep and arousal. Successful completion of the proposed studies may contribute to the development of new therapeutic and interventional strategies for a wide range of sleep and arousal disorders, including insomnia, hypersomnia and aging-related sleep disturbances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is one of the most common pediatric autoimmune diseases caused by complex interactions between genetic susceptibility loci and environmental factors. Despite identifying genetic regions associated with an increased T1D risk, many lack a testable gene or pathway to explain the risk for disease, and even validated variants have not been tested for cell type effects in the immune system. This proposal focuses on a promising gene associated with T1D and islet autoimmunity to understand the cell types responsible for diabetes progression when this genetic alteration is present.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a growing and serious worldwide health problem with significant health and socioeconomic consequences. Poor adherence to continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), the primary treatment option for OSA, is associated with increased morbidity, mortality, and health care costs, and has been a major obstacle in the effective management of OSA. This project addresses the critical need to improve CPAP adherence by refining and testing an innovative couple-focused mobile health intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal will advance our studies of the previous HL131872 program period by examining the role of serotonin receptor signaling and downstream events in the pathogenesis of degenerative mitral regurgitation. The proposed experiments will investigate serotonin related platelet activity in human and canine blood, and relate this mitral valve disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health and to the NIAAA's mission because it employs novel approaches to investigate neuroimmune factors expressed by astrocytes (understudied brain cells that are essential for the proper functioning of the brain) in an animal model of alcohol dependence. The proposed studies will provide insights on how alterations in astrocytes result in increased inflammation leading to increased alcohol drinking. The aforementioned insights, obtained using and clinical genetically engineered animal models emerging “-omic” approaches in a cell-type specific manner (astrocytes), will provide new mechanistic and understanding of the impact of astrocytes in alcohol dependence andwill lead to therapeutic interventions that are not only specific for a given molecular target, but also for a given cellular target and, for this reason, safer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The probability of Mendelian inheritance currently limits the utility of rodents to understand complex genetic processes in embryonic development and disease and to effectively develop drugs and therapeutic approaches that translate well to humans. Such limitations could be overcome by CRISPR/Cas9-mediated gene conversion to increase the probability an animal will inherit a combination of desired alleles, which would reduce the cost, time, and number of animals required to understand and treat complex genetic diseases.
