IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Chronic kidney disease is characterized by damage to kidney cells, accumulation of immune cells such as macrophages, and development of kidney fibrosis. We propose to study how PU.1 signaling pathway regulates macrophage activation and development of chronic kidney disease. Results from our study could provide novel insights into macrophage activation and development of chronic kidney disease and could lead to novel therapeutic strategies for chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Apremilast, a phosphodiesterase type 4 inhibitor and our most promising clinical target for reducing harmful alcohol drinking, has been shown to increase levels of the anti-inflammatory protein, interleukin 10, in the periphery. We investigate how anti-inflammatory signaling in the brain regulates binge-like drinking in mice that have been selectively bred to drink to intoxication. An overarching goal of this proposal is to identify and target anti-inflammatory processes in the brain to reduce drinking and restore alcohol-induced changes in anti- and pro-inflammatory signaling in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Scoliosis is one of the most common pediatric musculoskeletal disorders, causing disfigurement, psychosocial distress, and is associated with increased back and neurological pain later in life. The causes of these disorders of the spine are likely due to a variety of factors, yet little is known about the genetic factors and signaling pathways involved. This proposal will gain mechanistic insight into the regulation of spine development and homeostasis of important spine tissues through analysis of two signaling pathways, implicated by our characterization of several independent genetic animal models of scoliosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Mammalian aging is associated with the expansion and accumulation of fat tissue which hinders metabolic function and increases the incidence of premature death due to type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Cold temperatures can stimulate progenitor cells to form thermogenic beige fat which can boost metabolism to counteract uncontrolled fat accumulation and metabolic disease; however, the potential to create beige fat cells declines with age. Our application seeks to decipher how aging disrupts beige fat development with the goal to revive beige fat to promote healthy fat tissue and fuel metabolic fitness in aging humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As part of the Integrative Neuroscience Initiative on Alcoholism (INIA) Consortium, this project will focus on epigenetic-related mechanisms involving the neuroimmune system that are affected by excessive ethanol exposure. In collaboration with other INIA investigators, we will use cutting-edge approaches such gene mutagenesis (i.e., CRISPR) and high-throughput sequencing to determine novel molecular mechanisms associated with the development of Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: There is an urgent need to develop interventions that will delay functional disability and improve the quality of life of our growing aging population. This work is expected to lead to a scalable compensation and lifestyle intervention to improve well-being and delay disability in individuals at risk for Alzheimer's disease and other disorders. This research is relevant to public health and NIH's mission as the results are expected to have an important positive impact on caregiver burden, health care costs and the functional independence of our aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  The progressive loss of hair cells, the sensory receptors within the cochlea and vestibular system, results in irreversible deterioration of the auditory and vestibular functions. Our work has established that Hippo signaling serves as a major repressive mechanism preventing supporting cell-mediated hair cell regeneration in the mammalian inner ear. The pathway, therefore, represents a new therapeutic target for induction of hair cell regeneration, and the proposed work is directly relevant to the NIH’s mission to uncover new knowledge that will lead to better health for everyone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This proposal describes a new metabolic imaging technology to image infection, using a mirror-image amino acid that is an essential component of the bacterial cell wall. A new radiotracer developed for positron emission tomography will be used to identify bacteria common in cystic fibrosis patients with the goal of better understanding and treating this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Our goal is to understand how the immune system organizes in tumors and affects their growth and survival. Because the system is so complex, classical methods of microscopy cannot image the full immune response. Here we develop and apply leading-edge tools that merge genomics and imaging to study tumor immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. Mother-infant interactions that are characterized by shared positive affect and mutually responsive behavior facilitate the development of infant emotional self-regulation via co-regulation of infant neural systems. However, growing evidence suggests that this process is disrupted when the mother experiences postpartum depression. The proposed study has the potential to elucidate how postpartum depression impacts infant emotional self-regulation and, further, may help identify a specific mechanism, mother-infant biobehavioral synchrony, that could be targeted in future interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop a novel immunotherapeutic platform for maintenance of remission of high-risk malignancies. Specifically, we will establish a method for thymic generation of naïve CAR T cells, enabling the continuous (but reversible if needed) production of cancer-specific T cells with massive proliferative capacity. We anticipate that our approach will be safe, providing long-lived tumor immunosurveillance to prevent relapse of aggressive lethal malignancies, addressing a particular urgent need in pediatric and young adult patients where additional modalities promoting long-term tumor control could significantly improve survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This longitudinal observational study examines multiple levels of Structural Racism and Discrimination (SRD) including individual (both intrapersonal and interpersonal), neighborhood, institutional, and societal/policy and their associations with mental, physical, and behavioral health outcomes across the life course. Innovative mixed-methods (e.g., ecological momentary assessment, geographic information system data, community- based participatory approaches, biomarkers) are being used at two sites (Minnesota, Georgia), across two time points 18 months apart, with families from racially/ethnically and socioeconomically diverse households (n=927). Study findings will identify targets for intervening at multiple SRD levels to promote health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease is the sixth leading cause of death in the United States with no effective treatment, and the number of patients will triple by 2050. Inhibition of an enzyme called soluble epoxide hydrolase (sEH), which hydrolyzes endogenous largely beneficial epoxy fatty acid to proinflammatory dihydroxy fatty acid, alleviates Alzheimer’s pathological hallmarks and symptoms, like neuroinflammation, tauopathy, amyloidosis and, cognitive dysfunctions suggesting that sEH inhibitor is a rational therapeutic target. This project aims to develop a novel sEH inhibitor with high potency, significantly improved CNS drug-like properties, and CNS exposure to treat Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the major cause of dementia and selectively affects certain brain cell types. However, current single-cell technology limits the ability to study this on a large scale across multiple omics, such as DNA, RNA, and protein. To fill this knowledge gap, we will develop and implement statistical methods that will leverage existing rich tissue-level and limited single-cell omics data, with the goals of increasing our understanding of cellular mechanisms underlying AD and informing future prevention and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We found that hematopoietic stem cells accumulate ascorbate, which regulates stem cell function and suppresses myelopoiesis. We propose to test if ascorbate deficiency promotes the generation of inflammatory myeloid cells in steady state conditions and after plasmodium infection. We will test if increased myelopoiesis caused by ascorbate deficiency is deleterious in plasmodium infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As about a tenth of the population over 70 ages, a clonal population of mutated leukocytes, namely clonal hematopoiesis, arises that is typically benign in nature. Studies from our laboratory has shown that the outgrowth of these clonal populations, is linked to a casual role in the development of heart diseases. In our studies, we hope to fill the gap in knowledge by determining the mechanism behind this causal link in primary human models of clonal hematopoiesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Necrotizing fasciitis (NF) is a consequence of bacterial infection characterized by extensive tissue destruction. NF is considered a medical emergency requiring hospitalization, systemic antibiotics and surgery to remove dead/dying tissues. Mortality of NF is extremely high and new therapies are required. In this study, we test whether changing metabolism in infected tissues provides resistance to tissue damage thereby reducing treatment costs and increasing survival rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mounting evidence links perturbations in early life host-microbiota interactions with increased susceptibility to immune-mediated diseases later in life, yet we lack a mechanistic understanding of how mutually beneficial relationships between gut bacteria and the neonatal immune system are formed. Building from our discovery that maternal antibodies, delivered via breastfeeding, are key regulators of intestinal homeostasis, this proposal seeks to define the cellular and molecular mechanisms by which maternal antibodies restrain aberrant immune responses to gut bacteria in early life. The resulting data will advance our understanding of the immunological processes that regulate nascent host-microbiota interactions, thereby aiding in our ability to manipulate mucosal immune responses in early life to promote long-term health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients initiating hemodialysis for advanced kidney failure enter a period of profound risk for morbidity and mortality, they frequently present with marked hypervolemia, and often experience a rapid decline in urine output and residual renal function. Sacubitril/valsartan, a dual inhibitor of the renin-angiotensin system and the counter- regulatory vasoactive peptide system, is known to reduce signs and symptoms of congestion, and slow decline in renal function in patients with heart failure (compared with RAS inhibitors). Building on these data, our pilot randomized placebo-controlled clinical trial will evaluate the effect of sacubitril/valsartan on echocardiographic measures of hypervolemia, preservation of residual renal function, and key safety parameters in incident hemodialysis patients, and thereby inform the design of a larger multi-center study to evaluate hard clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Malassezia are lipid-dependent yeasts that are part of the normal commensal microbiome on human skin, and they are also associated with several skin diseases and implicated as playing a pathogenic role in Crohn's Disease, pancreatic cancer, and exacerbation of Cystic Fibrosis. In parallel, Candida auris has emerged globally as a human fungal pathogen that is frequently hospital-acquired and drug-resistant; this pathogen initially colonizes the skin and then causes systemic infections that are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. This proposal aims to apply recently developed genomics and genetics resources (combined with models of host-pathogen and microbial interactions) to elucidate molecular mechanisms of Malassezia pathophysiology in dysbiosis of the skin microbiome as a risk factor for Candida auris colonization and infection and provide insights to advance diagnosis, treatment, and prevention approaches and thereby improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  This application seeks to advance statistical methods for high-dimensional multiple disease mapping and boundary detection when the number of diseases and space-time coordinates can be massive. The proposal introduces new graphical process-based models for high-dimensional disease mapping while accounting for spatial misalignment when incorporating multi-source information from climate and other environmental factors, which will enrich epidemiologic analysis of diseases in relation to environmental, climate and socio-demographic factors.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is associated with many clinical and behavioral problems, including severe obesity, however treatment options are limited to managing symptoms, so new approaches are needed since the disease basis is unknown and multiple genes cause PWS. This project will assess an innovative gene therapy approach with a single viral vector carrying multiple PWS genes, testing therapeutic rescue of PWS cell and animal models. Similar miniaturization of genetic components within a single viral gene therapy vector provides a unique capacity that broadens the impact of this novel approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Mutations in genes affecting ciliary proteins, such as PKD2 or IFT88, cause cysts to form in the kidney, the severity of which is greatly exacerbated following renal injury. These data lead to the hypotheses that cilia function to regulate signaling pathways involved in renal repair, that these pathways become dysregulated when cilia function is perturbed, and that this leads to cyst development. The goals of this proposal are to determine whether cilia dysfunction or loss alters the kidney's susceptibility to injury, whether injured epithelium are direct contributors to cysts, and to identify the cilia and PKD2 dependent signaling networks that become dysregulated by cilia loss/dysfunction that cause kidney tubule maladaptive repair following injury and then cyst expansion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE INIA-N investigators have shown that brain immune-related pathways are involved in excessive ethanol consumption and that pharmacological intervention with anti-inflammatory drugs reduces drinking. This project will examine the cellular and synaptic mechanisms of alcohol-induced immune responses in the brain that are hypothesized to contribute to excessive drinking. Therefore, the present studies have the potential to identify new therapeutic targets to reduce excessive drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE: THE UNC-CHAPEL HILL SUPERFUND RESEARCH PROGRAM North Carolina (NC) communities are impacted by inorganic arsenic (iAs) contamination of soil and water resulting from naturally occurring and industry-derived sources. With relevance to the SRP, ATSDR and USEPA, the theme of the UNC-SRP is Identifying novel methods to reduce iAs exposure and elucidating mechanisms underlying iAs-induced metabolic dysfunction with a vision for disease prevention. With relevance to the communities in NC and the US, the UNC-SRP aims to discover biological mechanisms and susceptibility factors underlying iAs-associated metabolic dysfunction/diabetes, develop novel methods and technologies to predict iAs contamination and reduce iAs exposure, and translate the science of the UNC-SRP to key stakeholders in NC and the larger SRP program, and engage vulnerable communities. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through re-use of an existing linked database of national transplant registry data and Medicare claims, this proposal investigates the potential benefits of mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitor therapy with respect to survival, morbidity and Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD) in older kidney and liver transplant recipients. As a secondary objective, the significance of increasing age as a risk factor for mTOR inhibitor side effects is also studied in a large and longitudinal cohort of transplant recipients in the Veterans Health Administration. These findings will help validate the existing experimental evidence on the benefits of mTOR inhibitor therapy on aging-related diseases, support future clinical trials that aim to determine the role of mTOR inhibitors as potential disease-modifying therapies for AD/ADRD and provide key data to establish the safety and feasibility of studying mTOR inhibitors as an anti-aging therapeutic in older persons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative. Dopamine is essential to fear learning and modulates a larger brain network, yet dopamine- focused treatments for anxiety disorders are not available. This proposal will reveal a novel A8 dopamine to ventral pallidum pathway that bidirectionally controls and normally promotes fear. The results will uncover selective inhibition of the A8 dopamine to ventral pallidum pathway as a therapeutic target to effectively treat anxiety disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The immune system senses when a cell is infected or becoming cancerous through display of fragments of microbe- or tumor-associated proteins on the surface of a cell – often the only sign of disease apparent from the outside of a cell. We have developed an improved, streamlined, novel system for identifying these markers, and will use it to identify new therapeutic targets and understand the display process. We will also explore how the immune system from cancer patients responds to the markers we identify.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE: PROJECT 1 Growing evidence suggests that exposure to inorganic arsenic (iAs) increases risk of diabetes, but the underlying molecular mechanisms are poorly understood. This project will use in vivo and in vitro techniques to test the role of microRNAs and transcription factors in iAs-associated diabetes, and also human samples to identify extracellular vesicle microRNAs that serve as biomarkers. Results will advance understanding of diabetes pathophysiology related to iAs exposure and may open up novel therapeutic avenues for future investigation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Ischemic strokes are a major worldwide cause of death and long-term disability in part because of an inability to optimize treatments before ischemic damage becomes permanent. This proposal uses a new noninvasive bedside optical instrument to measure cerebral perfusion changes during endovascular therapy for acute ischemic strokes and monitor functional biomarkers of cerebral tissue health for 24 hours after therapy. Clinical application of this research will enable neurologists to identify complications due to endovascular therapy before injuries manifest in the brain, leading to personalized care and better treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Activation of EGFR and other RTK signaling pathways represents a key aspect of tumorigenesis in a broad range of human cancers, including lung cancer. In recent years, targeted EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapies have been successful in treating lung cancers, but unfortunately the effectiveness of these and other targeted drugs tends to be limited in time, with the almost inevitable appearance of resistant tumors and the resulting dismal 5-year survival rate, with over 130,000 deaths per year.  We propose to develop an alternative approach to suppress EGFR signaling in treatment-refractory lung cancer, which would also be applicable to any other cancer dependent on EGFR signaling. This strategy is based on the rational design of antisense drugs that re-program EGFR gene expression to replace the oncogenic EGFR isoforms with potent inhibitory, naturally existing soluble decoy EGFR variants, both when the EGFR pathway is driven by EGFR-activating mutations, or by wild-type EGFR overexpression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The polymorphic nature of Plasmodium antigen targets of immunity poses major challenges to malaria vaccine development efforts. This study leverages parallel analysis of parasite antigenic variation and variant-specific host antibody responses in a multi-year longitudinal study of a consistent cohort in order to triangulate variant positions and epitopes that contribute to protective immunity. This work will inform rational design of effective multivalent malaria vaccines targeting variants most critical for protection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primate-specific miRNA cluster, C19MC, has roles in trophoblast invasion and migration, but the roles of these miRNAs in primate embryonic development and early placentation remains to be elucidated. Our proposal aims to determine the gene networks controlled by the primate- specific C19MC miRNA cluster in primate placental lineage specification and development utilizing rhesus macaque embryos, primary trophoblasts, and trophoblasts stem cells. Understanding the roles of the C19MC in early placentation may lead to the use of these miRNAs as diagnostic tools in maternal blood, and as therapeutic agents in developing placental therapies in experimental animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE: PROJECT 4 Project 4 focuses on understanding the biogeochemical processes that result in solubilization of inorganic arsenic (iAs) and other oxyanion-forming elements of concern to human health (V, Cr). By coupling traditional field and laboratory geochemical approaches to cutting-edge spectroscopic and modeling techniques, we will develop an improved fundamental understanding of the geochemical factors that result in iAs, V, and Cr solubilization from the molecular to regional scales. The knowledge gained will allow for the development of predictive tools to reduce human exposure and improve management of these common geogenic and anthropogenic contaminants.!

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The structural protein, collagen, is a main component of dentin and plays a major role in the longevity of adhesive-based tooth reparative therapies of dental caries, which is highly prevalent in our population. Building on insights with plant-derived phenolic compounds in the group of tannins and using a bio-inspired modular agent strategy, this project will develop other naturally occurring plant phenols into new classes of dentin biomodulators for future preclinical development. The ultimate goal is to improve oral health by reducing the incidence of failing dental restorations and, thereby, reduce the pain and anxiety associated with dental procedures and reduce health care costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many genetic variants have been associated with psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia, but the biological effects of these variants -- and the mechanisms through which they impart risk for disease -- remain largely unknown. Substantial efforts have recently been undertaken to compile functional genomic data (e.g. genetic variation, gene expression, splicing) across a large number of human brain samples. Here, we develop and apply new techniques to directly integrate these reference brain genomic annotations with psychiatric disease- associated genetic variation to gain new insights into the neurobiological mechanisms associated with these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE: PROJECT 5 Geogenic and anthropogenic contaminants (e.g., inorganic arsenic, manganese, chromium, and vanadium) infiltrate private wells, placing residents at risk for health outcomes (e.g., metabolic disorder/diabetes associated with inorganic arsenic exposure). Project 5 aims to optimize membrane- and sorbent-based treatment technologies to reduce exposure to inorganic arsenic and co-occurring contaminants. To this end, we will develop an integrated membrane-sorbent system and evaluate its performance in North Carolina households served by contaminated groundwaters.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The main objectives of this proposal are to create a coherent analytical framework tailored for integration of available and novel multiomics resources for brains and Alzheimer’s disease (AD), to identify causal variants and genes, and to characterize the genetic profile of AD patients at different molecular levels across brain tissues. By identifying novel causal effects attributable to molecular functions, our result will provide insight for development of therapeutic drugs specifically targeting at cellar process. The multiomics risk profile built for AD patients will improve clinical trial designs for AD drug development, paving the path to personalized therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Despite the proven antidepressant effectiveness of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) for depressive episodes, procedure-related cognitive impairment (memory) prolongs the period of functional impairment (e.g., unable to work) and delays recovery from severe depressive episodes. This project proposes a novel method of individualized and precise ECT dosing with amplitude titration informed by electric field modeling and neuroimaging. The contribution of the proposed research is expected to create consistent and effective dosing at the amplitude “sweet spot” of antidepressant response with cognitive safety for late-life depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE KRAS mutant lung cancer is a leading cause of cancer mortality in the United States, and a lung cancer subtype for which targeted agents, such as MEK inhibitors, have not made significant clinical progress. Based upon the preliminary data from the investigators, we propose: 1) to study the role and reversibility of epithelial- mesenchymal transition (EMT) in KRAS mutant lung cancer to confer resistance to MEK inhibitors, ii) evaluate the effects of MEK inhibitors on the tumor immune microenvironment and the therapeutic vulnerabilities that arise due to immune checkpoint upregulation in pre-clinical models, and iii) characterize the immune-related markers associated with EMT/MAPK activation and investigate the markers of sensitivity/resistance to combination anti-PD-L1 and MEK inhibitor treatment in patient tumor samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This application seeks to study the biological functions and mechanism of action of a newly identified molecule called HIC2 that we found to regulate the transition of the fetal to the adult form of hemoglobin synthesis in red blood cells. Raising fetal hemoglobin in patients with sickle cell disease and some forms of thalassemia improves outcomes and has been an important therapeutic goal in the field for many years. The proposed studies aim to deepen our knowledge of the hemoglobin switching mechanism with ramifications for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Breakthrough SMN- inducing therapies have recently been approved by FDA for the treatment of SMA. However, they do not provide a cure and therapeutic approaches that address unmet needs of SMA patients by enhancing the clinical benefit of SMN- inducing therapies through combinatorial treatment are highly sought after. To address this issue, our project aims to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the initiation and execution of motor neuron degeneration in SMA as well as establish the therapeutic potential of SMN-independent, pharmacological targeting of this pathway for neuroprotection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a complex disease, and innovative treatments that use a biobehavioral framework, such as focusing on time-based energy intake goals (how energy intake is distributed across the day) may enhance initial and longer-term (12-month) weight loss. Time-based dietary goals are believed to promote synchronization of biological and behavioral circadian rhythms, and determining the health benefits of these goals is an objective of NIH’s nutrition strategic plan. This investigation is a randomized controlled trial designed to examine the effect of time-based energy intake goals on longer-term (12-month) weight loss, sleep regularity, and appetite regulation; if enhanced appetite regulation mediates the relationship with weight loss; and if chronotype moderates the effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: There is a great unmet need for human model systems to study biological processes involving complex interactions between diverse tissues within an organ. For example, there are many physiopathological processes related to the human intestine that involve cross-talk between tissue types, such as Hirschsprung’s disease, which is a congenital lack of enteric neurons affecting 1 in 5,000 births, that renders smooth muscle within the gut unable to contract. We present compelling preliminary data for a novel iPSC-derived human intestinal organoid (HIO) model that can co-differentiate as a complex multilineage tissue possessing an epithelium, a mesenchymal/stromal layer that includes organized smooth muscle, endothelial cells and enteric neurons - the first complex HIO model from iPSCs to co-differentiate tissues from all 3 embryonic germ layers in one model system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging of the immune system renders older adults susceptible to cancer, infections, neurodegeneration and cardiovascular disease. To turn aging into a modifiable condition, we need to understand the molecular alterations that lead to immune system aging. This project builds on data showing that T cells from older adults have leaky mitochondria, releasing bacterial motifs that trigger inappropriate tissue inflammation, and will use sophisticated bioassays to develop novel biomarkers and novel treatments to improve age-related disease outcomes in older humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Potentially lethal cardiac channelopathies associated with pathogenic variants in the RYR2-encoded cardiac ryanodine receptor type 2 (RyR2)/calcium release channel (CRC) are the pathogenic basis for a significant portion of autopsy-negative sudden unexplained death in the young (SUDY). Recently, we discovered a novel syndrome, that we have termed calcium release channel deficiency syndrome (CRCDS), in the Amish community that is responsible for highly penetrant, exertion-related sudden cardiac arrest and sudden cardiac death without an overt phenotype to suggest RYR2-mediated catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (CPVT1), but stems from biogenic loss of function in RyR2 secondary to a homozygous duplication in RYR2 that causes a 70% reduction in RYR2 transcript/RyR2 protein levels. The purpose of this study is to determine the contribution of both biogenic- and biophysical-mediated CRCDS in SUDY, to identify genotype/phenotype correlates to assist in clinical diagnosis and management of patients with CRCDS, and to determine the underlying molecular and cellular mechanisms of CRCDS associated with potentially lethal arrhythmias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Radiation therapy (RT) is a pillar of cancer therapy, yet certain group of cancer patients undergoing RT suffer from serious cardiovascular disease. Our research team will study why certain patients suffer from RT-induced heart disease (RIHD) using cardiovascular cells made from patient samples and animal model of RIHD. Ultimately, we seek to develop safe and efficacious drugs to cure RIHD that can improve the efficacy of radiotherapy treatment without concomitant cardiovascular side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal supports the creation of a virtual consortium that will use translational and transdisciplinary disciplinary approaches to provide the research community with an innovative computationally-based method to predict adverse effects of phthalates on ovarian function in women. This work will benefit human reproductive health by enhancing the screening of chemicals that could harm ovarian function in women. The transdisciplinary and translational environment created by this consortium will also provide unique cross- disciplinary training opportunities to trainees in the five institutions involved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Overall Plan: Narrative The goal of this application is to establish the Center for Integrated Biomedical and Rural Health Research (CIB- RHR), a Center of Biomedical Research Excellence (CoBRE), that will enhance research infrastructure in a unique geographical, socio-cultural and economic region of the Rocky Mountain front and adjacent plains. The application is significant as it serves the two primary purposes of increasing the cohort of NIH funded investigators and of advancing our understanding of common health conditions of special concern and/or prevalence in a rural environment. The application is innovative in that the Center will provide unprecedented opportunities for talent recruitment and innovation in a rural underserved region of the United States, will establish the physical and intellectual presence required to increase trust in biomedical research in rural communities, and will serve as a potential model for other rural communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The inappropriate differentiation of smooth muscle cells (SMCs) results in various diseases, including aortic aneurysms. PRDM6 is an epigenetic regulator of SMC differentiation. Its loss causes diverse cardiovascular diseases. We plan to examine how PRDM6 expression is regulated and how it regulates its target genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Microbiome science permeates much of the current thinking in biomedicine, which is demonstrated by the approximately 100 microbiome scientists at Oklahoma State University (OSU) contributing to research efforts to promote microbiome health and target treatments to reverse microbiome dysbiosis. To further advance microbiome research, we must develop a critical mass of new investigators who can compete successfully for independent funding. The goal of the Oklahoma Center for Microbiome Research is to recruit, mentor, and support Research Project Leaders and generally enhance infrastructure by establishing a research core to provide to customized anaerobic microbiology “culturomics” services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address the national need of increasing diversity in our biomedical workforce, the UIC Portal to Biomedical Research Careers PREP (UIC PBRC-PREP) will provide recent underrepresented baccalaureate science degree graduates with an intensive research experience and professional development in the biomedical sciences. This program will prepare these scholars for admission to and success in biomedical PhD or dual degree programs, with the long-term goal that these individuals join the nation’s biomedical workforce as research scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Pediatric AML is a heterogenous group of myeloid neoplasms with over 20 distinct molecular subtypes, many of which are associated with a poor response to chemotherapy, yet the majority of these subtypes lack robust model systems for the identification of therapeutic vulnerabilities. We will develop a series of models of high- risk pediatric AML using both human and murine approaches that capture disease heterogeneity with extensive transcriptomic, epigenomic and proteomic credentialing against our large collection of primary samples, exploiting the unique expertise of each research team in this multi-PI proposal. The successful completion of these studies will nominate new model systems for rare pediatric AML subtypes that can be used by the scientific community to develop new therapeutics or establish mechanistic insights.

PHR: Dysfunction in cell signaling is a fundamental driver of human disease, and our ability to optimize healthy, pain-free aging and find new treatments for neurodegenerative and metabolic diseases requires a broad understanding of the way cells communicate. The Center for Cell Signaling Research will build critical research infrastructure and support the research programs of junior investigators to meet these contemporary clinical challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE DNA genetic material (gene) is converted into RNA molecules that then generate the proteins required for life and these programs need to be well coordinated during development to maintain health. One regulatory mechanism of gene expression is known as “alternative splicing”, which allows individual genes to generate multiple proteins with potential different functions. Our research program will investigate the functions of alternative splicing regulation in the organization of the cytoskeleton, transcription, and local translation and we expect to provide conceptual advances to understand how these functions contribute to normal physiology and how their disruption leads to pathological conditions.

PROJECT_TITLE: When alternative splicing meets cytoskeleton organization, local translation, and transcription regulation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study aims to examine the relationship between multiple forms of discrimination and allostatic load, a condition characterized by the dysregulation of physiological activity across multiple systems in the body. Utilizing data from three large, population-based cohort studies, the study will assess the associations between multiple forms of discrimination (such as neighborhood and interpersonal) with allostatic load; examine the extent to which the "Conserved Transcriptional Response to Adversity" (CTRA) gene expression mediates the relationship between discrimination and allostatic load, as well as evaluate the moderating effect of social integration on these associations. By defining the relationship between multiple forms of discrimination and allostatic load, the study aims to provide a foundation for increasing the efficacy of prevention efforts and treatment to reduce allostatic load and Black-White disparities in allostatic load.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Depression and obesity often co-exist among middle-aged and older adults, disproportionately affecting racial and ethnic minorities, and are associated with greater cardiometabolic disease risk (e.g., diabetes), poorer treatment adherence, and worse quality of life than either condition alone. To address the lack of effective and scalable integrated treatment for these two conditions among racial and ethnic minorities, the current study will test a fully digital behavioral intervention that combines a virtual voice-based coach delivering problem-solving therapy for depression care management and a video-based intervention for lifestyle-based weight loss and increased physical activity among racial and ethnic adults aged 50-74 years. This work aligns with the National Institute on Aging’s strategic priorities to prevent multiple chronic conditions and reduce health disparities through innovative interventions to maintain health, well-being, and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic limb threatening ischemia (CLTI) patients display pathological remodeling of limb muscle that impairs walking performance, angiogenesis, and strength. We propose here to study a novel molecular pathway that links mis-regulated intercellular communication to pathological remodeling in the CLTI limb. Using modern genetic/molecular models and translational studies in already collected patient cells and tissues, these studies will provide important insights into the causes of worsened outcomes in CLTI and may lead to novel therapeutic approaches for these unfortunate patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the high mortality of prostate cancer, molecular mechanisms underlying castration-resistant progression of this disease remain poorly understood. This application is designed to elucidate how mechanistically the components of oncogenic signaling pathways that are often mutated in prostate cancer cooperate to drive prostate cancer progression and how this mechanism of action can be therapeutically targeted. Findings from this application will shed new light on understanding of the molecular mechanisms of prostate cancer progression and lead to identification of new therapeutic targets for treatment of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The long-range goal of the University of Chicago Initiative for Maximizing Student Development (IMSD) is to help diversify the scientific workforce. The IMSD provides research training and educational opportunities for newly admitted PhD graduate students from groups underrepresented in the biomedical and behavioral sciences until completion of the PhD. To assess the success of this endeavor, the participants’ progress is measured by quantitative metrics and skill-acquisition throughout their graduate programs and into subsequent career paths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The DIRECT (Diversifying Interdisciplinary drug and device development Research Expertise through Community building and Training) Program will recruit, prepare, and empower trainees from diverse backgrounds to successfully enter the biomedical workforce in academia, industry, legal, healthcare, government, and other biomedical sectors. The multidisciplinary program proposes rigorous, evidence-based teaching, learning, mentoring and assessment environments, as well as cohort building and career and professional development activities, that will prepare the students to become independent investigators and leaders in the drug and device development fields.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Parkinson disease (PD) is the second most common neurodegenerative disease with approximately 4-10 million people affected worldwide, and result in tremendous economic burden (14.4 billion/year in the United States). Neuroinflammation is a key element in the pathogenesis and progression of PD, yet the lack of specific biomarkers has hindered both targeted therapy and diagnostic imaging options. The success of this application may lead to identification of a neuroinflammation biomarker and facilitate anti-inflammation therapeutics for PD and other neuroinflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The “Clinical Methods for Nutrition and Obesity Research” course will be an annual, 5-day course to train postdoctoral fellows and early career faculty on gold standard and cutting-edge research methodologies for conducting obesity and nutrition related research at Pennington Biomedical Research Center in Baton Rouge, LA. This course will also allow us to train the next generation of scientists from around the country, particularly those from underrepresented groups in the biomedical sciences, and to foster collaborations between Louisiana scientists and others across the country who are interested in researching obesity and nutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal aims to address a key WHO End TB Strategy element, the improvement of diagnostic tools to enable the detection of the millions of missing cases, and has included cohorts from key areas of the world that are heavily affected by TB, as well as special target groups, like a wide age spectrum and people living with the important comorbidities, HIV infection and type 2 diabetes mellitus. A pipeline of novel tests that are suitable for different levels of health care and that target several key phases of host-pathogen interaction will be evaluated and include sputum-free triage and diagnostic tests, improved culture assays, predictive biomarker tests and a bacterial load marker test. The program promises to pave the way for cost-effective, novel and much improved diagnostic strategies for TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Death from chemoresistant germ cell tumors (GCTs) account for the greatest number of life years lost of any non-childhood malignancy, and the origins and evolution to chemoresistance in this disease are incompletely characterized. We have developed data identifying reciprocal loss of heterozygosity (RLOH) as a disease- defining genomic defect in GCTs, presence of apoptotic priming underlying the more typical chemosensitivity, and accumulation of RLOH as GCTs evolve towards chemoresistance. Through the use of several novel molecular techniques applied directly to patient specimens, this proposal will enable this program to develop a more complete understanding of the factors driving oncogenesis and evolution to chemoresistance in this rare cancer, with the plan to translate targets revealed through this study to therapeutic development in this area of unmet medical need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative IMSD at Stony Brook University: Maximizing Excellence in Research for Graduate Education This proposal aims to create a diverse group of highly motivated, exceptionally trained interdisciplinary scholars prepared to pursue research careers in the biomedical sciences. The training program focuses on efforts that build a strong, shared scientific identity amongst underrepresented biomedical science scholars across multiple degree programs, building their confidence and motivation to pursue research careers. These trainees will make novel contributions to the body of scientific knowledge that will lead to discoveries to improve our nation’s health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because there is an unmet need to develop new treatment approaches for patients with hereditary tyrosinemia type I (HT1) and other metabolic liver diseases which are a leading indication for liver transplants and cause significant morbidity and mortality. In this project, we seek to use gene editing, including its prenatal application, to treat HT1 as a model for other genetic metabolic liver diseases. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life and reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epigenetic DNA methylation patterns can serve as biomarkers for the detection of high-grade precancerous cervical lesions; however, few studies have investigated the utility of methylation markers as predictors of progression from low-grade to high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN-1 to CIN-2/3). This study will utilize a unique combination of longitudinal outcomes and methylation array data in a prospective clinical cohort of women to assess relationships between early-stage DNA methylation, high-risk HPV infection, and the progression or persistence of CIN-1. Study findings will help identify novel methylation markers of cervical disease progression, improve the clinical management of low-grade cervical precancer, and contribute to our knowledge of HPV-related carcinogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During the last decade there has been progress in defining the neurocognitive changes associated with breast cancer from pretreatment to post treatment, but little is known about how the neurocognitive changes beyond 1-3 years post treatment. It is possible that cancer related cognitive impairments result from accelerated aging processes, and if so, we need a better understanding of survivors’ neurocognitive changes beyond 3 years. To begin addressing these limitations, we aim to extend our current prospective study (CA172145), which longitudinally examines cognitive function and brain structure/function pre-surgery to 1-year post chemotherapy. In the proposed competing renewal study, we will continue to assess our breast cancer cohort at yearly intervals for 5 additional years providing unique longitudinal data up to 10 years post-chemotherapy. The proposed project will extend our knowledge on very long-term neurocognitive outcomes following breast cancer chemotherapy

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Memory deficits are found with many neurological disorders such as Alzheimer's disease and following stroke; the breakdown of interactions between memory systems can be particularly debilitating. This proposal examines the neural mechanisms underlying interactions between emotional and motor memory systems during associative learning. Elucidating the neural mechanisms underlying memory system interactions is potentially important for developing treatments for memory deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Hepatitis delta virus (HDV) is the most severe form of chronic viral hepatitis. While there are currently no approved therapies for HDV, both interferon- and interferon-λ, and other clinically relevant therapeutics such as nucleic acid polymers, myrcludex B, and a new prenylation inhibitor, lonafarnib, are being investigated as anti-HDV treatments. Using kinetic data from clinical trials and novel humanized mouse models of HDV and hepatitis B virus (HBV) infections, we propose to develop new mathematical models to elucidate the dynamics of HDV-HBV-host infection and treatment response in order to determine how to effectively treat HDV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The human fovea is essential for best vision but understanding the crucial cellular interactions among photoreceptors, neural circuits and supporting non-neural cells in the foveal center is limited because the extremely miniaturized and complex three-dimensional structure and synaptic organization of this region is difficult to untangle with conventional methods. The proposed project will apply new methods of volume electron microscopy (“connectomics”) to reconstruct the human fovea for the first time. Outcomes will have broad significance for retinal neuroscience, clinical image interpretation, and the pathophysiology of macular disease, especially age-related macular degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Colorectal cancer is the second most common cause of cancer deaths in the United States, with 133,000 new cases and 50,000 deaths per year. Thus, novel therapies are urgently needed to treat this deadly disease. The goal of this project is to develop a new personalized approach to treat colorectal cancers. We discovered that colorectal cancers with an abnormality (called a mutation) in a gene called Erbb3 require are sensitive to immunotherpy in mouse models. Here we propose further investigate this exciting finding with a goal to bring it to potential clinical trials to test the concept in colorectal cancer patients in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Gut integrity is markedly worsened following sepsis, the leading cause of death among critically ill patients. Cancer is the most common comorbidity in sepsis, and the presence of malignancy results in significant alterations in both immunity and gut integrity. This program seeks to understand mechanisms through which sepsis alters gut integrity and through which cancer worsens outcomes in order to uncover new potential therapeutic targets to improve outcomes in a disease that is very common and highly lethal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Key aging-related immune system changes (immunosenescence) combined with chronic, low-level inflammation states, termed inflamm-aging, have been increasingly related to neurodegenerative changes, both in the central nervous system and peripherally. The aim of this proposal is to combine advanced statistical methods and a systems biology modeling approach with high-throughput omics markers (blood-based epigenetics and metabolomics) to study immune system aging in neurodegenerative disease (AD and PD) patients relative to community-based controls. And importantly, relate markers of heightened immune states and faster inflamm- aging to longitudinal disease progression, including symptom development and multiple metabolomics measurements over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE The objective of this grant is to study the detailed molecular and cellular mechanisms by which chronic exposure to stimulant and opioid drugs of abuse alters specific types of neurons within the brain's reward circuitry. We focus on changes at the chromatin—or epigenetic—level as mediators of particularly long-lasting effects of drug administration. These studies will provide new information concerning how drugs of abuse cause a state of addiction as well as identify novel leads toward the development of improved diagnostic tests and treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this fellowship is to provide advanced training in resuscitation science research to junior physician-scientists and PhD-scientists. Resuscitation focuses on common yet highly lethal conditions such as cardiac arrest (i.e., heart no longer beating and requiring CPR), shock, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS, difficulty with breathing/oxygenation), therefore impacting the lives of millions of people each year. Our program will address a current shortage of investigators in this critically important discipline by providing high-quality research and career development training for the next generation of resuscitation scientists.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Resuscitation Science
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM(OA)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: There is a significant, unmet need to develop new interventions against systemic fungal infections, which account for ~1.5 million deaths annually. Collaborative studies in the Rivera and Xue labs recently identified a novel, highly immunogenic vaccine strain of Cryptococcus neoformans that showed potent heterologous protection against multiple invasive mycoses. In this application, we will employ this vaccine candidate strain to uncover immune mechanisms of vaccine-induced cross-protection with a focus on pulmonary innate immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE / PROJECT NARRATIVE Remarkable progresses have been made by checkpoint inhibition, metabolic reprogramming, and vaccination to enhance the properties of immune cells for immunotherapy, however, glycan engineering to achieve the same goal is just started to be explored. Given the critical roles of LacNAc, fucose and sialic acid in immune modulation, a deeper understanding of how these glycans are regulated and involved in receptor interaction may aid the development of new therapeutic modalities to treat autoimmune disease and cancer. We expect that such modalities may be combined with currently FDA-approved therapeutic agents, such as anti-PD-1 and anti-CTLA-4 based immune checkpoint inhibitors, to achieve better response rate in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Through this work, I will use an optical reporter assay that I have designed in larval zebrafish to explore the spatiotemporal metabolic gene response to high levels of dietary triglycerides, as well as the regulatory relationship between dietary triglyceride absorption and lipoprotein production/secretion. The optical tools that I develop and the regulatory sequences that I annotate will provide many additional avenues for interrogation of triglyceride metabolic pathway components as they relate to cardiovascular disease, diabetes, obesity, and other metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Using a unique set of human specimens from families with high rates of prostate cancer, we have identified new gene mutations that might explain why prostate cancer risk is heritable. Now, we will test whether these mutations disrupt protein functions, disrupt DNA repair in cell culture, and increase cancer risk in mouse models. These insights will impact the field by increasing the availability of biomarkers for early diagnosis and providing molecular targets for anti-cancer drug development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: It is critical to provide accessible evidence-based psychosocial support to parents and caregivers of children with cancer (PCCC) in order to mitigate individual and family-level psychosocial risks. This effectiveness trial evaluates an eHealth intervention for English- and Spanish-speaking (PCCC) with study endpoints focused on decreasing negative psychosocial sequelae (acute distress, posttraumatic stress, and anxiety) and improving coping abilities (coping self-efficacy, cognitive coping strategies). The long-term goal of this research program is to sustain and disseminate an effective, scalable, high-reach, and cost-effective intervention to provide crucial support to PCCC across the pediatric cancer trajectory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project is aimed at improving the outcomes of trauma patients by developing a deeper understanding of a common and deadly bleeding disorder that arises after serious injury. The investigator will pursue several promising lines of inquiry to characterize in detail the mechanisms underlying platelet dysfunction and microvas- cular blood flow disturbance in this disorder. The project will also provide training for the candidate to develop a unique and advanced skill set and launch an independent research career to continue this work.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project’s goal is to produce knowledge about how the immune system causes two different but related forms of uveitis (inflammation in the eye) that affect people all over the world. Uveitis can cause blindness, low quality of life, and high economic cost. Successful completion of this research may help to develop treatments that can be tailored to specific patients based on genetic testing, with more focused, foreseeable, and powerful effects against uveitis than current forms of treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The over 44 million persons worldwide living with dementia are primarily older adults with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) or related dementias (ADRD). The consequences of physical disability and death from ADRD combined with uncertain clinical benefit of AD treatments motivate the search for targets of preventive intervention. We hypothesize that biomarkers of aging are related to cognitive and physical decline long before dementia and physical disability and are the source of modifiable biological mechanisms; thus, we propose to harmonize data from over 11,000 older adults with measured biomarkers to develop and disseminate statistical methods to identify potential biological aging-related targets of intervention to prevent ADRD and physical disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: We will examine the therapeutic specificity and efficacy of antisense oligonucleotide targeting a neuron-specific protein kinase on suppression of the phosphorylation and accumulation of tau protein, a pathological hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease. This reagent will be administered into animal models of Alzheimer’s disease and human neuronal cells derived from Alzheimer’s and tauopathy patient induced pluripotent stem cells. The successful completion of the study will lead to the development of a novel nucleic acid-based therapeutics by targeting neuron-specific kinase.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative: Tumors release microvesicles called exosomes that reflect the protein content of the tumor itself. We will develop methods using a universal internal standard(UIS) for highly reproducible quantitative analysis of the protein content of exosomes from patient serum during a course of treatment with chemotherapy and radiation therapy. This method will be applied to a set of exosome protein markers from prior work for monitoring changes in protein cargo after treatment via a targeted mass spec-based approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease and the leading cause of dementia in the United States. Unfortunately, there is no cure for AD, and drug discovery for AD has suffered significant failures. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The proposed research is relevant to public health because the characterization of the variable response to opioids is expected to advance our understanding of the mechanisms that underlie opioid overdose through respiratory depression eventually leading to the development of alternative opioid overdose reversal agents as well as through prediction of individuals in whom opioids are contraindicated due to overdose vulnerability. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission to develop fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of human disability and death. This proposal addresses the notice by the Division of Neuroscience and Behavior of NIDA (June 25, 2018) to give high programmatic priority to opioid-related basic research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Relevance to Public Heath Lack of representation of minorities, financially disadvantaged, and disabled individuals in the biomedical research and healthcare workforce has been identified as a critical factor underlying widespread human health disparities. Important to such human health research are comparative studies and investigations using animal models, which are routinely conducted by veterinarians; unfortunately the racial and ethnic diversity in the veterinary profession is no better than that of the biomedical research workforce in general. This research education program is designed to increase the number of undergraduate and veterinary medical students from underserved populations who pursue advanced education and careers in biomedical research in the fields of heart, lung, or blood diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative This study will provide valuable information about the effects of stereotype threat on brain functions and the relation of these stress-related effects to alcohol misuse. This research will build the necessary groundwork for future studies that aim to reduce and prevent alcohol misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal addresses fundamental limitations in current corneal transplant surgery by developing an artificial intelligence guided compact robotic surgical tool that could empower corneal surgeons to achieve difficult surgical objectives, reduce intraoperative complications, and improve clinical outcomes when performing Deep Anterior Lamellar Keratoplasty (DALK). Further, these capabilities are broadly applicable in other microsurgical problems, and the tools will enable further advances both for ophthalmology and for other microsurgical disciplines.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Patients with multiple chronic health conditions (i.e., multimorbidity) and their primary care providers (PCPs) must deal with numerous, often competing health concerns. With many competing health concerns, focusing healthcare on the outcomes patients prefer can help avoid burdensome, unwanted, or harmful care. This project develops an intervention (Vet-Align) to align what Veterans with multimorbidity find meaningful and their preferred health outcomes with the routine clinical care provided by PCPs. This study clarifies Veteran perspectives on how what is meaningful in life affects their health decisions, designs an evidence-informed tool and pathways to guide Veterans and PCPs in making health decisions consistent with Veteran-preferred health outcomes, and tests the intervention’s acceptability and feasibility for patients and staff at two VA primary care clinics. This research promotes a person-centered care approach for Veterans with multimorbidity by aligning care with what matters most to patients, with long-term potential to improve care quality and patient engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to understand the neural mechanisms underlying spatial and nonspatial knowledge. The information gained from this research will be important for developing rehabilitation strategies in people with impaired sight, who often suffer from wayfinding difficulties. Moreover, because the brain regions that support spatial and nonspatial knowledge are involved in several kinds of memory, information about these systems is important for mitigating the memory problems and navigational challenges that occur when these systems are impacted by normal aging, stroke, and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a burgeoning public health crisis that is projected to affect nearly 25% of the global population, and may soon become the leading indication for liver transplantation. The role of S-nitrosylation in this disease is poorly understood. The goal of this study is to probe the role of S-nitrosylation in NAFLD through genetic and pharmacologic modulation of the denitrosylase enzyme AKR1a1 in order to better understand its role in the pathophysiology of this disease and to identify AKR1a1-regulated enzymes as potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dopamine receptor DRD2 antagonist and mitochondrial protease ClpP agonist ONC201 has shown early clinical efficacy in patients with diffuse midline glioma harboring H3K27M mutation (H3K27M-DMG); but we do not know how to improve responses in resistant tumors. In our preliminary data, ONC201 activity is dependent on ClpP activity and resistance correlates with high expression of EGFR and the brain developmental transcription factor FOXG1. The proposed research will determine the impact of EGFR and FOXG1 signaling on H3K27M-DMG bioenergietcs, and the ability of EGFR/FOXG1 modulation to impact ONC201-induced mitochondrial stress in H3K27M-DMG.

PHR: NARRATIVE Overgeneralization of negative memories often precedes and predicts the development of depression and other affective disorders, and is recognized as a major cause of the recurrence and severity of such disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Georgetown University Initiative for Maximizing Student Development (IMSD) will expand the diversity of our PhD student population, build a community of interdisciplinary scholars, facilitate career self-efficacy, and establish a community of practice in inclusive mentorship. We will welcome a yearly cohort of PhD students from underrepresented backgrounds, from across 7 PhD programs on the Georgetown Main and Medical Center campuses, train them in foundational research skills and experimental design, and set them up with faculty mentoring teams. We will provide our students with cross-departmental and cross-sector skills training and professional experiential learning opportunities, and facilitate their growth as near peer mentors. Trainees will transition into their thesis research projects empowered with a sustained network of professional resources and interdisciplinary scientific skills to prepare them for broad careers in the scientific workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Nicotine addiction is responsible for the recent increase in vaping, and also drives tobacco smoking, the major preventable cause of death in the United States. One reason nicotine is addictive is because it makes other rewards feel even better. We will identify new brain mechanisms through which nicotine enhances experience of other rewards, and using molecular techniques, we will determine how these pathways contribute to behaviors related to nicotine addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have recently discovered that human deceased-donor kidney allografts produce fibrinogen in response to cold-storage, which can cause pathologic plugging of microvasculature upon reperfusion via local aggregation of red-blood cells (rouleaux formation). In this grant, we will: 1) Define the mechanisms that drive this fibrinogen stress response during cold-storage; and 2) Develop pre-transplant therapeutic strategies to ameliorate this pathology during ex vivo organ perfusion. All work will be performed using a well-established pipeline for human tissues (transplant-declined human organs and clinical biopsy specimens) to ensure that successful completion of our aims will translate rapidly into reduced mortality for kidney-transplant patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Facioscapulohumeral Muscular Dystrophy (FSHD) is a severely debilitating disease affecting males and females of all ages. The goal of this proposal is to identify factors selectively responsible for pathogenic gene expression leading to FSHD, characterize their roles in vertebrate and muscle development, and validate them as viable therapeutic targets. A specific and practical means of reducing pathogenesis in FSHD is critically needed for an effective therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer's disease is a progressive degenerative disorder with limited treatments. Our hypothesis is that transcranial alternative current electrical stimulation (tACS) can improve Alzheimer's disease progression through improving impaired metabolism. We will apply tACS to a well-characterized mouse Alzheimer's model (CVN-AD) comparing scheduled and dynamic, adaptive or closed-loop approaches to improve metabolism. These experiments will establish the feasibility and parameters to translate into clinical trials of human Alzheimer's disease tACS approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The clinical success of targeting cancer metabolism at curing certain malignancies has increased the growing interest in improving our understanding of how cancer cells rewire metabolism to promote tumorigenesis. The proposed research aims to determine how various cancer cells maintain redox homeostasis to adapt to different nutrient environments and support the elevated biosynthetic demands of uncontrolled proliferation. This research will help uncover novel metabolic vulnerabilities that may lead to the development of more effective and selective cancer treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project develops pre-clinical approaches for repairing ischemia-damaged retina by employing a new class of ‘naïve’ human induced pluripotent stem cells (N-hiPSC) that can be differentiated to transplantable embryonic ‘naïve’ vascular-pericytic progenitors possessing high epigenetic plasticity. Naïve vascular progenitors (N-VP) derived from diabetic donor cell-derived hiPSC display higher functionality and engraftment capacity in the milieu of the ischemic neural retina, compared to primed vascular progenitors (VP) derived from conventional diabetic hiPSC (DhiPSC). Additionally, more effective reprogramming in naïve DhIPSC (N-DhiPSC) ‘erases’ metabolic epigenetic aberrations harbored in diabetic donor cells to produce ‘pristine’ non- diseased differentiated tissues for regenerative medicine of the diabetic retina.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of this IMSD Training Program is to increase diversity of the biomedical research workforce via increasing the number of diverse students who complete PhDs in biomedically-related science fields. For this, we propose to enhance and implement comprehensive intervention programs that have research and education activities for graduate students. We anticipate that our carefully developed enrichment activities will produce students who are well-prepared for their dissertation research, who will increase diversity of our PhD life science recipients, and who will successfully advance to the next step of their biomedical research career.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance As the number of Asian Americans continues to grow faster than any other racial/ethnic population in the U.S., so too will the number of those with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias; yet very little is known about their risks for cognitive impairment and dementia. This proposal will be the first to study an underserved population of Southeast Asians, Vietnamese Americans, at risk for dementia. Understanding the nuanced roles of early life adversity and trauma as well as sociocontextual diversity in a high disparity group has significant implications for understanding risk and resilience factors in all individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of the proposed research is to uncover the role of the primate primary visual cortex (V1) in mediating figure-ground segmentation. We will use multiple experimental techniques to monitor and manipulate neural responses in V1 while animals perform a demanding figure-ground discrimination task with camouflaged targets. These experiments will allow us to test specific hypotheses regarding the way in which V1 interacts with downstream circuits to mediate figure-ground discrimination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We will reveal the proteome dynamics of colorectal cancer cells and tumors at the proteoform level and across various biological conditions. The results will be an unprecedented resource for understanding the colorectal cancer metastasis in a proteoform-specific manner. The data will also help us gain a better understanding of the roles played by mutations and functions of DNA mismatch repair genes in Lynch Syndrome (an inherited form of colorectal cancer) at the proteoform level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ovarian cancer is the deadliest female cancer in the world, and currently there is no effective preoperative diagnostic biomarker. We have demonstrated that the circulating T cells can be used as indicators of cancer status, and plan to prospectively collect an ovarian cancer patient cohort with matched immunogenomics data and to train a machine learning model to obtain a novel TCR-based biomarker. Successful delivery of our Aims will provide a validated, independent ovarian cancer biomarker with improved diagnostic accuracy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Clinical resistance, tumor recurrence and an unacceptable side-effect profile are the major limitations of currently available targeted therapies for patients with basal cell nevus syndrome (BCNS) (also known as Gorlin-Goltz syndrome) as well as in patients with sporadic BCCs that are surgically inoperable or have metastasized. We will test the hypothesis that dysregulation of the epigenetic regulators BRD7 and BRD9 are drivers of BCC resistance by investigating the mechanisms responsible for these effects and test the preclinical utility of pharmacological BRD9 blockade in overcoming vismodegib resistance, potentially reducing the side-effect profile and improving the therapeutic index of pharmacologic inhibitors of Sonic Hedgehog signaling in these tumors.
