IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Rigorous clinical trials are necessary to improve acute treatment for time-sensitive and life-threatening conditions. The unexpected nature of emergency conditions requires special preparation and skill to recruit and protect participants in clinical trials. Emergency care spans multiple locations including ambulances, emergency departments, intensive care units, and even homes. An experienced research team will implement pragmatic and successful strategies to accomplish enrollment under all these conditions and in all these settings at multiple locations as part of a national emergency care research network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiovascular inflammation promotes Heart failure (HF) development, and lung inflammation promotes the transition from left HF to right HF and death. By using experimental studies and a powerful single cell genomic profiling of immune cells after HF, we have identified PD1 (an important target for cancer therapy) and several related genes as potential important targets to regulate cardiac and lung inflammation resolution during HF. We will investigate the role and mechanism of PD1 and these related targets in HF development and HF progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Each year 700,000 people die from hepatocellular carcinoma and nearly all of these deaths are preventable with appropriate screening and treatment. Migrants to the United States have increased risk due to unrecognized viral hepatitis infections but have poorer access to screening and treatment, resulting in disproportionally high rates of cancer and death. This proposal seeks to reduce preventable cancer deaths in migrants by improving our understanding of who should be screened and how they should be treated, this knowledge will have a direct impact on health policy and patient care, helping people to live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Joint bleeding in hemophilia leads to arthropathy and is not fully prevented by standard prophylactic treatments. Joint and muscle bleeding likely cause changes in movement strategies and lower limb biomechanics, which we hypothesize leads to subsequent increased risk of lower extremity bleeding. This proposal seeks to better understand the biomechanics of joint and muscle bleeding, with a goal of quantifying bleeding risk at any given time in future studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The CORE-EM Alliance (Coalition for Research in Emergency Medicine) brings to SIREN six, highly experienced research infrastructures, each with their own spokes, partnering as an innovative, single, super-hub within the SIREN network. The goal of CORE-EM is to provide rapid implementation and high-quality performance in large pragmatic clinical trials to study acute conditions including neurologic, cardiovascular, respiratory, hematologic, infectious disease, and trauma-related emergencies. CORE-EM is committed to conducting rigorous trials, training the next generation of physician scientists, and providing outstanding clinical care to diverse populations of patients through excellence in research, discovery, and implementation science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Using airway epithelial cells from clinically well characterized asthmatic children, we will investigate the regulation of epithelial interferon responses to viral infection and the impacts of excessive or deficient epithelial interferon responses on incident viral triggered asthma exacerbation risk and lung function over time. The studies conducted in my research program, and unique resource of primary airway epithelial cells from clinically well characterized asthmatic children, provide an exceptional training environment for young investigators dedicated to a career in mechanistic patient-oriented research to learn translational research techniques to investigate the role of the airway epithelium in pediatric lung diseases and viral infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE), a recently recognized disease with a rapidly increasing incidence, prevalence, and health care burden, is characterized by the abnormal presence of eosinophils in the esophageal lining, leading to failure to thrive, abdominal pain, vomiting, and heartburn in children, and progressing to esophageal stenosis and food impaction in adults. The goals of this project are to identify early life factors that increase risk for EoE by measuring environmental exposures in deciduous (“baby”) teeth, and to determine the mechanisms by which these early life factors may act. The proposed study will impact patients with EoE not only by increasing the knowledge of EoE disease pathogenesis, but by potentially identifying opportunities for disease prevention which could lead to the development of new treatment options.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our research aims at understanding the development and aging of the eye lens. We believe that such an understanding will lead to an ability to delay of possibly eliminate cataract surgery and its possible complications. Delaying cataract surgery by even a few years or reducing its most common complications could reduce health care costs by a very significant amount.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer (PC) is a highly lethal malignancy with surgical resection as the most effective curative option. Limited sensitivities of pre-operative imaging modalities, inconspicuous lesion/margin detection under white light, and limited efficacy of surgical Laparoscopy to visualize small lesions contribute to incomplete resections, high local recurrence rates, and poor outcomes. We propose to develop and evaluate MUC4-targeted near-infrared fluorescence imaging probes to facilitate fluorescence-guided surgical navigation for improved surgical resection of PC and its pre-malignant precursor lesions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The intestinal microbiome harbors a community of commensal and pathogenic bacteria, yet the mechanisms of pathogen detection by the intestinal epithelium remain poorly understood. Proper detection of pathogens promotes human intestinal health. This proposal will define a new mechanism of pathogen sensing by intestinal cells in a model organism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Our long-term goal is that our UA biomedical sciences Ph.D. students contribute to diversifying the national workforce and become leaders in our institution, in our state and in our nation. Our vision is that our strengths- based guidance and mentoring enable our students to be part of a community of diverse and excellent scholars that mentor and support each other as they move through the steps of their career pathways. This IMSD proposal supports twelve students from groups underrepresented in the biomedical sciences in the first year of their graduate programs, and the IMSD program continues to mentor and guide these students until they complete their PhDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE To advance our understanding of breast cancer on a subcellular level, we will investigate the role of early endosomal function, morphology and mitochondria interaction on the regulation of receptor-mediated signaling pathways and iron homeostasis. Early endosomes act as a literal “fork in the road” for receptors, as both the endocytic recycling and lysosomal pathways are initiated from this dynamic organelle. Early endosomes play a crucial role in the transport of metabolic nutrients, such as iron, as well as in receptor signaling via epithelial growth factor receptor. Significantly, cancer cells exhibit an enhanced dependence on iron for growth and are more susceptible to iron depletion than their normal counterparts. Since cancer cell 3D growth was shown to alter organelle morphology and better mimic in vivo tumor characteristics, the analysis of the morphology and function of organelles and inter-organelle interactions in 3D tumor systems is the new frontier of cancer cell biology. Thus, breast cancer cells grown as 3D tumor systems in vitro will be used to elucidate the complex relationship between signaling and iron metabolism that takes place in the early endosomes, and cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Addiction is a chronically relapsing neurobiological disorder that impacts both men and women but there are sex-specific patterns of drug use and relapse vulnerabilities in clinical and preclinical populations. Recent research suggests that individual differences before drug experience predict addiction vulnerability. To better understand the influence of sex on relapse vulnerability phenotypes, I propose to investigate sex differences in brain circuitry that is critical for sex- and phenotype-specific behavioral flexibility before drug experience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer in the United States and modifiable risk reduction strategies are needed. This study will be the first Mendelian randomization study to investigate the potential causal relation between long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) and risk of colorectal tumors (cancer and adenomas) in Caucasians. The knowledge gained from this study may help to identify prevention strategies for colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a spectacular amount of genetic and phenotypic diversity on Earth, but a clear mapping between genotype and phenotype often remains elusive, inhibiting our understanding of complex traits and diseases. Indeed, phenotypic variation is not sufficiently explained by genetic variation, and genetic variation is itself present in apparent excess. This project aims to test the premise that epigenetic variation is a key causal factor for explaining this abundance of both phenotypic and genetic variation, by empirically assessing how epigenetic variation may explain differences among genetically identical individuals and theoretically how heritable epigenetic variation may influence the maintenance of genetic variation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to characterize a novel biomarker of seizures using advanced computer algorithms that monitor brainwaves in real time. These biomarkers, known as High Frequency Oscillations, have been recognized for some time but their research has been restricted to very short datasets within a handful of centers worldwide. This project will use Big Data tools to help translate these biomarkers into widespread use while exploring several novel ways in which they will help clinicians identify seizures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This study will evaluate the impact of the Common Elements Treatment Approach (CETA), an evidence-based intervention comprised of cognitive-behavioral therapy elements, at improving HIV treatment outcomes among women with HIV who have experienced intimate partner violence (IPV) and have an unsuppressed viral load on HIV treatment. To evaluate CETA, we will conduct a randomized controlled trial of HIV-infected women, with or without their partners, who have experienced IPV and have an unsuppressed viral load to test the effect of CETA in increasing viral suppression and reducing violence. We will also identify mediators and moderators of CETA’s effect on retention and viral suppression and assess the cost and cost-effectiveness of CETA vs. active control at increasing the proportion who are retained and virally suppressed by 12 months.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will examine how early variation in naturalistic emotion processing—how we attend to, interpret, and respond to emotional cues—are linked to risk for depression and anxiety in a large longitudinal sample of infants. Specifically, we will examine how neonatal activation to salient stimuli is linked to how infants attend to naturalistic emotions, and how this association is moderated by infant temperament. This proposal will therefore provide important insight to the etiology of depression and anxiety as well as important training opportunities in infant mental health methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Heart failure (HF) refers to a condition in which the heart is either too weak to maintain a normal output or it does so at cost of high filling pressures causing congestion, as such patients with HF have symptoms related to low output such as fatigue and dizziness or related to congestion such as dyspnea and bloating. HF can be caused by many conditions, and its frequency is increasing becoming the most common heart condition, especially in the elderly, a segment of the population that is growing. Despite the improvement in therapies for HF, the number of patients suffering and dying from HF continues to be unacceptably high, suggesting that the current strategy misses one or more pathophysiologic mechanisms. We propose to explore the mechanism by which systemic inflammation, and Interleukin-1, an apical pro- inflammatory cytokine, in cardiac dysfunction and HF by studying an unconventional signaling not yet explored in the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A stroke is caused by a lack of blood flow to the brain, usually due to the blockage of blood vessels, resulting in damage to the brain tissue. Inflammation, the body's reparative response to tissue damage, can worsen the initial damage to the brain produced by the stroke when blood flow is restored. Therefore, a better understanding of inflammation in the brain after a stroke may improve the effectiveness of anti-inflammatory therapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a progressive vascular disease with high morbidity and mortality. This application aims to elucidate a role of DNA damage during the pathogenesis of PAH and to shed light on novel therapeutic strategies for PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Approximately 80 % of triple negative breast cancers have mutations in the gene for the tumor suppressor p53 (TP53) and these cancers are aggressive and disproportionately affect the African American (AA) community. The proposed work will benefit all women with TNBC which would include the AA over-represented population. We discovered a set of interactions in human Triple Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC) cells between mutant p53 (mtp53), PARP, and MCM proteins which exists as a mtp53-PARP-MCM chromatin axis on replicating DNA. Understanding the mechanisms involved in mtp53 engaging more PARP and MCM proteins on chromatin during DNA damage, and testing for detection of mtp53 and PARP in TNBC, offer opportunities to expand TNBC knowledge. Completing this work will provide mechanistic insights on how mtp53 cross-talks with PARP and MCM proteins on chromatin in cell culture, xenograft models, and patient tissue. These studies will inform the potential of using the mtp53-PARP-MCM chromatin axis as a diagnostic and therapeutic (theranostic) hub, to detect and target nuclear co- expression of the biomarkers mtp53 and PARP. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in the leucine-rich repeat kinase 2 (LRRK2) gene are the most common genetic cause of Parkinson's disease (PD). Current understanding of how LRRK2 mutations cause PD is lacking and will be key to combating this disease therapeutically. Our studies will explore novel mechanisms by which LRRK2 regulates neuronal morphology and how this goes awry with the common LRRK2 G2019S mutation as an important basis for understanding LRRK2-dependent PD and future therapeutic development efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Delirium, an acute disorder of attention and cognition, is a common, life-threatening, and costly condition for older adults with strong links to Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). The goal of the current proposal is to advance foundational research to develop more effective treatments for delirium. This goal will be accomplished by utilizing and expanding a research network, the Network for Investigation of Delirium: Unifying Scientists (NIDUS II), to bring together investigators across disciplines and institutions to conduct essential research to develop safe and effective treatments for delirium, and ultimately to improve outcomes for delirium in all older adults, particularly those with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Small-animal positron emission tomography (PET) is an in vivo molecular imaging technique widely used in preclinical research, however, the performance of currently available small-animal PET systems is far from reaching the theoretical limit in terms of spatial resolution and sensitivity, which limit its application in high resolution and fast dynamic imaging, such as imaging of mouse brain and obtaining image-derived input functions for kinetic modeling. We propose to develop a total-body small-animal PET system with a ~0.5 mm resolution and ~24.5 % sensitivity to enable high-resolution and fast dynamic imaging using mouse models. The improved performance will promote the use of total-body small-animal PET imaging for monitoring biological processes that result in fine structures and expand the range of applications for this powerful, non-invasive and translational imaging modality in preclinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Delirium, a form of acute brain dysfunction defined by acute change, inattention and a fluctuating course, is a devastating entity that is common in older adults and leads to negative patient outcomes. Little is known about the impact of delirium that persists beyond the time of discharge to the home environment on patient outcomes and day-to-day function immediately after discharge home. We will develop and establish the diagnostic accuracy of a telemedicine- based delirium assessment tool that can be utilized to assess for delirium in the home environment and facilitate further research of patients discharged home with active delirium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRITIVE Evidence suggests that the United States has entered a ‘fourth wave’ of mortality in the current opioid epidemic, largely due to increased overdose deaths associated with use of fentanyl (and other synthetic opioids) and co-use of methamphetamine and other psychomotor stimulants. Polysubstance use, which is very common in clinical populations, is understudied in preclinical research, which may contribute to the minimal number of effective treatments for opioid use disorder. Therefore, the proposed studies evaluate the behavioral and neurobiological effects and interactions of co-use of fentanyl and methamphetamine to identify adaptations to the mesolimbic dopamine system that are unique to polysubstance uses.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Severe problem behavior (e.g., self-injurious behavior, aggression) of children with intellectual developmental disorder is prevalent, potentially dangerous, and negatively impacts social integration and quality of life. Function-based, differential reinforcement of alternative behavior interventions reduce such behavior effectively, but treatment relapse is common when a caregiver does not deliver reinforcement for the alternative behavior. This translational project represents an integrated and unique collaboration between basic and clinical researchers to identify innovative theory-driven methods to reduce such treatment relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the success of cancer screening as an impactful cancer control strategy, utilization is suboptimal and disparities in screening rates by race and ethnicity persist, contributing to the disparities in cancer-specific survival. Improving utilization of cancer screening is critical to achieve population-level mortality reduction, but care must be taken to tailor interventions to underserved populations to ensure that existing disparities are narrowed, rather than widened. This research will address a critical gap in our understanding of multilevel drivers of cancer screening rates by incorporating healthcare system-level factors and advancing understanding of patient- and provider-level factors while focusing on racial and ethnic disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Treatment strategies for multiple sclerosis patients that redirect the immune response away from inflammation without leaving patients immunocompromised are urgently desired. In this project, I will design a controlled-release biomaterial drug delivery system composed entirely of immune cues and loaded with an immunosuppressant drug to target the innate and adaptive immune system involved in multiple sclerosis. This plan is expected to provide insight that informs the design of new therapies to treat MS and other autoimmune diseases such as type 1 diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our laboratory takes a multidisciplinary approach spanning biology, physics, engineering, and medicine to develop new tools to answer hematologic questions that are technologically infeasible with current systems. While our basic interests involve developing microtechnologies to investigate the biophysics of hematologic processes at the micro-to-nanoscales, these microdevices can then be adapted to function as novel pre-clinical disease models, clinical diagnostics, and drug discovery platforms. Overall, we adopt a “basement-to-bench-to- bedside” approach in which the invention, translation, and clinical assessment of diagnostic and therapeutic microtechnologies takes place under one scientific “roof” with the ultimate goal of improving the lives of patients with blood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kenya has a high incidence of breast and cervical cancers, and most women are diagnosed with late-stage disease. We will conduct a study to assess the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of strategies to increase the uptake of cancer screening and completion of recommended diagnostic and treatment services. The findings can be used to design optimal approaches and plan investments in infrastructure to scale up implementation of breast and cervical cancer screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There is great interest in defining cancer drug targets that are uniquely expressed in tumor cell lineages, as the pharmacological inhibition of these targets can cause tumor-specific cell death while sparing normal tissues which do not express the target. In this proposal, we describe our recent discovery that an enzyme complex, PI3Kg, is selectively expressed and functional in cells that give rise to a class of cancers known as myeloid leukemias. In the proposed studies, we will evaluate the fundamental role that PI3Kg plays in acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the most lethal of these diseases, while also evaluating whether its inhibition can safely and effectively treat advanced patient-derived and animal models of the disease, thus establishing a foundation for the clinical development of PI3Kg inhibitors as a new class of safe and effective AML therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The use of ponatinib and other tyrosine kinase inhibitors for CML and other cancers are associated with an increased risk for cardiovascular events approaching 30% of patients. We have observed that ponatinib increases thrombosis risk in rodents by increasing vascular inflammation and inducing hyperactive platelets. In our experimental models, ponatinib use is associated with immune cell vascular inflammation. On RNAseq of aorta, we note increased expressed of genes associated with thrombosis. Further, we have observed increased signaling in platelets. The PPAR agonist pioglitazone corrects ponatinib-induced thrombosis risk and thrombosis gene expression and normalizes platelet hyperactivity. Presently we aim to expand the investigations on the mechanisms by which ponatinib increased thrombosis risk and broaden these investigations to all the TKIs used to treat CML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a pressing need to make the bioscience research academic workforce in the US more inclusive. The UC Berkeley PREP program will support and prepare outstanding biomedical scientists who will excel as researchers and role models in an academic setting. Not only will this program allow scholars to acquire the tools needed for successful careers in research and sustained innovation to the benefit of all, but it will also inspire students from underrepresented groups to pursue graduate training and become valuable contributors to the future of biomedicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This training program provides research training and curricular-based training to a pool of talented, highly motivated students recruited into our Trainers’ laboratories, with training focused on cystic fibrosis (CF) to provide a disease-centric but widely applicable learning experience. Students are nurtured in a highly interactive environment; all trainees enroll in a core course, several courses in ethics, several advanced courses, and career development workshops pertinent to their area of research training. In addition to participating in weekly seminar series and journal clubs and presenting their work at joint lab meetings, retreats, an annual graduate program Research in Progress seminar, and annual Dartmouth CF Retreat open to all members of DartCF, Trainees supported by this T32 award are also provided with a series of additional enrichment activities, including attendance at the CF Clinical Conference, seminar speaker invitations, funds for travel to meetings and to attend off-site courses and career workshops, supplemental guidance with Individual Development Plans, the ability to present at the Dartmouth CF Retreat, and leadership and mentored teaching opportunities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative – Overall Diabetes, obesity, and associated complications account for a major share of disease burden and health care costs nationwide. The Michigan Metabolic Phenotyping in Live Models of Obesity and Diabetes Center (MPMOD) will provide standardized, high quality and state-of-the-art in vivo phenotyping services for investigators ̶with focus on underrepresented PIs and small laboratories that have not received significant federal research funding ̶to boost the development of novel therapeutic strategies. The advanced phenotyping services include hyperinsulinemic-euglycemic clamps with tracers, indirect calorimetry with dietary and environmental temperature challenges, ultradian hormone analysis (automated blood sampling from freely- moving undisturbed mice) and behavioral measurements (hedonic and homeostatic feeding, obesity-induced depression, anxiety, etc).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poverty and opioid addiction are interrelated and chronic problems which have not been addressed adequately. This Stage III application seeks to develop and evaluate a Therapeutic Workplace that community treatment programs can implement and that arranges low-cost abstinence-contingent wage supplements to maintain drug abstinence and employment. If low-cost abstinence-contingent wage supplements in the community Therapeutic Workplace maintain drug abstinence and employment and decrease poverty, community drug-abuse treatment clinics could apply this intervention widely as a long-term maintenance treatment for unemployed adults with opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alterations in DNA methylation, particularly within mesenchymal cells, plays a key role in the pathogenesis of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), but a complete analysis of the global methylome and how it varies among different mesenchymal cell populations has not been examined. This proposal will examine the heterogeneity of DNA methylomic patterns within IPF mesenchymal cells, investigate how methylation influences gene expression, and determine how the methylome is regulated by the actions of various methylation machinery. These findings will provide insight into the importance of DNA methylation in IPF and how methylation changes may be targeted for future therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Episodes of altered mental status, from slight confusion to delirium to coma, are a leading complication of acute medical illness in hospitalized patients and are associated with increased risk of death, long-term cognitive impairment, and increased risk of vascular dementia and Alzheimer’s dementia. This study seeks to improve understanding of the mechanisms that govern the brain’s pathologic response (encephalopathy and delirium) to the metabolic derangements during acute medical illness and how those mechanisms influence cognitive impairment and subsequently increased risk for developing early vascular dementia, Alzheimer’s dementia, or other related dementias after acute medical illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite recent progress in medical therapy, current treatments for PH can only improve patients’ symptoms temporarily, and these patients often need lung transplant. This proposal will investigate the role of small intestine and lung in the pathogenesis of PH induced by oxidized lipids. We will delineate novel underlying mechanisms and exploit our mechanistic experimental design to develop new treatments for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the formation of -amyloid plaques and tau neurofibrillary tangles, the latter of which correlates with dementia scores in patients. We will develop a novel class of disease-modifying drugs for the treatment of AD that will ultimately increase tau degradation to prevent tangle formation. We will accomplish this goal using state-of-the-art drug discovery approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Young-onset Alzheimer’s disease occurs in individuals who experience symptoms before the age of 65 and lack a known mutation. Using advanced neuropathology and transcriptomics technology, we seek to investigate why younger individuals suffer more significant accumulation of tau in neurons and more commonly report non-memory symptoms. Our scientific team has combined one of the largest series of young-onset Alzheimer’s disease brains to study, which will be critical for our evaluation of why certain brain regions and specific cells are vulnerable to changes in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This K01 proposal aims to elucidate how caspase-mediated nuclear pore complex trimming enables myogenesis over short time scales but drives muscular dystrophies over longer time scales. The non-apoptotic functions of caspases and the direct role of the nuclear pore complex in muscle biology are examined. More broadly, this project will reveal new nuclear transport-dependent proteins and pathways that are involved in the formation and deterioration of skeletal muscles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative This project will test the efficacy and 12 month follow-up of a family-based therapy that uses specialized exposure to bodily cues compared to family therapy that focuses on taking control of child refeeding. Preliminary data suggests that family therapy with exposure increases autonomous eating and reduced judgmental body evaluation. This study will determine if these changes are the mechanism for treatment changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ovarian cancer recurrence affects more than 50% of ovarian cancer survivors; however, little is known about specific factors contributing to ovarian cancer recurrence risk. The proposed research project will identify recurrence patterns on a population level, and evaluate the associations of patient, clinicopathologic factors, and gene expression signatures with patterns of ovarian cancer recurrence and mortality. Information gleaned from this proposal may improve identification of patients at higher risk for ovarian cancer recurrence, thereby informing clinical decision-making and leading to alternative therapeutic strategies and patient follow-up.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative CHARGE syndrome is a complex of multiple congenital malformations including T cell Immunodeficiency that is caused by thymic hypo/aplasia, and CHD7 is the key gene in the etiology of CHARGE syndrome. Thymic epithelial cells (TECs) that arise from thymic epithelial progenitors (TEPs) and definitive endoderm (DE) are the major component of the thymic microenvironment to support T cell development. The purpose of this project is to determine the ability of CHD7 gene deleted human embryonic stem cells and induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) from CHARGE patients to develop into DE, TEPs and TECs, and the ability of gene correction to enable the CHARGE iPSCs to develop into functional DE, TEPs and TECs to support T cell development from co-transplanted human hematopoietic stem cells in immunodeficient mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Autism spectrum disorder is an early onset, life-long disorder that affects approximately 1% of the population, and is defined by fundamental impairments in social communication and restricted or repetitive behavior or interests. This work focuses on understanding how dysfunctions in two autism-linked genes ANK2 and SCN2A affect neuronal function. This project will shed light on the cellular and molecular mechanisms that contribute to the disorder, and potentially identify new avenues for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients often suffer from permanent neurological deficits due to secondary degeneration of axons after spinal cord injury and there are no effective therapies to treat these problems. The molecular mechanisms that cause secondary “bystander” axonal loss following spinal cord injury remain poorly understood; however, growing scientific evidence suggests a key role of calcium overload and neuroinflammation in this process. We will explore the role of aberrant store-operated calcium entry (SOCE) as mediating direct secondary “bystander” degeneration and indirectly by targeting SOCE in microglia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: We live in an uncertain world in which events are often unpredictable, and so being able to appropriately modify our decision making relative to our own uncertainty regarding future rewards is crucial for survival. Malfunctions of behavior and emotion in uncertain contexts are associated with psychiatric disorders and maladaptive behavioral states, such as anxiety, risk-seeking, and drug-addiction, but to date the neuronal mechanisms of uncertainty-related behaviors, such as risk seeking, are poorly understood. We will assess the mechanisms of risky decision making and study how neuronal circuits give rise to risk seeking or avoidance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In normal physiology, the repertoire of human T cells includes a 10% subpopulation that expresses two, rather than a single, T cell receptor (TCR), determining the antigenic reactivity of the cell. Despite the obvious implications for potentially unwanted heterologous reactivity, dual TCR T cells are largely unstudied, though we recently proposed the novel paradigm and provided evidence demonstrating that dual TCR expression is important in thymopoiesis and that dual TCR cells have exceptional ability to recognize ligands driving alloreactivity and autoreactivity. Research proposed in this application examines dual TCR T cells in mouse models and human transplant patients to define the mechanistic basis for the atypical thymic selection and antigen recognition properties of these cells with the goal of revealing important aspects of T cell biology relevant to transplantation and potentially identifying novel targets for development of innovative therapeutics to improve clinical transplant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will identify and characterize new epigenetic drug therapies for Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). This proposal will also advance our understanding of the roles of epigenetic gene regulation in DMD. The proposed research is relevant to public health because this study will take advantage of three model systems, zebrafish, human cell lines, and rats, to advance potential new treatment options for DMD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed prospective, four-parallel-arm, randomized controlled trial tests two theoretically driven strategies to improve weight and dietary outcomes in women and men with overweight or obesity who are attempting to lose weight: an environmental control strategy and an impulse control training strategy. This research addresses the oft-debated question of how to best optimize behavior change, and whether one should attempt to resist temptation in consistently inhibiting impulses or avoid temptation altogether in eliminating unhealthy options from the home environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cancer occurs when cells acquire changes that convert them from a normal to malignant state. Apoptosis is a program of cellular suicide that eliminates damaged cells to prevent cancer; yet the body also turns on this program following chemotherapy and radiation treatments in order to kill cancer cells. Therefore, it is important to investigate the pathways that control apoptosis to understand how cancer occurs and should be treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is the most common, life-shortening genetic disease, affecting approximately 30,000 persons in the U.S. and 100,000 persons worldwide. Defective bicarbonate secretion in CF contributes to the morbidity and mortality associated with this disease. My aim is to establish patient derived 3-dimensional duodenal enteroids which recapitulate native CF duodenal tissue’s bicarbonate secretory properties and identify new ways to circumvent defective bicarbonate secretion in CF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Center for Metabolic Phenotyping of Mouse Models of Obesity and Diabetes (MPMOD) at UC Davis will serve a primary role in providing unique, complex, and hard-to find tests and procedures for phenotyping live mouse models submitted by investgators from the biomedical research community. The MPMOD Center at UC Davis will also provide expertise, consultation, and advice to researchers on project planning, test selection, and outcomes measures. Further, the Center has proposed a partnership with Hispanic Serving Institutions as a component of the MPMOD Vibrant Program to enable underrepresented PIs and those from small research institutions that traditionally have not received significant research funding and/or have historically served under-represented populations to produce outstanding results and better compete for funding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE The overarching goal of our continued program of research is to find a safe and effective medication to prevent or treat retinal neurodegeneration that leads to diminished vision or even blindness. This application for renewal addresses whether the estrogen-deprived male and female retinas are especially vulnerable to neurodegeneration, and our topically applied prodrug restricting estrogen’s action to the target site could be a preventative and/or curative pharmacological intervention. Ocular neuroprotection is a pressing unmet medical need, as irreversible retinal neurodegeneration is a fundamental pathological feature of several blinding eye diseases such as glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The overall goal of this application is to study lung and peripheral blood immune cells and lipids in asthma patients to identify mechanisms that induce a corticosteroid-refractory inflammatory phenotype that can be targeted to block chronic disease and improve response to therapy thereby preventing stress-induced premature senescence, a phenomenon increasingly being associated with other chronic lung diseases such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment (TME) represents a substantial barrier for effective Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR)-T cell therapies targeting solid tumors. This research plan describes the development of transformative technologies to elucidate, engineer, and rewire the signaling pathways in CAR-T cells to overcome TME-associated immunosuppressive signals.

PHR: The National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) is providing funds to establish the coordinating unit (CU) for the National Centers for Metabolic Phenotyping in Live Models of Obesity and Diabetes (MPMOD) program. The CU will coordinate the interactions of the MPMOD Phenotyping Centers, provide financial management for the MPMOD Vibrant Program, interact with the Executive Steering Committee and External Scientific Panel as well as provide a national web portal for MPMOD in order to disseminate information and provide an organizational infrastructure for the program. This application will provide the infrastructure for the CU for MPMOD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Discovery of the genetic factors involved in brain communication and brain connectivity that contribute to PTSD may prove vital to new treatment breakthroughs. The coupling of brain connectivity with its genetic architecture, mapping the neurogenetic pathways of PTSD, and new knowledge of neural and genetic mechanisms will support precision-medicine guided drug discovery for managing mental illnesses that follow psychological trauma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Genetic mutations do not fully explain metastatic behavior. We are studying the contribution of the non-coding genome – and particularly of a novel RNA species, circular RNA (circRNA) – to melanoma metastasis. The objectives of this proposal are to genetically demonstrate CDR1as’ metastasis suppressive role and to dissect the biological effects and downstream mediators of CDR1as loss in melanoma progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Clonal hematopoiesis, a condition where stem cells of the blood acquire mutations and experience increased rates of division, is a relatively common phenomenon, with an incidence of over 10% in patients over the age of 65. Importantly, while patients with clonal hematopoiesis do not experience any symptoms as a result of these mutations, they are at significantly increased risk for developing blood cancers and cardiovascular disease. Using genetic analysis that permits identification of these mutations in single cells, and therefore resolving the admixture of wild type and mutant cells within a sample, this project aims to uncover the processes by which clonal hematopoiesis develops into more serious disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Our group as discovered that focused ultrasound stimulation targeted to sensory neurons located at the hepatic portal vein and other sites within the GI tract has the capacity to restore glucose homeostasis in pre- clinical models of type 2 diabetes. Under this proposal we are using hyperinsulinemic-euglycemic clamps, oral glucose tolerance testing and stable isotope NMR imaging methods to characterize the effect of focused ultra- sound treatments targeted towards different afferent sensory fields on insulin sensitivity and hepatic glycogen storage; thereby contributing to normalization of glucose levels in recently diagnosed type 2 diabetic subjects. If confirmed our studies will help establish neuromodulation via focused ultrasound not only as a new tool to interrogate regulation of human glucose homeostasis, but also as a potential non-pharmacologic treatment modality for diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE Cerebral blood flow (CBF) measures cerebrovascular health and regional brain function and has broad range of applications in both neuroscience and clinical care. In this Academic Industrial Partnership, neuroimaging investigators from the University of Pennsylvania and the University of Maryland will partner with investigators from Siemens Medical Solutions, USA to develop and disseminate a robust MRI technology that can noninvasively quantify CBF. The methodology is also applicable to studying brain tumors and other organs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We want to study the role of adhesion GPCR ADGRB3 as a tumor suppressor in the formation of medulloblastoma, a malignant brain tumor in children. We found that ADGRB3 gene is silenced in the WNT subgroup of medulloblastoma and that reactivation of its expression by epigenetic means has therapeutic benefits. The knowledge derived from these studies may lead to the development of novel epigenetic therapies for brain cancer through the restoration of the ADGRB3 tumor suppressor pathway function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this R01 project is to understand how nutrient signals, such as arginine, regulate the pancreatic islet alpha cell. We will define the molecular mechanism by which arginine is transported and sensed in alpha cells and how this stimulates glucagon secretion and α cell proliferation. Successful completion of this award will identify new targets for the dysregulated glucagon secretion observed in individuals with diabetes that exacerbates hyperglycemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a dreadful common disease. We will determine the potential contribution of bacteria in the gut to AD and the cognitive decline in the patients with AD and their spouses, and the usefulness of indices in the blood to predict cognitive decline. Thus, the findings from this project may ultimately help the care for patients with AD and the health of their spouses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Urinary urgency incontinence is a major public health concern affecting over 40 million people, primarily women, in the United States alone. Our understanding of how and why urgency incontinence develops is incomplete which prevents efficient diagnosis and treatment. The results of this study will not only fill a significant knowledge gap in understanding the etiology of UUI, but will provide a potential method of differentiating phenotypes of UUI and potential targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Evidence suggests that activators of specific muscarinic acetylcholine receptor (mAChR) subtypes in the brain have exciting potential as novel treatments for positive symptoms, negative symptoms, and cognitive disturbances in patients suffering from schizophrenia. We propose a series of studies aimed at developing a better understanding of the roles of specific mAChR subtypes in brain circuits that may underlie their ability to improve symptoms in schizophrenia patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because mobility is a key driver of the HIV/AIDS epidemic and mobile fishermen and their partners along Lake Victoria in Kenya are an exemplar mobile population who are at exceptionally high risk for HIV. Insights from this research will provide a comprehensive understanding of male engagement and relationship-level barriers and facilitators affecting safer conception uptake in the context of mobility and help high-risk HIV-affected couples to safely have children, affirm reproductive rights, and ultimately limit HIV transmission risks. This project is relevant to NIMH’s research priorities to advance the understanding of how human mobility affects engagement with HIV prevention and to develop prevention strategies to address these challenges for mobile populations who are at high risk of HIV transmission, acquisition, and care disengagement.

PHR: Project Narrative RNA-binding proteins (RBPs) and ribosomes are key molecules that drive and regulate post- transcriptional gene expression. RBPs are implicated in many different diseases including cancer and brain and neurodegenerative diseases (Fragile X syndrome, ALS). Ribosome-based genetic tools such as Ribo-TRIBE, Ribo-STAMP and Nanobody-editing will enable different areas of biology and medicine to address gene expression regulation within very small numbers of specific cells or neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed project is aimed at determining the conditions under which feedback-based learning can be improved in children with developmental language disorder (DLD). Aim 1 will determine whether manipulating the timing of the feedback improves learning in children with DLD and aim 2 will compare learning under two feedback conditions, one that promotes active and intentional self-correction which is in line with declarative learning, and one that passively exposes the learner to corrective feedback and leads to learning that is assumed to be implicit in nature. For both aims, behavioral indicators of response to feedback will be complemented by electrophysiological measures of feedback processing that capture the involvement of implicit and declarative brain systems in the learning process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently, there are no FDA-approved drugs that can counteract GI acute radiation syndrome characterized by microbiome dysbiosis, destruction of mucosal layer, intestinal epithelial barrier dysfunction, and severe inflammation that can lead to rapid death. MIIST305 is a novel GI-targeted therapeutic that greatly enhances survival in mice exposed to lethal radiation and protects the GI tract from injury by maintaining a balanced gut microbiota and effectively reducing proinflammatory responses. Further development of this drug as an FDA- approved medical countermeasure will be of critical importance in the event of a radiation public health emergency.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Three in ten Americans have prediabetes – high blood sugar that could lead to type 2 diabetes. There are few effective ways to prevent prediabetes from developing into type 2 diabetes, but new research suggests that insomnia can increase people’s blood sugar, making type 2 diabetes more likely. In the proposed study, we will test whether therapy to treat insomnia can also lower blood sugar in people who have both insomnia and prediabetes, potentially preventing them from developing type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose novel, domain-independent, reusable methods for generalizing inferences from a cluster trial to a target population of substantive interest, by addressing bias due to selective trial participation. Specifically, we propose to develop and evaluate methods for (1) generalizing inferences about average treatment effects that account for dependence within clusters, small number of clusters, and small cluster sample sizes, and allow estimation using modern machine learning methods; (2) identifying the optimal covariate-dependent treatment strategy in the target population among a (possibly restricted) class of strategies; and (3) handling missing outcome data when generalizing inferences from cluster trials to the target population. Our proposal is motivated by 3 large-scale cluster trials of influenza vaccination strategies in U.S. nursing homes nested in nationally representative data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE MR-LINAC is the ideal platform for online adaptive radiotherapy and will bring cancer radiotherapy to a new level of precision and personalization. However, this new format of radiotherapy also comes with new challenges for patient safety and plan quality check that cannot be satisfactorily addressed with traditional quality assurance (QA) tools. This project is to address the urgent unmet clinical needs by developing the first intelligent, efficient, reliable, and independent QA system, to facilitate unleashing the full potential of MR- LINAC online adaptive radiotherapy to advance cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fundamental advances in our understanding of the normal function of the human brain, and how this understanding can be used to combat brain disorders, will increasingly depend on researchers equipped with multidisciplinary technical expertise. Major advances in the use of the light microscope to probe brain function have been made in the past three decades, and the technologies continue to improve and advance at a rapid rate. This grant supports an advanced hands-on summer course focused on using light microscopy approaches in the nervous system. The course communicates cutting- edge experimental approaches and concepts to a select cadre of postgraduate trainees, who will immediately apply what they learn to their own areas of neurobiological research. This highly intensive course provides a forum for in-depth evaluation of the emerging and converging light microscopy techniques to probe human brain function and disease, and helps to embed the trainees in a collaborative network of like-minded scientists who are working to understand brain function and the etiology of mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Glaucoma is the leading age-related cause of irreversible blindness worldwide and will afflict an estimated 112 million people by 2040. The disease causes retinal and optic nerve degeneration through sensitivity to ocular pressure, but lowering pressure does not always stop progression. The work proposed here will test how adaptive mechanisms in the retina and optic nerve could slow degeneration and preserve vision in glaucoma by distributing energy resources where needed to enhance signaling from the retina to the brain.

PHR: Project Narrative Focused ultrasound (FUS) neuromodulation will be combined with real-time MRI guidance and fMRI feedback to develop acoustic technologies (hardware, software, and activatable particles) for focal pharmacological neuromodulation of the monkey sensorimotor system. Safety will be monitored longitudinally and post-mortem. The proposed developments will improve the spatial capabilities of FUS neuromodulation, expand its use to focal pharmacological modulation, and provide key data to translate this technology to humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methylation of cytosine in CpG dinucleotides plays a critical role in gene organismal development, and its deregulation is commonly observed in cancer. This application will focus on the epigenetic mechanisms of regulation of the de novo DNA methyltransferase DNMT3A by post-translational modifications of histones. These novel insights will provide an enhanced understanding of DNMT3A, reveal the role of histone modifications in regulating its recruitment, activity, and function, and lay the foundation for developing novel inhibitors that could be used for cancer therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) is currently the 8th leading cause of cancer death in the United States and is unusual for its high frequency of epigenome regulator gene mutations, including a gene called SETD2 that when mutated, is associated with reduced survival and metastasis. Identification of genes that act as redundant backups to known cancer mutations is a proven approach to identifying new therapeutic drug targets. Using this approach, called “synthetic lethality” we identified novel and druggable pathways that we expect to lead to a better understanding of how SETD2 loss drives ccRCC and new ways to therapeutically target tumors with this mutation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  A significant workforce shortage is looming for cancer-focused careers, underscoring a critical need to recruit and train the next generation of providers and researchers. To inspire and prepare undergraduates to pursue careers in cancer research and/or healthcare delivery, a Fox Chase Cancer Center (FCCC)-University of Delaware (UD) intensive, summer internship program is proposed. Key elements of this program include a one- week preparatory course, taught at UD, focused on lab skills, research ethics, and basic information about cancer biology, followed by a 10-week residential program at Fox Chase which integrates a laboratory internship with professional skill development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: Alzheimer’s Disease is a devastating neurodegenerative disease, the most common cause of dementia, and a significant healthcare burden worldwide, with many complex genetic and environmental drivers that remain uncharacterized. Pathogenic infections have been proposed as a potential risk factor for Alzheimer's, by triggering an immune response utilizing Amyloid beta as antimicrobial peptides, which protect against infections in the short term, but ultimately cause excessive Aβ deposition and the pathological cascades that ultimately lead to dementia, a link particularly relevant given the Covid-19 pandemic. Here, we dissect the potential mechanistic basis of such pathogen-Alzheimer's interactions using cutting-edge experimental and computational methods, and focusing on HSV-1 and CMV infections as a model for Alzheimer's-pathogen interactions in hopes for this to provide a foundation for both a deeper understanding of how pathogens impact Alzheimer's and the development of new therapeutics against this devastating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Squamous cell carcinoma is a major cause of mortality, but despite breakthroughs in genetics, little is known about the role of post-translational modifications, including the most abundant PTM protein glycosylation. In this proposal, I will use murine skin as a highly tractable model system to investigate SCC glycosylation. By discovering how carbohydrates change in SCC and the downstream consequences, my work has the potential to dramatically improve our understanding of SCC and identify new therapeutic opportunities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE  To address reproducibility and power issues in aging and Alzheimer’s disease research, we launch ENIGMA’s World Aging Center, a global brain study of aging and AD across 45 countries. Leveraging our ENIGMA network (340 institutions), we launch 4 coordinated projects to empower genetic and epigenetic studies of brain aging: (1) Enigma-Lifespan- creates normative charts of brain aging metrics from MRI, diffusion imaging, and functional MRI in 20,000 people worldwide; (2) ENIGMA-Epigenetics- relates genome-wide methylation to brain aging; (3) ENIGMA-Plasticity- seeking genetic loci affecting brain atrophy rates; and (4) ENIGMA-Alzheimer’s- to identify how Alzheimer’s genetic risk and new risk scores for accelerated tissue loss, affect the brain. We will analyze worldwide imaging, epigenetic, and clinical data with harmonized methods, to create new aging “clocks” and reveal targetable risk factors and modifiers of brain aging in the genome and blood, worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are no effective treatments for perianal fistula (PAF), which occurs in up to 40% of Crohn’s disease pa- tients. This proposed study aims to develop a biostimulatory nanofiber-hydrogel composite plug to promote tissue healing and test its efficacy to repair PAF in rodent and swine models in conjunction with adipose-de- rived stem cells (ADSCs) or ADSC-derived exosomes. If successful, this study will offer a translatable off-the- shelf biomimetic NHC microporous plugs for PAF repair and tissue healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria is one of the world’s most devastating infectious diseases, causing greater than 400,000 deaths per year and primarily impacting young children living in sub-tropical and tropical regions. Key to the virulence of the deadliest malaria parasite, Plasmodium falciparum, is its ability to evade the human immune system. This proposal seeks to understand the mechanisms by which this parasite can escape our natural immune responses and will aid in the developments of new approaches to reduce the impact that this disease has on the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Elderly surgical patients are at extremely high risk for cognitive and functional decline after hospitalization, but individual interventions to reduce this decline (e.g., anesthesia/sedation strategies, mobilization, rehabilitation) have exhibited limited success. An extensive program combining physical and cognitive training prior to, during, and after hospitalization has not yet been evaluated. The COPE-iOS study will examine whether a comprehensive program of computerized cognitive training, guided progressive physical exercise, and health education performed throughout the entire perioperative period will improve long-term cognitive and disability outcomes in elderly surgical patients at high risk for decline.

PHR: The Vanderbilt Center for Metabolic Phenotyping in Live Models of Obesity and Diabetes (VMPMOD) advances knowledge of diabetes, obesity, and related disorders by providing state-of-the-art phenotyping services to the scientific community. Access to the services of the VMPMOD broadens the scope, expedites the completion, improves the quality, and reduces the overall costs of research for investigators nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: RELEVANCE Alcohol use disorder is a major health concern that exacts significant social and economic burden on the United States, and stress significantly contributes to this problem. This research project aims to enhance our understanding about brain mechanisms and circuits that underlie the ability of stress to further increase alcohol drinking, trigger relapse, and exacerbate impaired ability to engage behavioral flexibility that would serve to dampen stress-alcohol interactions. The overall goal is to use this knowledge to facilitate development of new and more effective interventions for treating stress-related excessive alcohol drinking, and alcohol use disorder in general.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Based on our preliminary data, activation of oncogenic Kras in the pancreas leads to expansion and reprogramming of myeloid cells that in turn promote carcinogenesis. Conversely, upon inactivation of oncogenic Kras, the pancreas undergoes tissue repair, a process that is accompanied by and requires myeloid cells as well. The major goals of this project are to longitudinally characterize myeloid cell evolution during pancreatic carcinogenesis in mice and human patients and dissect mechanisms of myeloid cell-driven carcinogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite recommendations for annual HIV screening among adolescents, testing rates among adolescent sexual minority males, transgender girls, and gender diverse teens (ASMM/TGD) are extremely low, and interventions specifically aimed at increasing adolescent testing rates are scarce. This proposal aims to test the effectiveness of a text message-based intervention on HIV testing behaviors and investigate factors that may facilitate widespread implementation of such programs among ASMM/TGD. Ultimately, increased HIV testing in this group will mitigate transmission rates and improve the HIV prevention and care continua in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type-2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) is associated with faster cognitive decline in aging and a higher risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease. The objective of this project is to aid public health by identifying markers of the brain changes in T2DM that are associated with cognitive impairment with the hope that these markers could be used to develop new clinical treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Burns are a common type of trauma that affects approximately 2 million Americans each year. A major cause of mortality in patients with major burns is injured tissue releasing cell death products into the blood to cause small blood vessel leakage. This project investigates the role and mechanisms of increased plasma histones as major cell death products that disrupt blood vessel integrity, with the goal to identify new therapeutics for treating burns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lupus nephritis (LN) is a severe complication of lupus that can lead to kidney failure but for which current treatments are toxic and insufficiently effective. The goal of this proposal is to improve our understanding of what causes damage to the kidneys by studying a particular group of highly dynamic immune cells (myeloid cells) that are associated with poor outcome when they are found in kidney biopsy tissue of patients with LN. Myeloid cells can cause inflammation but can also help with tissue repair. Using new technologies that allow analysis of single cells we will construct an “atlas” of these cells in human and mouse LN, study their function in mouse LN models and determine what factors control their differentiation with the long-term goal of finding ways to target the harmful myeloid cells while retaining those that mediate protective functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE STATEMENT Mitochondria are tiny engines that generate the chemical power that cells use to grow and function. This project aims to understand how an enzyme known as PDK4 helps mitochondria to maintain high rates of energy production in during normal stresses, such as food restriction and exercise. These studies will delineate the precise role of PDK4 in regulating fuel selection and use in tissues such as muscle and heart. The results could provide new approaches to treating metabolic disorders such as diabetes and heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will seek to study the pathophysiology of chronic pancreatitis mediated by misfolded pancreatic triglyceride lipase mutants. We hope to fill the important knowledge gaps with respect to mechanisms driving chronic pancreatitis. Completion of the project will establish mutation-induced misfolding of pancreatic enzymes as a relevant disease mechanism in the pathogenesis of chronic pancreatitis and identify potential therapeutic targets to prevent or slow chronic pancreatitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Cancer is a common disorder; at some point during their lifetimes, one out of every three Americans will be diagnosed with cancer. Nearly 80% of cancer patients will experience either insomnia symptoms or insomnia disorder during chemotherapy. Insomnia is associated with numerous adverse health outcomes; it affects quality of life, contributes to fatigue, and may influence response to cancer treatments and survival. The proposed study will improve our understanding of insomnia pathophysiology and management in a clinical oncology community clinic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance Statement  Pathologic dysregulation of the coagulation system is a major contributor to human morbidity and mortality, resulting in either excessive bleeding or clotting. While major improvements to human health have been made through advances in genetic technology and recombinant protein engineering, there are still a number of limitations to current diagnostics and therapeutics. The proposed studies will identify potential new diagnostics, therapies, and therapeutic targets, which will result in broadened treatment options for a diverse array of affected patients, enabling clinicians to tailor therapy to individuals with both hemostatic and thrombotic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Adoptive cell transfer T cell immunotherapy has immense potential for treatment in several diseases, including cancer. Non-invasive quantitative imaging would be a powerful tool for evaluation of the impact of T cell modifi- cations and delivery routes, monitoring of off-target T cell accumulation, and stratification of groups of responders or non-responders to therapy on the basis of measures of T cell tumor accumulation. This project will pioneer non-invasive and quantitative tracking of adoptive T cell cancer immunotherapy using a new molecular imaging modality called magnetic particle imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The FDA has launched numerous initiatives to improve trial design and enrollment practices; however, there are significant gaps between the need to improve Alzheimer’s disease (AD) trial eligibility criteria design and ways available to fulfill the need in practice. We propose (1) novel causal-principled, explainable AI (XAI) approaches to generate real-world evidence using large collections of real-world data to facilitate AD trial eligibility criteria design, and (2) to create the web-based ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE ELIGIBILITY EXPLAINER (ADEP) tool. We will leverage two large RWD resources, the OneFlorida+ (~19 million patients from Florida, Georgia, and Alabama) and INSIGHT (~12 million New Yorkers) clinical research networks (CRNs) contributing to the national Patient- Centered Clinical Research Network (PCORnet).

PHR: NARRATIVE We propose a large, multi-state epidemiological study to assess whether select social determinants of health – as reported on patient records through the use of ICD-10 Z-codes – modify associations between outdoor temperature and visits to hospital emergency departments. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although many human cancers share similar metabolic alterations, including the Warburg effect, it remains unclear whether oncogene-specific metabolic alterations are required for tumor development. We found that phospholipase A2G7 (PLA2G7) is selectively important in Nras Q61K/R mutants in melanoma cells, which is a secreted enzyme that catalyzes the degradation of phospholipid platelet activating factor (PAF) and production of a biologically inactive phospholipid product Lyso-PAF to regulate PAF-induced inflammation. We hypothesize that “functionless” Lyso-PAF has an intracellular and signaling role that is selectively important for mutant Nras transformation by contributing to PAK2-dependent S338 phosphorylation of Raf-1, and thus PLA2G7 represents an alternative therapeutic target to selectively treat melanoma cells expressing mutant Nras.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Interactions with complex objects such as carrying a cup filled with coffee are ubiquitous in daily life and essential for maintaining independence. Dexterous handling of objects is challenging as they create complex interaction forces that humans need to predict, preempt, and compensate for. Implementing the task of “carrying a cup of coffee” in virtual and real environments, we examine both healthy and neurologically impaired individuals to test the hypothesis that humans achieve dexterity by simplifying these interactions, i.e., by making them predictable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Limited mobility due to conditions like osteoarthritis, cerebral palsy, and Parkinson’s affects millions of individuals, at a great cost to public health and personal well-being. Rehabilitation can dramatically improve mobility and function, but current rehabilitation practice requires in- person guidance by a skilled clinician, increasing expense and limiting access. This project will revolutionize how we diagnose, monitor, and treat mobility limitations and enable personalized rehabilitation at low cost and on a massive scale using wearable sensing technology in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a crippling condition that impacts approximately 1 in 12 Americans, and exposure to stress has been demonstrated to both increase vulnerability to developing AUD as well as worsen AUD in those already suffering. Brain stress systems, such as the dynorphin/kappa opioid receptor (Dyn/KOR) system, have been implicated in neurological adaptations to stress and/or alcohol exposure which drive negative behavioral states. In this proposal, we examine how KORs adapt in various brain regions associated with alcohol and stress in response to chronic dependency-like alcohol exposure and a two stress paradigms in mice, in the hopes that our results will help guide pharmacological treatment of both AUD and negative affect conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: We have shown that grafts of human neural stem cells (NSCs) improve motor recovery after cervical contusive spinal cord injury (SCI) in a large animal model. The present work will increase understanding of mechanisms underlying graft-related improvements and will explore pharmacological and molecular methods of enhancing NSC-mediated regeneration and functional recovery after SCI in a large animal model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: The research will deliver a low-cost, fieldable, non-cryogenic multichannel system to enable interleaved measurements of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in the ultra-low field (ULF) regime (<< 1 T) and magneto- encephalography (MEG) of the human brain, substantially benefiting functional brain imaging with enhanced image quality and speed. The advanced biomedical technology will aid in diagnosis and treatment of multiple brain disorders with the potential to provide new insights into brain function. The hybrid MEG-MRI system could resolve lack of clinical MEG-MRI imaging services in suburban and regional locations, impacting public health care services in the USA as well as worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will determine the underlying mechanisms for ADAR1 sensitivity in triple-negative breast cancer. The ARF tumor suppressor directly binds to ADAR1, and ARF's loss in triple-negative breast cancer allows for ADAR1 to repress type I IFN signaling and inhibit immune cell infiltration. Accomplishing the aims in this proposal has critical implications for informing new approaches in treating triple-negative breast cancer through activation of IFN signaling in the tumor microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mendelian disorders associated with increased IFN levels have now been grouped as a distinct disease category. These patients develop debilitating and potentially fatal conditions where the pathogenesis is poorly understood and therapeutic options are limited. We have identified a murine model of DNaseII deficiency that recapitulates many of the clinical features of patients with DNaseII hypomorphic mutations, including liver fibrosis. This application will explore the interplay between nucleic acid sensors and elevated levels of type II and type III IFNs in the pathogenesis of DNaseII deficiency and related disorders that can lead to liver fibrosis. The mechanisms we are exploring are highly relevant to human disease and the key to future targeted therapies.
