IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: With the rise in opioid use disorder (OUD) and overdose, racialized disparities in buprenorphine access and use are a significant concern nationally—studies estimate that Black patients with OUD are 50-60% less likely to access buprenorphine compared to White patients, and similar disparities have also been observed for Hispanic/Latinx patients. COVID-19-related policy changes increased flexibility in the provision of buprenorphine and other effective medications for OUD over telehealth and present an unprecedented opportunity to examine impacts of a structural intervention—relaxed MOUD restrictions—on disparities that result from structural racism and discrimination (SRD). The proposed study, guided by Public Health Critical Race Praxis, will use data from the nation's largest provider of substance use care and quantitative and qualitative methods to examine the impact of these policy changes on racialized disparities for Black and Hispanic/Latinx patients to inform future policy and interventions to improve equitable care for OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The discovery and characterization of novel immunotherapy targets is required to improve upon the response rates and overall survival of patients. A novel regulator of T cell activity, TrIP, has been shown to improve anti- tumor immunity in mice, but the mechanisms of these effects are poorly understood. This proposal seeks to explore in more detail the effects of TrIP modulation on individual T cell subsets using tumor models to better evaluate its potential as an immunotherapy target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: It is now established that single nucleotide polymorphisms that are associated with disease predominantly map to regulatory regions. We suggest that a vast majority of these will affect the timing by which paired regulatory elements find each other in order to activate gene expression. These are very early studies but we expect that insights from these experiments will provide new insights and future directions relating to the role of space and time in gene regulation/somatic recombination and how this relates to health and the development of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Chronic kidney disease is a common problem in the general community and the early changes in the kidney tissue that predict which people will develop chronic kidney disease are not well understood. This study will study the structures and proteins in kidney tissue specimens of patient populations that undergo removal of one kidney by surgery and have a relatively normal remaining kidney. The goal is to develop artificial intelligence-based image processing tools and protein marker tests that can identify kidney tissue with high risk features for the subsequent development of chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breathing is a critical physiological behavior that supports life from our first moment to our last. Anatomically and genetically diverse populations of neurons in the brainstem are responsible for both the effortless persistence of breathing from birth to death, and the flexible control that allows for complex behaviors like feeding and vocalizing. This project utilizes novel experimental techniques to unravel how neural populations distributed throughout the brainstem work together and how they are reconfigured to control different breathing frequencies and gasping.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This grant will prepare Biomedical Engineering seniors from diverse backgrounds with the knowledge, skills and perspectives to be able to develop and translate safe biomedical technologies to improve public health. Students will learn how to design a medical device within a multifunction team following the biodesign innovation process, starting with student identified needs assessment focusing on preventing medical device failures and project identification originated within a summer clinical immersion, and completing the course with a functioning prototype. In addition, in a team-based environment, the class teaches students advanced medical device failure analysis so that students understand modes of failure, are able to design safe reliable medical devices and techniques for simulating and evaluating failures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative A high-level spinal cord injury (SCI) interrupts supraspinal regulation of sympathetic activity to the heart. The imbalance of sympathetic and parasympathetic outflow leads to cardiac and hemodynamic disorders. In this project, we will determine whether integration of transplanted raphe nucleus-derived neural progenitor cells (RN-NPCs) or human induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-derived serotonergic progenitors with spinal cord circuitry reestablishes serotonin regulation to improve cardio-electric transduction. Meanwhile, we will test whether combining RN-NPC transplants with exercise further enhances the reconstruction of sympathetic regulation to restore cardiac activity, hemodynamics, and autonomic dysreflexia after SCI. The results will provide vital guidance to future clinical therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Bladder cancer (BCa) is a common solid tumor with poor outcomes in advanced disease with the most significant prognostic factor being the presence of metastasis. While much work has been done on identifying the presence of metastatic tumor cells in lymph nodes, little research currently explores the mechanisms that govern BCa progression to metastasis. These studies will define the role of mitochondrial DNA in BCa metastasis and open an entirely new area of development for biomarkers, therapeutics, and targeted preventative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Failure to maintain asthma symptom control is a major cause of lost school and workdays. This project aims to evaluate the role of the Triggering Receptor Expressed On Myeloid Cells 1 (TREM1) signaling pathway in the pathobiology of poor asthma control. We will use genomics to define the pathway components most pertinent in asthma control. We will evaluate a soluble form of TREM1 (sTREM1) as a potential biomarker of asthma control. We will also evaluate a TREM1 inhibitor as a potential non-steroidal therapy for asthma management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer's disease is one of the most prevalent and impactful diseases in the United States and throughout the world. Currently no effective treatments or therapeutics that slow or stop Alzheimer's disease are available. This project seeks to determine the mechanism by which changes in the gut microbiota and gut permeability can modify the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease. The proposed work is expected to result in new information that can inform the development of new therapeutic strategies or treatments for Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Our project tackles the heterogeneity in individuals at high-risk for psychosis which has been a long-standing challenge in the field of psychiatry. This challenge has hampered investigation and therapeutic intervention for decades. Using objective biomarkers to parse this heterogeneity in the early phase of the illness, we seek to describe this population and its subgroups, predict outcome, and provide the basis for personalized early therapeutic interventions for the purpose of preventing the illness before it arises.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Autoreactive B cells play central roles in the pathogenesis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This study investigates a novel bispecific antibody-based immunotherapy designed to engage T lymphocytes to selectively destroy autoreactive B cells in SLE. The goal of this proposal is to generate precise, effective, and safe immunotherapies to treat autoimmunity without impairing the normal, protective B cell pool in SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This research is highly relevant to public health because of the rapidly growing population of childhood cancer survivors and the increasing burden of late effects from therapy on survivors, families, and the healthcare system. Determining specific medical and neurocognitive late effects that increase psychosocial morbidity, as well as protective factors, will inform more effective interventions to optimize quality of life in children affected by early onset cancer. This is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will extend human life and help to reduce the burdens of illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health because it explains how scleral remodeling is regulated during myopia development and evaluates efficacy/safety of the first pharmaceutical treatment modality that accelerates natural crosslinking for myopia control. Our mechanism and treatment discoveries will likely translate to humans due to the usage of a close-to-primate animal model and may provide a new and safe treatment to battle the myopia epidemic representing a significant global health concern.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Von Willebrand Factor is a circulating blood protein important for staunching bleeding at sites of endothelial injury. Von Willebrand Disease (VWD), the most common bleeding disorder worldwide, is due to mutations in VWF, causing variable degrees of excess bleeding. To inform therapeutic efforts to alleviate morbidity from VWD, the proposed research will expand our structural understanding of the tubule VWF adopts intracellularly, a potential target for modulating VWF’s hemostatic function, before secretion into blood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Epidemiological data suggest that traumatic brain injury (TBI) represents an important environmental risk factor for several devastating neurodegenerative diseases including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD) for which no effective therapies are available. We and others have reported that a genetically encoded program governed by the axon destruction factor SARM1 clearly promotes TBI-associated neurodegeneration and a role for SARM1 has also been proposed in ALS/FTD. Here we investigate the role of repetitive TBI in initiating pathology and determine whether the mechanisms linking TBI and ALS/FTD converge on the neurodegenerative pathway governed by SARM1 in search of a therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease is a progressive, life-altering condition characterized by substantial burden, increased health care costs, and disproportionate prevalence in older adults. Because older adults often require support from family care partners to self-manage chronic disease, it is critical to acquire an understanding of how to best support both patients and their care partners as they work together to manage the full course of chronic kidney disease. This proposal leverages existing resources, uses multi-method approaches, and proposes data collection to understand the different ways in which older patient-family care partner dyads work together to manage chronic kidney disease over time and the impact of shared disease management on health and well- being at both the individual- and dyad-level; this information will then be used to adapt and test the feasibility of a novel, family-centered intervention designed to jointly benefit patients and family care partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Idiopathic transverse myelitis (ITM) is a single immune mediated attack of the spinal cord leading to paralysis, numbness and bowel/bladder dysfunction. We found a genetic mutation in families with ITM and we propose to model this genetic mutation in cell culture and human research. Understanding how this genetic mutation causes alterations between the immune and nervous systems will provide important insights into the cause of the disease as well as mechanism to test new therapies.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Danionella cerebrum is a novel adult transparent vertebrate model that is in its infancy and provides an exciting opportunity to advance our understanding of dynamic and complex biological processes through non-invasive in vivo live imaging and optogenetic manipulations. This proposal outlines the strategy to build an infrastructure for the use of this model that includes the development of live imaging techniques, transgenic lines, DNA reagents, as well as methods for tissue injury of adult D. cerebrum. We will generate fluorescent and activity reporter transgenic animals for the study of immune-related processes involved in the development of, injury to, and disease progression in multiple organ systems.

PHR: Narrative Sleep is a basic biological need and sufficient sleep is required for physical and mental well-being. Here we propose to investigate the molecules that accumulate in the brain to signal sleepiness. The identification of such molecules in the brain would reveal targets for the improvement of sleep and provide important insights into its neural regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES

PHR: Viral infections bring about profound changes in the host cell, either as a means to enhance viral replication or as a consequence of the host anti-viral response. This project investigates the changes induced by herpes simplex virus infection on the host nuclear factors responsible for key steps in RNA processing. Understanding how these factors influence viral reproduction and spread may lead to new therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: The Behavioral Health of Venezuelan Families in Diaspora: A Cross-National Study of Migration-Related Stress and Resilience Project Narrative: Public Health Relevance Venezuelans are among the fastest-growing immigrant groups in the United States (US), filing two times the number of US asylum applications annually as citizens from any other country. Our preliminary research— coupled with surveillance statistics and front-line journalism—suggests that depression and alcohol misuse are very important challenges for this population, and that many Venezuelan crisis migrants are exposed to high levels of stress before and after migrating. This research will provide us with knowledge vital to addressing the needs of Venezuelan crisis migrant families, and will inform responses to future crisis migrations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Regulators of small GTPases play a central role in tuning the strength of synaptic connections. The aims of this project focus on defining the activation mechanisms and allosteric regulation of a prominent negative regulator of both Ras and Rap signaling. The proposed research is relevant to public health because delineating the regulatory mechanisms of synaptic signaling is a prerequisite to developing therapeutics and biomarkers for the mental health disorders that arise from its dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Adolescents with single ventricle heart disease (SVHD) show brain injury in regions which impact cognition that can affect their academic achievement, self-care ability, quality of life, mortality, and morbidity. However, the potential processes that can contribute to brain changes in SVHD in cognitive regulatory areas are unclear, but may include hypoxemia from lower O2 saturation and reduced cerebral blood flow from lower cardiac output, resulting to impaired brain metabolites and antioxidant levels, and cerebral blood flow deficits in those areas, as well as altered serum biomarkers. The findings from this study will have potential implications for identifying effective interventions that could be implemented on large clinical trial to rescue/restore brain metabolites and cerebral blood flow, which could benefit cognitive health, as well as improve mortality and morbidity, academic performance, and increase quality of life in this high-risk patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE – Declines in cognitive function due to Alzheimer’s Disease threaten the independence and quality of life for many older adults. This project will provide valuable new information regarding a potential novel therapeutic strategy with strong potential for translation to humans. This approach targeting a highly-promising and underexplored area has important potential for improving late-life health.

PHR: Project Narrative: Overall Our Center is focused on understanding the environmental and health impacts of biologically active, environmentally persistent free radicals (EPFRs). These pollutant-particle systems, emitted from thermal treatment of Superfund or other hazardous wastes, have been shown to impact respiratory, cardiovascular, and metabolic health. Currently, no rules or regulations for limiting or monitoring EPFRs in the environment exist, and the studies from our Center will guide environmental and public health policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a devastating brain disease in aged population that has no cure. Mounting evidence supports that regular exercise has profoundly positive impacts on AD; however, the scientific reasons are poorly understood. We have obtained evidence and generated animal models to unveil the functional role and control of the removal of damaged/unfunctional mitochondria, the powerplants of cells, in the nerve cells in the brain by two types of exercise training (aerobic exercise and weight training) to mitigate AD in mice and lay solid foundation for developing effective therapeutics for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative: Administrative Core Environmentally persistent free radicals (EPFRs) are pollutant-particle systems emitted from thermal treatment technologies, or wind-blown dusts created during remediation and containment activities of Superfund wastes. Our research has shown that inhalation exposure to EPFRs elicits cardiac and pulmonary dysfunction. The Administrative Core supports the program’s goals by providing a cohesive administrative structure to manage the diverse aspects of the Center and ensuring that our data improves public health by guiding site remediation, decision-making, and environmental policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative: Community Engagement Core (CEC) The new CEC consists of two major initiatives: the LSU Clean Air Research Engagement for Superfund Communities (LaCARES) and the LSU SRP Environmental Health Literacy Project. LaCARES is a CBPR program wherein residents of two communities where TT of hazardous materials has been conducted share their observations and work with Center researchers to help select locations for new field samplers to detect and assess exposures to EPFRs. The LSU SRP Environmental Health Literacy Project will include bidirectional engagement with Superfund communities where TT may be used as a site-remediation method and an annual break-out meeting during the Dellinger Symposium for community leaders, regulators, industry representatives, and researchers to explore best practices for CBPR and exposure-reducing strategies for EJ communities.

PHR: Project Narrative: Materials Core The MC is a support Core whose main purpose is to provide combustion-borne PM that contain EPFRs to the research Projects for the study of their properties and health effects. This is achieved by synthesis of such particles in a laboratory environment and from PM field sample retrieval from media (collected in Project 3), followed by chemical characterization and distribution to Projects 1, 2, 4 and 5 for further study. The MC will also provide analytical expertise to all projects in respect to chemical analysis and thermal decomposition analysis of samples, as needed by the Projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative: Inhalation Toxicology Core (ITC) Major objectives of this Superfund Research Program (SRP) include determining the in vivo and in vitro responses of cardio-pulmonary system components following exposures to real-world, EPFR-containing particles. We have developed a customized Venturi-based aerosolization system to generate EPFR-rich aerosols for both in vivo and in vitro exposures, thus allowing for maximum direct comparability between the two exposure modalities. The ITC will provide the expertise, facilities, and equipment necessary for LSU SRP investigators to expose either mice or cell cultures to aerosolized and well-characterized EPFR-rich aerosols.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT. The at age death, tau form o frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD-tau) is a class of neurodegenerative diseases found autopsy that underlies a wide range of clinical dementia syndromes, commonly affecting individuals under 65. The proposed work aims to clarify the relationship between FTLD-tau, pathologic markers of cell in vivo MRI atrophy patterns, and distinct clinical features of FTLD-related dementia syndromes. f Findings will inform our understanding of the putative substrates of neurodegeneration in FTLD-tau, and are highly relevant to the future development of disease-specific biomarkers and therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research examines how muscles involved in communication and swallowing are affected by radiotherapy and chemoradiation. Experiments will examine how increased muscle activity in the form of tongue exercise or neuromuscular electrical stimulation may mitigate radiotherapy and chemoradiation-induced deficits in the muscular microenvironment. Further, this work will determine how different treatment modalities induce biological changes and improved function in radiated and chemoradiated tongue muscles

PHR: Project Narrative: Project 2 Our project will examine the mechanisms underlying the cardiovascular responses and toxicities produced by inhalation of environmentally persistent free radicals (EPFRs), a unique type of pollutant found at Superfund sites and produced by thermal treatment of those sites. Our studies will provide important new data linking exposure to EPFRs with the development and progression of cardiovascular disease. This information is critical for assessing risks to those living in proximity to sites using thermal treatment technologies to remediate Superfund or other hazardous wastes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Large craniofacial defects missing a multitude of tissue types from birth, trauma or cancer resection often require complex reconstruction using free tissue transfer, a procedure with high donor site morbidity. Highly translational research would focus on the transfer of engineered, pluripotent stem cells that could induce multi-tissue regeneration in a three dimensional manner. The project characterized herein, which proposes to utilize human adult-derived urine stem cells induced by BMP9 and Notch signaling pathway and novel 3D-printed, citric- acid/graphene scaffolds, has relevance to patients with congenital and acquired complex defects of the craniofacial skeleton.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative: Project 3! This study addresses questions related to human exposure to EPFRs, a recently realized class of pollutant species found at Superfund sites and formed during certain TT processes. Specifically, this research will provide critical information about the extent and duration of air (i.e., EPFR, PM, etc.) and detonation-related noise pollution in communities near Superfund and other TT sites handling hazardous wastes. This comprehensive picture of exposure will have important implications for guiding environmental and public health policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative: Project 4 Project 4 is researching the formation of the pollutants called EPFRs, which are associated with the emission of PM from TT of Superfund site materials. We are focused on revealing the mechanism of EPFR activation in biological media and the generation of hydroxyl radicals, which are responsible for health effects associated with PM exposure. We are also developing methods for EPFR emission control during TT of Superfund site wastes, as well as methods for detection of EPFRs in communities residing near TT sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative: Project 5 The researchers in Project 5 are determining the microscopic identity of a new chemical species, an interfacial pollutant called an EPFR. As well as understanding the microscopic structure of these new chemical species, we are studying the elementary processes that are responsible for their formation (e.g., charge and spin transfer) as well as their decay. In so doing, we will be able to design rational and effective approaches for limiting the production of EPFRs and also for neutralizing them once formed, thereby ameliorating their dangerous health effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative - MUSC Gastroenterology (GI) and Hepatology Medical Student (MUSC-GIHMS) Training Program The pool of physicians engaged in research is shrinking, and there is a need for physician researchers. The goal of the MUSC Gastroenterology (GI) and Hepatology Medical Student (MUSC-GIHMS) Training Program is to engage, inspire, and excite talented medical students in the area of biomedical research on digestive, pancreatic, and liver disease through a focused program specifically designed to facilitate and enhance a research experience for them. We anticipate that students who are exposed to GI research through this program will be motivated to pursue a career in GI and liver disease oriented research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retrotransposons are the most abundant elements in animal genome and their activation has fundamental impact on host biology. Our proposed study aims to understand how retrotransposons achieve their DNA replication to shape host biology via a process of circular DNA production. This research will have the potential to provide new insights on controlling retrotransposons and on harnessing them to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE While U.S. demographics are becoming increasingly diverse, individuals from historically underrepresented groups are lacking in the biomedical workforce. As studies indicate that diverse teams outperform homogeneous teams, this underrepresentation compromises the capacity to build high-performing scientific research teams. Thus, the goal of UNC PREP in the Biomedical Sciences is to address this need by equipping, encouraging, and empowering talented undergraduates from groups that have been historically underrepresented in the biomedical workforce to pursue and succeed in top biomedical graduate programs and careers through immersive, mentored research experiences, comprehensive relevant professional development, and a continued support network upon program completion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have discovered highly active, orthogonal sortase mutants that recognize unique peptide sorting motifs, enabling repeated covalent assembly and disassembly of surface bound biomolecular constituents, thereby providing a means to regenerate anti-thrombotic constituents on blood contacting films after device implantation. We have also developed new chemoenzymatic schemes leading to the discovery of a synthetic heparin that is resistant to heparanase mediated biodegradation, forming the basis of a novel family of highly durable and rechargeable heparin thin films. We believe that breakthroughs by the investigative team in protein engineering, carbohydrate synthesis, heparin structural biology, and materials science offer an opportunity to extend the lifetime of anti-thrombotic blood contacting films with a commensurate improvement in the clinical performance of a variety of implanted cardiovascular devices.

PHR: The proposed work aims to investigate the sex-specific myofilament-based alterations that underlie diastolic dysfunction in HFpEF and the role of female androgens in postmenopausal HFpEF. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This work will uncover cues that integrate DNA replication with cell cycle progression and genome stability and will entail comprehensive analyses on the role of pre-replicative proteins in interconnecting these events. The proposed research is relevant to public health because the accomplishment of the proposal will provide fundamental mechanistic insights into the mechanism of genome inheritance. Thus, the project is relevant to NIH’s mission of studying the molecular basis of the proper functioning of a cell, and this would have direct implications for biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Steady emergence of microbes displaying acquired drug resistance phenotypes has prompted health organizations to declare multidrug resistance a global public health concern. In addition, multidrug resistance compromises the efficacy of cancer treatment. The proposed studies will yield a structural dynamic blueprint for transporters underlying basic multidrug resistance phenomena in bacteria and humans, knowledge which can be exploited to develop strategies to inhibit these transporters.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The association between early life exposures and development of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in children and young adults may be mediated by epigenetic mechanisms; however, the specific epigenetic modifications implicated in NAFLD risk remain largely unknown. We recently identified 1,488 novel putative human imprinted gene control regions throughout the genome and our goal is to identify aberrant methylation in those imprint control regions that is associated with the development of NAFLD. We propose one of the most rigorous investigations of this association, leveraging a large, multi-ethnic birth cohort with longitudinal data and specimens from birth to young adulthood, state of the art imaging of liver fat content and fibrosis, and a novel array able to systematically measure methylation at all imprint control regions – mechanistically linking early life to NAFLD and laying the foundation for improved early detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small vessel injury leads to multi-organ impairment and death in children undergoing bone marrow transplant through the development of thrombotic microangiopathy or TMA. The proposed research project will test the hypothesis that TMA is triggered by dysregulation of components of the immune system, namely complement and interferon. Examining longitudinal blood samples from children with and without TMA will identify key initiators of TMA, allowing for the future study of targeted treatments to prevent organ damage and death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endemic Burkitt's lymphoma (BL), the most prevalent childhood cancer in Equatorial Africa, is a rapidly growing B-cell malignancy that is ultimately fatal if untreated. The knowledge gained by this study will improve the understanding of the etiology of endemic BL which will ultimately allow for the design of tools aimed at the prevention of BL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Blood pressure is higher in males than it is in females. We discovered that a receptor known as OLFR558 is responsible for this sex difference, but we don’t understand how OLFR558 is regulated. In this proposal, we will study activators (‘ligands’) for OLFR558 to reveal how it regulates blood pressure differently in males and females, and to determine if modulating OLFR558 is a potential therapy in hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The nephrology workforce in the Unites States is declining, despite a significant prevalence of kidney diseases and hypertension. There is an unmet need to engage undergraduate medical students in nephrology early in their career decision-making process. The goal of this proposal is to engage rising second-year medical students at the University of South Florida and the University of Florida in a 10-week summer program that will stimulate interest in the field of nephrology by allowing participants to (i) gain depth and better understanding of renal physiology, (ii) engage in experimental methods to elucidate kidney function, and (iii) see first-hand how basic science and clinical research translates to the patient bedside.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE C1 inhibitor is a multifunctional serine protease inhibitor that serves as a major endogenous inhibitor of the contact pathway of coagulation. This proposal will also evaluate the therapeutic potential of exogenous C1 inhibitor as a novel hemostasis sparing anticoagulant.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: This proposal will use fruit flies to investigate how the testis and reproductive neurons distinctively interpret the genetic code of life. Our approach takes a distinctive look at genetic code interpretation in the context of reproduction and fertility. Our preliminary findings in fruit flies closely parallel genetic code interpretation in humans, and so our studies are highly likely to impact human reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Diversity in the biomedical research workforce elevates scientific innovation and impact to levels necessary to impact human health and well-being. Underrepresented minorities and persons with disabilities face systemic issues that impede their research training, which limits this diversity. This renewal of PREP@UGA builds on the program’s successes to date and continues to advance the diversity of the biomedical research workforce by recruiting recent post-baccalaureate underrepresented minority and disabled students and providing research-intensive training and professional development to facilitate their transition to and success in biomedical PhD programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE There is limited information on health effects from wildland-urban interface (WUI) fires, which burn a mixture of vegetation, structures, and vehicles. The proposed research will work in partnership with firefighters to evaluate their exposures and toxic effects from WUI fires, and evaluate the effectiveness of exposure-reduction interventions. The proposed research will provide a more complete measure of chemical exposures from WUI fires and associated health effects, and inform exposure prevention measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mount Sinai PREP seeks to increase the participation of individuals from underrepresented minority groups and socioeconomically disadvantaged individuals at the cutting-edge levels of biomedical research, and seeks to accommodate individuals with disabilities. Research shows that diverse groups function more effectively and innovatively than groups lacking diversity. Major benefits to public health will result from further diversification of the biomedical work-force and a diverse work-force will increase engagement and expert focus on problems related to health and health care disparities, which are in need of such focus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug-induced liver injury (DILI) is a serious adverse drug reaction that can occur with the use of many prescription and non-prescription medications and lead to mild-to-severe liver damage. DILI is a leading cause of acute liver failure and the most common reason for drug recalls. This project seeks to develop a next- generation, animal-free human DILI risk prediction platform through human liver tissue engineering and the development of a microfluidic organ-on-a-chip. Results from this study could improve DILI risk prediction and may ultimately lead to the development of safer and more effective medications and identify potential strategies to treat DILI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will generate three atlases that describe the molecular signatures, anatomical phenotypes, and three-dimensional distribution of mouse spinal cord cell types over developmental time. These rich datasets will serve as a fundamental resource for the spinal cord field and address a long-standing gap in knowledge linking adult cell types to their developmental lineage. The atlases will focus on cell types that mediate somatosensation and thus, lay important groundwork for cataloging spinal cell types in native states that can be compared to injured or diseased states, referenced to other species, and used for cell-type regeneration and engineering efforts of spinal cord tissue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the rapid growth of antibody-based drugs, challenges limiting their success as a therapeutic class persist, including the development challenges of high attrition rates and the therapeutic challenge of heterogeneous benefit across patient populations. A key driver of these issues is our poor understanding of antibody pharmacology across biological contexts, and antibody therapeutics frequently fail in translation when their mechanism of action cannot keep up with the diverse and dynamic biological contexts and tissue environments. Our research has focused on developing systems modeling methods and spatiotemporally-resolved molecular imaging tools to investigate antibody pharmacology across biological contexts and resolve issues that hinder the development and application of antibody drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Dynamic RNA modifications have emerged as an exciting new mechanism of post-transcriptional regulation of gene expression. We propose a nanopore RNA sequencing strategy that will read an RNA modification twice, first through the copied strand and then the template strand, where the copied strand provides the “ground truth” for the modification in the template strand. This 2-read strategy will improve reading RNA modifications with accuracy and quantification to facilitate investigation of their important roles in human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-range goal of the University of Chicago Post-Baccalaureate Research Education Program (PREP) is to help diversify the scientific workforce. The PREP provides mentored research experiences and academic enhancements in the form of skill-building workshops and courses, with the aim of preparing members of groups underrepresented in the biomedical and behavioral sciences for admission to PhD (or MD/PhD) programs at competitive research institutions. To assess the success of this endeavor, the participants’ progress will be followed throughout their graduate programs and subsequent career path.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because genetic and acquired diseases affecting the airways pose major disease and economic burdens. Small molecule CFTR potentiators or correctors have provided groundbreaking improvements in the quality of life for most people with CF; however, these drug treatments are not cures and provide no benefit to the ~10% of CF patients with nonsense CFTR mutations. Unlike small molecule potentiators or correctors, a CFTR gene editing approach is potentially a single dose, life-long curative therapeutic strategy for many people with CF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative In this project, we propose to develop and apply spatially resolved single-cell transcriptomics and epigenomics methods to classify cell types and states, map their spatial organization, and determine cell-type-specific cell- cell interactions in the human brain. Our results will provide fundamental insights into the structure and function of the human brain at the molecular and cellular level. The technological innovations and scientific results obtained from this project can also be applied to understand brain diseases and aging.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite their low cost and high level of safety, it is still unclear whether antihypertensive and statin therapy prevent Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias because randomized trials have provided mixed results and were often limited by short follow-up times, low statistical power, and a lack of representativeness for the broader population and routine care. Along with machine-learning techniques for heterogeneous treatment effect estimation, this project will apply a novel and well-validated method in large-scale electronic health record data from the US, UK, and Denmark to obtain causal evidence on the effects of antihypertensive and statin therapy on the incidence of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. In doing so, we aim to inform clinical and public health guidelines as well as directions for research on dementia prevention, and ultimately encourage similar efforts in other areas of medicine where our approach can be applied.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The biomedical research community at UC Santa Cruz has played a leading role in broadening participation in pre-graduate and graduate research training programs. Through extensive programming and various support services based on best practices, we create an inclusive and equitable environment for underrepresented students to succeed in attaining higher degrees in the biomedical field. With this PREP proposal, we will broaden training opportunities for recent graduates so that they will be able to gain admission to and complete a top-ranked Ph.D. program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The technology developed during this project will enable direct, true single-molecule, high-accuracy RNA sequencing, including the ability to identify specific modifications thereof, all via the unprecedented ability to iteratively read a given RNA molecule. Enabling accurate transcriptomic and epitranscriptomic investigations via a single technology will be a significant advancement relative to current state-of-the-art technology in the field, which presently requires a combination of techniques and/or chemical reactions that even then cannot fully access the range of nucleotide modifications. Ultimately, an ultra-high-accuracy RNA sequencing technology that can reliably distinguish canonical and modified nucleotides within a RNA strand will propel transcriptomics and epitranscriptomics research and developments into the future and directly enable the associated RNA-based diagnostics, prognostics, and therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Most delirium treatments developed to date have been ineffective in improving outcomes such as accelerated cognitive decline, because they modify risk factors for delirium development and are uniformly administered to all patients 24 to 48 hours after admission. We propose this randomized control trial to determine if early (<24 hours) cognitive training and rehabilitation improve 6-month global cognition in older delirious patients with and without Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. To identify patients who may benefit more from the cognitive intervention, we will also perform latent class analysis to identify novel delirium phenotypes, and determine if they modify the relationship between the cognitive intervention and 6-month global cognition.

PHR: Narrative Invasion in glioblastoma is a major contributor to poor prognosis. We have identified interstitial fluid flow across the invasive edge of tumors to stimulate glioma cell invasion through effects on cancer cells and the surrounding microenvironment. Here we will probe the nature and effects of interstitial fluid flow in glioma invasion and identify new targets and strategies against this deadly disease

ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Developmental exposure to endocrine disrupting compounds such as organophosphate flame retardants (OPFRs) may disrupt cognitive processing in the adult offspring. It is well known that chronic stressful experiences can result in maladaptive states that impair learning and memory processes in both rodents and humans. The combination of developmental OPFR exposure and adult chronic stressors may further exacerbate cognitive impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC) is a highly aggressive disease that has limited treatment options. This proposal focuses on determining if a protein called YES1 may underlie the malignancy associated with TNBC and the molecular pathways it uses to cause poor patient outcomes. This work will also provide a proof-of- concept in model systems testing the possibility of inhibiting YES1 with drugs that may ultimately lead to a more effective approach for treating TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Dysregulation of the anti-apoptotic BCL2 family of proteins allows cancer cells to survive. Results from the proposed studies will significantly increase understanding of an understudied BCL2 family member and its contribution to lymphoma survival and resistance to targeted therapies. Our studies will ultimately lead to improved therapeutic targeting for the treatment of lymphomas and likely other malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT – Abramson Cancer Center Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States and prevalent in the ethnically diverse catchment area of the Abramson Cancer Center (ACC), which consists of 12 contiguous counties in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Delaware, in which 81.4% of ACC's patients reside. Through our Research Programs and Community Outreach and Engagement, the ACC addresses the burden imposed by highly prevalent cancers in the catchment area, including breast, prostate, lung, colorectal, melanoma, and lymphoma. ACC basic, clinical, and population science research – along with Community Outreach and Engagement Activities – are integrated to prevent, diagnose, and treat these cancers and address cancer risk factors to promote healthy living.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Patients harboring mutations in both KRAS and LKB1, two of the most frequent mutations detected in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), develop aggressive lung tumors, show a high frequency of metastases and are resistant to therapeutics. Using genetically engineered mouse models (GEMMs) of KRAS-mutant, LKB1- deficient (KL) NSCLC, we have demonstrated that autophagy is required for KL lung tumor initiation and tumor growth. In this proposal, we will explore the mechanism by which autophagy regulates lipid metabolism for KL tumorigenesis in vivo, determine how autophagy promotes KL tumor metastasis, and identify metabolic bypasses that potentially create resistance to autophagy inhibition in KL NSCLC. Our overall goal is to validate the novel concept that autophagy inhibition is a selective and powerful therapeutic strategy against primary and metastatic KL NSCLC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Cerebral small vessel disease (SVD) is a major cause of stroke, white matter (WM) disease and dementia, but the mechanisms underlying brain damage and cognitive decline remain largely elusive. This US-China Biomedical Research Collaboration project will apply cutting edge MRI technologies in a unique cohort of Chinese patients with genetically defined SVD (NOTCH3 mutation carriers suffering from cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy or CADASIL), to understand the role of blood-brain barrier (BBB) in the initiation and progression of SVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current leukemia treatments although effective in achieving remission, fail to eliminate leukemia stem cells, resulting in a high rate of relapse. The proposed research aims to develop improved understanding of the mechanisms and role of altered mitochondrial metabolism in leukemia stem cell preservation and treatment resistance, and identify metabolic vulnerabilities that can be targeted to enhance elimination of leukemia stem cells and improve outcomes for leukemia patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Therapeutic  exploitation  of  oncogene  addiction  has  become  a  central  aim  of  modern  cancer  therapy,  but  effective targeted therapies for aggressive cancer types including hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) are lacking.  In  this  proposal,  a  collaborating  team  of  experts  will  investigate  whether  a  valid  approach  for  therapeutic  interventions  in  HCC  can  be  based  on  a  strategy  to  inhibit  supportive  non- oncogene  addiction  pathways,  interfering  with  tumor- promoting  metabolic  reprogramming  and  improving  the  predicted  power  of  anti- tumor  immunity  through  depletion  of  Hsf1.  This  research  will  provide  the  rationale  to  develop  novel  strategies  to  prevent, and perhaps treat, cancers, including HCC, that arise on the background of chronic hepatic injury due  to impaired liver metabolism, protein homeostasis and suppression of anti- tumor immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Our project proposes to form an academic-industrial partnership to translate a novel lung function imaging modality into radiotherapy clinical care for lung cancer patients. The novel lung function imaging modality is referred to as `4DCT-ventilation,' and uses 4-Dimensional CT data along with image processing techniques to innovatively calculate lung functional maps. 4DCT-ventilation has great potential to reduce toxicity and improve outcomes for lung cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy. Our project will develop methods that will enable widespread clinical integration of this novel imaging modality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetic kidney disease (DKD) is the common cause of end-stage renal disease in the US. However current regimen provides only partial therapeutic effects and the incidence and prevalence of these diseases remains high, suggesting that the key pathogenic mechanisms driving DKD progression are not adequately inhibited by current treatments. The current proposal to study the glomerular endothelial cell injury in the diabetic kidney could help us to develop potential new therapy for DKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Solid tumors remain one of the leading causes of death in the United States because their complex microenvironment resists conventional treatment modalities. I have generated a novel IL12 prodrug that potently activates immune cells without adverse effects, allowing the administration of doses capable of eradicating solid tumors in mice. Through pharmacokinetic and mechanistic studies, I will ascertain exactly how this prodrug functions, bringing it one step closer to treating cancer in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Research Narrative The United States is facing an opiate epidemic that is spiraling out of control, with a recent CDC report finding that drug overdoses kill one and a half times more people annually than motor vehicle accidents. The proposed research of the effects of cannabis on opiate use is timely and would address a glaring gap in the knowledge base in ways that could potentially have an important public health impact. The proposed patient-centered, observational, adaptive intervention design will compare three broad classes of cannabis products: a THC only product, a product that has a 1:1 THC to CBD ratio, and a CBD only product over the course of 12 weeks in a sample of individuals who want to reduce their opiate use and plan to use cannabis to do so.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a common, high-mortality disease, with no generally effective therapies. Immature cancer cells are strongly implicated in therapy failure but are challenging to identify. New analytical tools will allow us to determine the molecular diversity and tumorigenic potential of immature cancer cells in TNBC, thereby laying a foundation for the development of new therapies to improve TNBC outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Although a mainstay for treatment of many cancers, the clinical utility of Doxorubicin (Dox) is severely limited by cardiotoxicity and there is a critical need for new therapies to mitigate these adverse effects but without interfering its efficacy against cancer. The proposed research will establish the sphingolipid enzyme nSMase2 as a mediator of Dox-induced cardiotoxicity through effects on cardiomyocyte cell death and cardiac fibrosis, and in proof-of- principle studies will demonstrate that nSMase2 inhibitors reduce cardiotoxic effects of Dox but without impacting its anti-cancer activity. Collectively, these studies will advance our basic understanding of the pathogenesis of Dox-induced cardiotoxicity and will establish nSMase2 as a novel and viable druggable target for cardioprotection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Synaptic strength must be regulated in the face of changing levels of input in order to ensure that neurons are able to maintain their output firing within reasonable limits. Homeostatic regulation of action potential duration and synaptic efficacy works in conjunction with acutely induced Hebbian plasticity to maintain network stability and information flow. This project will study the features and mechanisms of adaptation to chronic disuse aiming to advance our understanding of how cells remodel themselves, and shed light on abnormal responses in disease states, including autism spectrum disorders.

PHR: Narrative Biomedical research drives the future of medicine, as new discoveries provide understanding of and treatments for disease. There are clear disparities in the number of underrepresented individuals who become biomedical researchers. Virginia Commonwealth University Postbaccalaureate Research Education Program (VCU PREP) will continue its successful program to prepare underrepresented scholars for highly competitive doctoral programs, and for research careers in the biomedical sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Repeated cycles of alcohol intoxication and withdrawal foster adaptations in brain regions that regulate mood, learning, and goal-directed behavior. This project centers on a previously undescribed alcohol-induced adaptation in the amygdala that involves a molecular target implicated in anxiety and learning. By investigating the mechanisms underlying this adaptation and its impact on circuit function and behavior, we will gain a better understanding of processes that drive alcohol withdrawal-related behavior and may identify new targets for therapeutic intervention designed to treat alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will take human and animal model genetic approaches to understand the basis of phenotypic variability of congenital heart disease among 22q11.2 deletion syndrome patients. We will analyze whole genome sequence from subjects with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome with/out congenital heart defects and validate discoveries in mouse and zebrafish models. Some of the genes studied may also be risk factors for sporadic congenital heart disease in the general population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Obesity is associated with increased risk for chronic diseases and mortality. Diet and eating behaviors are important modifiable behaviors that can reduce obesity and help maintain a healthy weight. The proposed project will study the association between cognition, specifically inhibitory control, and eating and dietary intake behaviors in a sample of adolescents with the goal of elucidating inhibitory control as an important factor related to eating and dietary intake behaviors in adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative  Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is a typical progressive neurodegenerative disease in which a majority of upper and lower motor neurons (UMNs and LMNs) are degenerated. In ALS, dysfunctions of MN axons have been widely observed, which often precede motor neuronal soma and axon degeneration. This project will investigate novel roles of astroglial exosomes in promoting axon growth, functions, and (motor) neuron survival especially in ALS models. Results from this project will reveal a new astroglial exosomal HepaCAM-mediated pathway and downstream signaling in modulating (motor) neuron axon growth and survival. It will also provide important knowledge about the loss-of-functional effect of astroglial exosomes in ALS. These studies will significantly advance our understanding of the astroglial dysfunction in ALS and help develop new astroglia-based neuroprotective strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  For the millions of individuals who experience migraine each year, treatment typically consists of reactively treating attacks only after experiencing disruptive pain and secondary symptoms. Because individual migraine attacks are unpredictable to most sufferers, efforts to make future attacks more predictable will enhance treatment effectiveness and reduce suffering. This project will create a new forecasting model that predicts the risk of future migraine attacks for an individual person.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulation of transcription and splicing is pervasive across all human cancers, however very few approved therapies exist that target these processes. This Program Project seeks address this deficiency through target discovery, validation, and deep mechanistic investigation. The insights gained through this research are likely to reveal highly specific, new vulnerabilities in cancer cells that will be the basis of innovative drug development in the fight against cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 1 – TARGETING ONCOGENIC TRANSCRIPTION FACTORS PROJECT NARRATIVE Specific oncogenic transcription factor complexes have been identified by this Project as therapeutic opportunities in aggressive carcinomas of the pancreas and breast. To exploit these targets for cancer therapy, we will employ the latest innovations in genome editing technology and biochemistry to elucidate `druggable' interactions involving these factors. A major thematic focus of this work will be to leverage RNA biology and signaling interactions to allow for pharmacological modulation of oncoproteins.

PHR: PROJECT 2 – RNA-SPLICING DYSREGULATION IN CANCER PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA splicing is a fundamental step in the normal function of genes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Activation of the immune system by immunotherapy can be used for the treatment of cancer but major gaps in our knowledge compromise optimal outcomes. This project will study how immunotherapy affects the differentiation of myeloid cells, a major component of the innate immune system, and their ability to crosstalk with T lymphocytes and attack cancer. This work may significantly improve the outcome of immunotherapy and provide a major benefit to cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Pathological tau protein accumulates as lesions in neurons of patients with Alzheimer's disease and Alzheimer's Disease Related Dementia disorders. Aberrant tau causes neuronal dysfunction and neurodegeneration. Tauopathy disorders have no effective treatment, are progressive, and ultimately cause premature death. The molecular basis underlying the neurotoxicity of pathological tau remains poorly understood. Our previous studies have demonstrated the unfolded protein response can detoxify pathological tau. Completion of the proposed work will inform the molecular mechanisms of tau mediated neurodegeneration setting the stage for future translational studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: One of the major tasks of red blood cells (RBCs) is to carry oxygen from the lungs to tissues throughout the body. The goals include the discovery of membrane protein channels responsible for the movement of oxygen into or out of RBCs. Another goal is to understand how the absence of these channels causes experimental animals have greater exercise efficiency. Achieving these goals could have a major positive impact for patients with an impaired ability to carry oxygen from the lungs to their tissues (e.g., reduced exercise in heart failure).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE BRAF-mutant anaplastic thyroid cancers are almost always incurable and frequently lethal. They are heavily infiltrated by myeloid and T cells. We propose to investigate the relative contribution of myeloid cell depletion and antigen presentation by tumor cells in their remarkable response to MAPK inhibition, because they point to ATC vulnerabilities that could be targeted through alternative approaches, as well as to eventual mechanisms of resistance to this therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Homologous recombination is a DNA repair pathway, which plays crucial roles in genetic disorders, cancer and aging. Several tumor suppressor proteins are now known to participate in homologous recombination, and defects in these proteins are broadly associated with human cancers. Included among these are BRCA1 and BRCA2, which are key proteins involved in the early stages of homologous recombination, and are frequently mutated in hereditary breast and ovarian cancers. To help extend our understanding of how BRCA1 and BRCA2 participate in homologous recombination we have developed a powerful new experimental platform based on state-of-the-art optical microscopy that enables us to directly observe the proteins that participate in homologous recombination in real time. These powerful new research tools allow us to address questions in cancer research that cannot be tackled with more traditional experimental approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 3 – REGULATORY RNAS AS CANCER DRIVERS AND DEPENDENCIES PROJECT NARRATIVE Project 3 will characterize the function of several long non-coding RNAs that are over-expressed in basal-like triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) and basal-like pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). The impact of antisense oligonucleotide knockdown on cancer progression and metastasis will be studied using patient-derived organoid xenograft models. Insights gained from this study will significantly impact considerations of new therapeutic approaches to treat basal-like TNBC and basal-like PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heterogeneous and inadequate blood flow and obstructive stroma in pancreatic tumor microenvironment (TME) are the critical determinants of extrinsic resistance while cancer stem cells contribute to intrinsic resistance to chemotherapy and selective targeting of these barriers can significantly enhance the delivery and efficacy of chemotherapeutic agents. We propose to undertake studies to target endothelin axis using selective and clinically-tested antagonists with a goal to improve the efficacy of GEM/ABX using preclinical models of pancreatic cancer. Further, we propose to evaluate the safety of ET-axis antagonist bosentan in combination with FDA approved combination of chemotherapeutic agents (Abraxane and Gemcitabine- GEM/ABX) in pancreatic cancer patients in a Phase I trial with a goal to generate meaningful data for a future Phase I/II clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  New England is one of the epicenters of the opioid overdose crisis, with five New England states ranking in the top 10 with the highest overdose deaths. This mentored research proposal will evaluate the preliminary effectiveness and implementation of measurement-based care (MBC) as a treatment progress monitoring tool to enhance pharmacological treatment for opioid use disorder in community settings. Results of this rigorous, mixed methods study will advance understanding of MBC’s effectiveness and implementation potential in community opioid treatment programs, setting the stage for future research focused on scaling up MBC to enhance opioid treatment and reduce the impact of the opioid overdose crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Although tremendous progress has been made in treatment modalities of acute myeloid leukemia (AML), there is the necessity to improve and develop novel therapeutic approaches. We propose to develop a strategy based on Gene Expression Analysis (GMA) profiling to identify patients with AML displaying specific preferences for repairing spontaneous and drug-induced DNA damage. DNA repair pathways will be then attacked by GMA-guided DNA repair inhibitors eventually combined with standard treatment to eliminate leukemia stem and progenitor cells without affecting normal cells and tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the discovery of mechanisms linking demyelination to neuronal hyperexcitability and neurodegeneration will increase understanding of the pathogenesis of numer- ous neurological disorders and diseases including multiple sclerosis, trauma, and stroke. The project is relevant to NIH's mission, as the research pursues fundamental knowledge of glial-neuronal interactions in the brain, and how they go awry in the context of demyelinating disease, which may provide a foundation for the develop- ment of novel and more effective strategies to treat neurological disorders by selectively targeting specific glial- neuronal interaction mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: CORE B – ORGANOID BIOBANK PROJECT NARRATIVE Tractable experimental models that accurately recapitulate human pancreatic and breast carcinoma biology are critical to the overall goal of this Program Project Grant. Core B will provide all three Projects with access to a large human patient-derived organoid biobank, which includes hundreds of breast and pancreatic cancer samples. Expertise and methods for evaluating transcriptional and splicing dependencies will be provided to provide deep insights into biomarkers and molecular mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disruption of mitochondrial dynamics and quality control are key components of leading causes of disability, such as cerebrovascular disease and age-related neurodegeneration. The proposed research aims to investigate the contributions of dysfunctional mitochondrial quality control to cerebral ischemia/reperfusion injury, as well as the onset and progression of neurodegenerative disease. Utilizing innovate molecular and computational techniques, these studies will advance our understanding of mitochondrial dysfunction and inform the development of future therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Some Latino subgroups are at greater risk of heart disease than others based on years in the US, generations in US, and country of origin. Prior large-scale studies assessing these risks have treated this racially diverse population as monolith, failing to capture the variety racial characteristics that can affect how Latino subgroups develop heart disease. We propose to improve how we measure and identify racial subgroups within Latino populations to better understand differences in heart disease risk, permitting specific, targeted solutions for racial health inequities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths in the USA, with an estimated 158,000 deaths in 2016: the direct cause of these deaths is the eventual emergence of resistance to initially effective therapies, which is a process driven by Darwinian evolution. To better understand, and prevent the emergence of this resistance, we propose an integrated mathematical and experimental research project focused on discovering and targeting the ecological and evolutionary mechanisms driving resistance in EGFR mutated non-small cell lung cancer. Our overarching goal is find evolutionarily informed treatment strategies using existing drugs to extend the survival of patients with this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE  Marshallese are a subpopulation of Pacific Islanders that are experiencing significant health disparities, with some of the highest documented rates of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in the world. Culturally- appropriate diabetes self-management education and support (DSMES) has been shown effective in other minority communities; however, no DSMES has been shown effective and sustainable with Marshallese in the Republic of the Marshall Islands. It is critically important to determine a DSMES intervention that is effective, scalable, and sustainable in this population experiencing extreme health disparities and a crisis in rates of T2DM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Myotonic Dystrophy type 1 is a complex disease characterized by CNS dysfunction. Patients with the severe congenital DM1 (CDM1) are intellectually challenged. There is no cure for CNS dysfunction in DM1. We propose to apply new mouse model to determine the cause of CNS dysfunction in CDM1. The development of drug for the reduction of CNS pathology in CDM1 will be performed in mouse model of CDM1. The obtained knowledge will be used for the developing clinical trial for pediatric patients with CDM1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment, and specifically Alzheimer’s disease, represents one of the most significant healthcare problems in the aging population of the United States, and development of effective therapy will be facilitated by understanding its underlying mechanisms. We are studying a protein called synaptobrevin1/VAMP1 and present strong argument for the association of VAMP1 to Alzheimer’s disease, which has public health relevance. After completion of the proposed research we will have developed a new model that offer insight into the mechanism and potential treatment of Alzheimer’s disease leading to dementia in the elderly, thus the proposed research is aligned with the mission of NIH that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burdens of human disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Sleep and circadian disorders are extremely common and impact all aspects of public health. There is a need for new investigators to study sleep and circadian rhythm biology and examine their impact on cardiovascular, metabolic, pulmonary and neurodegenerative disease and overall quality of life. The goal of this joint training program with experienced faculty from Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and New York University Grossman School of Medicine is to provide mentored post-doctoral training in sleep and circadian science encompassing basic science and clinical research.
